title: Covid-19 Symptom Tracking Survey
body: Covid-19 Symptom Tracking Survey Creating a Symptom Tracking Survey Sending a Symptom Tracking Survey Analyzing & Exporting Results Covid-19 Symptom Tracking Survey Covid-19 Symptom Tracking Survey Creating a Symptom Tracking Survey Sending a Symptom Tracking Survey Analyzing & Exporting Results ENTERPRISE FEATURE: The COVID-19 Symptom Tracking survey is only available in the United States (US). If you're interested, contact sales . If you already have an Enterprise account, contact your Customer Success Manager. The COVID-19 Symptom Tracking and Risk Assessment survey is a tool to help your employees return to work safely. Start with a template with key questions to help make decisions about coming in to work. Based on people's answers, they'll be put into groups and you can set up a custom message to help guide their next steps. We have enabled our HIPAA security features for all SurveyMonkey accounts that have purchased the COVID-19 Symptom Tracking and Risk Assessment survey. Creating a Symptom Tracking Survey Start by setting up the survey in the Design Survey section. This is where you review the questions and add in the custom message with next steps for people to take after submitting their response. Design Your Survey Log into your SurveyMonkey account . Click Create Survey . Choose Start from a template . Choose the COVID-19 Symptom Tracking and Risk Assessment template. Once you have the basic template you can start customizing or adding new questions . You can customize existing questions by clicking Edit on the one you want to change. It's not possible to use skip logic with this template. Instead, we score questions (similar to quizzes ) and let people know next steps based on their answers. Each question in the template has point values assigned, and the total points determine the person’s score group. Each score group will see a different message at the end of the survey. The template has the points set up for each question, but you can edit the points depending on the needs of your organization. Points are assigned based on how people answer each question. For example, in the default template, people who answer Yes to "Have you had any symptoms of COVID?" or "Have you had contact with anyone who has been diagnosed with COVID?" are placed in the Stop group . People who answer No to these questions are placed in the Go group .If you don’t make any edits, these default point values will apply. Assigning points to new questions If you add new questions to the survey, they will automatically have scoring turned on. If you ask questions about additional symptoms or risk factors, add points to the answer choices so that people's answers place them in the right group. If you don't want the new questions to be counted in the results, uncheck the box that says Score this question . This will remove the option to add points to that question. If you add new questions to the survey, they will automatically have scoring turned on. If you ask questions about additional symptoms or risk factors, add points to the answer choices so that people's answers place them in the right group. If you don't want the new questions to be counted in the results, uncheck the box that says Score this question . This will remove the option to add points to that question. TIP! Once you open the template, Genius Assistant will pop up to guide you through the setup process. You can click through the prompts to make sure your survey is ready to go. Customize Messages Based on Answers To make sure people know next steps after taking the survey, customize the message that people see based on their score group. To customize the messages people see at the end of the survey: On the left sidebar of the Design Survey section , click Options . Click Score Groups . By default, people are put into 2 groups depending on their answers Go group: People with a score of 0. Stop group: People with a score of 1 or more points. Go group: People with a score of 0. Stop group: People with a score of 1 or more points. Click the group you want to customize the message for. The point range is already configured for you based on the survey template. We don't recommend changing this. Write your Message title and Message . Click Save . You'll need to repeat the steps to customize messages for both score groups. Preview the Survey Preview your survey to make sure everything works the way you expect it to. You can take the survey and make sure the correct message displays based on your answers. If something doesn't look right, go back to the Design section and make changes. Sending a Symptom Tracking Survey When you're ready to send your survey, you can choose any collector type . For daily surveys that will get sent to the same group of people, we recommend using the email invitation collector . You can customize the invitation, track who has responded, and set it up to re-send on specific days and times. Add Your Contact List If you're using the Email Invitation collector, create a contact list to make sure the right people get the survey. This also gives you more control over your recipient list because you can add and remove people as needed. Set Up an Email Invitation Go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Choose Email . Click Add Contacts . Click Contacts . Choose the group you want to send the survey to and click Add . Customize the Message section and write what you want people to see when they open the invitation. Click Next . (Optional) Choose any collector options . If you want people to get a copy of their responses, turn Email Results On. Click Next . Make your survey recurring If you want to automatically send the survey to the same group more than once, select recurring email . Then, choose the time and dates you want the survey to be sent. When you use a recurring email, it creates a new message in the same collector each time the survey is sent to that same group. If you add or remove people from your contact list, new messages will be sent to the most up-to-date list. TIP! If you want to set up a contactless survey for one time survey takers or visitors, use the QR code Web Link collector option. Choose How to be Notified About Responses There are two ways to get notified about survey responses: Instant notifications: Get an email after every survey response. Smart notifications: Get an email when a response meets certain criteria. How to set Smart notifications for responses indicating exposure to COVID-19 You can use Smart notifications to get an email when someone indicates that they may be exposed to COVID-19. To set up the notification: Go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Click Manage Notifications . Click the Create button next to Smart notifications. If you're using the template, set the Trigger so that if the answer to questions about COVID-19 exposure is exactly yes, you will get an email. Click Save . You can use Smart notifications to get an email when someone indicates that they may be exposed to COVID-19. To set up the notification: Go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Click Manage Notifications . Click the Create button next to Smart notifications. If you're using the template, set the Trigger so that if the answer to questions about COVID-19 exposure is exactly yes, you will get an email. Click Save . Analyzing & Exporting Results Analyzing Results You can view all responses to the survey in the Analyze Results section. Click the Question Summaries tab to see a summary table with the survey taker's name and their Stop or Go status. To see a specific survey taker's responses, click their row in the summary table. Filtering for Responses By default, there are 2 filter rules set up for you: Go Group: People with a score of 0. Stop Group: People with a score of 1 or more points. Click the filters to turn them on or off. When a filter is on, only responses that match that response group will show. TIP! You can use other filter types to sort responses too. For example, filter by collector or respondent metadata to find people by name. Exporting Results To get the simplest view of your data, we recommend choosing the XLS All Responses Data when you export your results. To export individual responses: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Click Save As at the top of the page. Click Export file . Choose All Responses Data . Choose the XLS File Format and select Current view if you want to export with filters you turned on in Analyze. Click Export . Under Exports in the left sidebar, click the export to download the file to your computer. Sharing Survey Responses with Others If you want other people to view the survey data, you can share your exports or create a Shared Data page . The shared data page will include the summary table you see in Analyze. If you use a shared data page, people will be able to see data about individual survey takers. Learn more about our sharing options: Sharing Survey Results Related Articles Company SurveyMonkey About Us Jobs Blog Help SurveyMonkey Help GetFeedback Help Market Research Help SurveyMonkey Audience Help SurveyMonkey Contribute Help Wufoo Help Apply Help Support Site Status Unsubscribe Contact Us Email Opt-In Policies Legal Center Privacy Policy Cookies Notice California Privacy Notice

title: Using Inclusive Language
body: Using Inclusive Language Main Considerations Gender Identity Sexual Orientation Race, Ethnicity & Nationality Using Inclusive Language Using Inclusive Language Main Considerations Gender Identity Sexual Orientation Race, Ethnicity & Nationality After you create your survey and write your questions, you should take a moment to make sure that your questions are written inclusively and with sensitivity to the experiences of marginalized individuals. We’ve offered some suggestions below on the main considerations and common pitfalls that people run into with writing inclusive language. Main Considerations Use person-centered language It’s important to value people more than the specific rules we have around language. We should always focus on the person rather than specific aspects of the person as it is dehumanizing to refer to someone using just an aspect of their identity. Ultimately, our language should be used in a way that is respectful, caring, and informed by how the individual chooses to identify. When in doubt, put the word ‘person’/’people’ before any descriptors about an individual or community. Consider the context of your language Unless it is essential to what is being communicated, you should avoid identifying people based on characteristics such as their race, skin colour, national origin, gender, disability, age, sexual orientation, and religious or spiritual affiliation. Do your research Inclusive language regularly changes because of the terms that people use to self-identify change. Regularly researching the appropriate language to use when referring to marginalized peoples and communities helps in speaking about others in a way that is both respectful and inclusive. Gender Identity When creating questions based on gender, you should consider whether it is even relevant. If gender is relevant, it is ideal to use gender-neutral terms wherever possible - unless you know the pronouns of the reader. Additionally, you should never assume the gender of an individual based on their appearance. Sexual Orientation When asking questions based on sexual orientation, it is essential to be inclusive of all relationship statuses and orientations. As well, it is important to consider if someone’s sexuality is even relevant to the content. Some individuals may self-identify using terms that were or are derogatory, as a means of reclaiming the meaning behind the language. These terms can only be used to self-identify and should not be used if you aren’t a part of the community the terms have targeted. Race, Ethnicity & Nationality When asking questions about race, ethnicity & nationality, it is essential to refer to individuals and communities using the terms they prefer to be referred to as. Unless it is essential and appropriate to the context, avoid referring to people based on their race, skin colour, and/or national origin. As well, it is especially important to avoid generalizations and stereotyping people based on someone’s skin colour, cultural background, or ethnic origin. title: Using Themes to Style Surveys
body: Using Themes to Style Surveys Applying a Theme Types of Themes in the Theme Library Creating Your Own Themes Customizing your Themes Editing Details and Limitations Classic Themes Accessible Surveys Using Themes to Style Surveys Using Themes to Style Surveys Applying a Theme Types of Themes in the Theme Library Creating Your Own Themes Customizing your Themes Editing Details and Limitations Classic Themes Accessible Surveys You can change the appearance of your survey by changing the colors or fonts, applying a theme, or customizing options like adding a logo or removing the footer. Applying a Theme To apply a theme to your survey: Go to the Design Survey tab in any survey. Select Style . Select the Themes tab. Select any theme to apply it to your survey. As you build your survey, you can always use the rich text editor to make formatting changes to specific text to override the theme settings. Theme colors apply to Email Invitations ! When you use the HTML Template with an email invitation, the header and Begin Survey button match the Survey Title Background color of your theme. Types of Themes in the Theme Library You can choose from themes in a few categories: Creating Your Own Themes There are a few ways to build your own theme: Generate a theme from an image : Use our theme generator to build a custom theme based on an image, like your company’s logo. Create a custom theme : Manually create your own custom theme. Anyone can create a custom theme and preview it on a survey. Depending on your plan and the features you use, you may be prompted to upgrade your plan or remove the paid features before you can send your survey. Generating a Theme from an Image Device limitation: Generating a theme using an image is only available to customers on desktop devices. Generate a theme to quickly customize your survey theme to match your brand’s style. All you need to do is upload an image, like your company logo, and we'll use machine learning to pull colors from the image to generate a theme. File requirements: Upload a PNG, JPG, or GIF. File size can be 2 MB or less. To generate a theme: Go to the Design Survey tab of your survey. In the Style menu, select Generate theme . If your survey already has a logo, your theme is generated based on that image. If you haven’t uploaded a logo yet, continue with the instructions below: Select Upload image . Choose whether to Use image as my logo . Select Generate theme . SurveyMonkey generates and saves your theme. Select Upload image . Choose whether to Use image as my logo . Select Generate theme . SurveyMonkey generates and saves your theme. Choose from the suggested font, color, and layout options to customize your theme. If you want to add a color, click + under Select theme color . You can use more detailed customization tools later. (Optional) Use the thumbs up and down buttons to tell us whether the generated theme works well for you. Select Done . To find your generated theme, go to the My Themes section of the Themes tab. Theme generation isn't available if your survey uses a classic theme. Create a copy of your survey to use this feature. For Teams and Enterprise plans, this feature may not be available if an admin has set a default logo in your library . Manually Creating a Custom Theme Custom Themes To create a custom theme: Go to the Design Survey section in any survey. In the left sidebar, click Style . Select the Themes tab. Under My themes , select Create custom theme . Your theme is saved in the Style menu under My themes. In the Settings tab, customize your theme. Customizing your Themes To edit custom and generated themes: Open the Style menu. Go to the Themes tab. Scroll to My themes . Find your theme, then select the three dots menu. Select Edit . Theme Settings These are the sections you'll find in the Settings tab as you're customizing your theme. Logo and footer settings aren't carried over when you apply your custom theme to a different survey. Nickname Enter a name for your theme to stay organized. Respondents won't see this. Enter a name for your theme to stay organized. Respondents won't see this. Logo When you add a logo you can choose to position your logo Left , Center , or Right . When you add a logo you can choose to position your logo Left , Center , or Right . Footer You can hide SurveyMonkey branding from the bottom of your survey design. You can hide SurveyMonkey branding from the bottom of your survey design. Fonts You can change the font type, style and size for the survey title, survey questions, and answer choices. The font formatting used for your thank you message , disqualification message , over-quota message , or password required message is inherited by the Answer Choices font settings. You can change the font type, style and size for the survey title, survey questions, and answer choices. The font formatting used for your thank you message , disqualification message , over-quota message , or password required message is inherited by the Answer Choices font settings. Layout You can use layouts to choose how and where your background color or image is displayed. You can use layouts to choose how and where your background color or image is displayed. Background Image You can upload your own background image or select one from thousands in our gallery. How your background image displays and what size your image should be depends on the type of device and screen size. We recommend uploading your background image, then previewing your survey to see what it will look like on multiple device types. To change the background image: Click Replace . Choose From Computer or From Image Gallery . Click Done . Backgrounds on Mobile Devices How background images display on mobile or tablet devices depends on which layout you choose: Full background surveys don't display the image. Instead, the survey background color will show. Partial background surveys will display the image by shrinking it to fit the device. Images larger than 600px may be cut off. TIP! When you select a background image, it's automatically used as your Thumbnail Image . You can further customize your Thumbnail Image & Text in the collector options. You can upload your own background image or select one from thousands in our gallery. How your background image displays and what size your image should be depends on the type of device and screen size. We recommend uploading your background image, then previewing your survey to see what it will look like on multiple device types. To change the background image: Click Replace . Choose From Computer or From Image Gallery . Click Done . Backgrounds on Mobile Devices How background images display on mobile or tablet devices depends on which layout you choose: Full background surveys don't display the image. Instead, the survey background color will show. Partial background surveys will display the image by shrinking it to fit the device. Images larger than 600px may be cut off. TIP! When you select a background image, it's automatically used as your Thumbnail Image . You can further customize your Thumbnail Image & Text in the collector options. Colors You can change the color of the elements listed in the table below by using the color picker, or entering your own hex codes. Element Description Title Text The text color of your survey title . Quiz score text takes on the Title text color selection, so choose contrasting Title text and Survey background colors. Question Text The text color of your survey questions. Answer Choice Text The text color of a question's answer options. Accents Accents are things like buttons, progress bars, and selected checkboxes. Accent Text The text color for accents like buttons, progress bars, and selected checkboxes. This color will always appear on top of the Accents color, so make sure there’s enough contrast so it’s easy to read. Survey Background The background color that appears behind the questions in your survey. If you’re using a background image, this color is hidden. Secondary Background If you’re using a background image, this color overlays on top of the background image. You can control the Overlay Opacity in the Background settings to make the text in your survey easier to read.If you’re using a Split Background layout, this is the background color of the Third, Half, or Banner part of the layout. The Survey Background color will only show if you haven't added a Background Image. You can change the color of the elements listed in the table below by using the color picker, or entering your own hex codes. Previewing Your Theme As you customize your theme, you can view your changes on the right side of the page. However, to see the background image, you need to preview your survey. Editing Details and Limitations There are a few things to keep in mind when editing your themes: Fonts Font You can choose from several popular fonts for your survey. Choosing a font from the Font menu applies it to every text element in your survey. You can override the main font for the Survey Title or Page Title by selecting a different font in those specific sections. Font Size & Style For each of the following text elements in your survey, you can edit either the text size, style (bold, italic, or underline), or both—depending on the element. Element Text Size Style Survey Title ✅ ✅ Page Title ✅ ✅ Page Description ❌ ✅ Progress Bar ✅ ❌ Question Text ✅ ✅ Answer Text ✅ ✅ Error Text ✅ ✅ Font You can choose from several popular fonts for your survey. Choosing a font from the Font menu applies it to every text element in your survey. You can override the main font for the Survey Title or Page Title by selecting a different font in those specific sections. Font Size & Style For each of the following text elements in your survey, you can edit either the text size, style (bold, italic, or underline), or both—depending on the element. Colors You can change the color of the elements listed in the table below by using the color picker, or entering your own hex codes. Number Element 1 Survey Logo Background 2 Survey Title 3 Survey Title Background 4 Survey Background 5 Page Title 6 Page Title Background 7 Page Background 8 Progress Bar Text 9 Progress Bar Indicator 10 Progress Bar Border 11 Progress Bar Background 12 Page Description 13 Error Text 14 Required Asterisk 15 Question Text 16 Answer Text 17 Answer Text Highlight The Survey Background color will only show if you haven't added a Background Image. Button Colors The background and font colors of the Next button will always match the Survey Title Background and Survey Title settings, which you can edit in the Colors section of your theme. If these colors are the same, the buttons will default to grey with black text. However, you can't change the button color if you use the Sea Foam or Autumn themes. See the Editing Limitations sections below for more information. You can change the color of the elements listed in the table below by using the color picker, or entering your own hex codes. The Survey Background color will only show if you haven't added a Background Image. Button Colors The background and font colors of the Next button will always match the Survey Title Background and Survey Title settings, which you can edit in the Colors section of your theme. If these colors are the same, the buttons will default to grey with black text. However, you can't change the button color if you use the Sea Foam or Autumn themes. See the Editing Limitations sections below for more information. Logo When you add a logo you can choose to position your logo Above Title , Below Title , or Left of Title . When you add a logo you can choose to position your logo Above Title , Below Title , or Left of Title . Editing Limitations Depending on the theme you're using, there may be some elements that can't be edited. Theme Editing Limitations Autumn The theme is full width, so you can't add a Background Color or Background Image.You can't edit the shape or color of the Next and Previous buttons.You can't change the height of the Survey Title Background.You can't edit or remove the circles around the question numbers. Boardwalk You can't remove the drop shadow around the survey. Charcoal You can't remove the small horizontal line under the Survey Title.Editing options are limited for Matrix/Rating Scale or Matrix of Dropdown questions.You can't update the Font Type of Answer Text. City Lights You can't change or remove the header background image.You can't change the transparency of the Survey Title Background.Editing options are limited for Matrix/Rating Scale or Matrix of Dropdown questions.You can't update the Font Type of Answer Text. Jungle The theme is full width, so you can't add a Background Color or Background Image. Midnight Editing options are limited for Matrix/Rating Scale or Matrix of Dropdown questions. Moss You can't change the rounded corners of the survey.Editing options are limited for Matrix/Rating Scale or Matrix of Dropdown questions. Ocean Editing options are limited for Matrix/Rating Scale or Matrix of Dropdown questions. Sea Foam The theme is full width, so you can't add a Background Color or Background Image.You can't edit the shape or color of the Next and Previous buttons.You can't change the height of the Survey Title Background.You can't change the color of the question numbers. Sky You can't change the rounded corners of the survey Spring Editing options are limited for Matrix/Rating Scale or Matrix of Dropdown questions. Depending on the theme you're using, there may be some elements that can't be edited. Adding CSS Themes Enterprise Admins have the option to add a CSS theme to completely customize survey fonts, colors, and branding. Keep in mind, CSS isn’t the same as JavaScript and allows styling customization, but not logic changes. To add a CSS theme, see Managing Brand Assets in the Library . Editing a Custom or CSS Theme Changes made to a custom or CSS theme affect any surveys with that theme applied. If you need to edit an existing custom theme that’s already being used on other surveys, select the three dots next to the theme and choose Duplicate . This ensures you don’t change your existing surveys. If you share a survey with a custom theme, only the survey owner will be able to make edits. Classic Themes The following themes are considered classic themes: Jungle, Sky, Ocean, Sea Foam, Midnight, Spring, Autumn, Charcoal, Moss, Aqua, City Lights, Boardwalk, and Seashell. To use a classic theme on a new survey, you can make a copy of an existing survey with the classic theme applied and the styling will carry over. It isn’t possible to use a classic theme on a survey created any other way . Incompatible Features Some features aren’t supported when using a Classic theme. If you want to add incompatible features, like the Best Worst Scale, Name, Email Address, Phone, Address questions, confirmation emails for web link surveys, or MaxDiff questions, you need to update your theme to any Standard or Premium theme. To create a copy of your survey with a compatible theme to utilize all features: Add a new Best Worst Scale, Name, Email Address, Phone, or Address question to your survey that uses a Classic theme. Click Copy survey . This keeps the rest of your survey design intact and creates an exact copy but with a compatible theme. You’re able to change your theme to any other Standard or Premium theme after copying. Accessible Surveys You can use SurveyMonkey to create surveys that are accessible to people using screen readers. Learn more: Creating Accessible Surveys Related Articles Company SurveyMonkey About Us Jobs Blog Help SurveyMonkey Help GetFeedback Help Market Research Help SurveyMonkey Audience Help SurveyMonkey Contribute Help Wufoo Help Apply Help Support Site Status Unsubscribe Contact Us Email Opt-In Policies Legal Center Privacy Policy Cookies Notice California Privacy Notice

title: Paste Your Content to Create a Survey
body: Paste Your Content to Create a Survey Create a Survey with Paste Your Content Paste Content using AI Paste Your Content to Create a Survey Paste Your Content to Create a Survey Create a Survey with Paste Your Content Paste Content using AI If you drafted your survey in a document and now need to program it into SurveyMonkey, you can Paste your content all at once, instead of adding each question one by one. Create a Survey with Paste Your Content You may need to reformat your document to recognize and properly create the Single textbox and Multiple choice questions. After adding questions this way, you can always edit and customize the output survey. To create a survey via Paste your content: Click Create survey . Select Paste your content. On the Import Questions screen, copy and paste your Multiple choice or Single textbox questions and answer choices. Each question and answer choice needs to be on their own line. Press Enter or Return on your keyboard twice to separate your questions. Each question must be separated by a blank line. In the Preview section, view the questions you add in real time. Once done entering your questions, click Add Questions to create your survey. Once the survey is drafted, you can give the survey a title , add different question types , edit or switch the question type , change the survey theme , add rich text formatting , and more. Paste Content using AI If you have your survey questions and answers already written outside of SurveyMonkey, simply Copy and paste your survey into SurveyMonkey and let AI do the rest. Paste your content is powered by OpenAI/Azure Open AI. We use machine learning and generative AI to convert your content into a survey to recognize the various survey elements within your document, of any format, and convert it into a survey. To paste your survey content into SurveyMonkey: Click Create survey . Select Paste your content as your starting point and click Create survey . To agree to use AI to create your survey, click Use AI . Copy your survey from your document and paste it into SurveyMonkey. Click Create survey . Once your survey is created, be sure to review your survey. The import may result in inaccuracies and there may be limitations impacting the import. Review your survey design for accuracy, adjust any question types , add logic , or style your survey. If you’re on the Basic (free) plan and your survey contains paid features, you’ll either need to upgrade to a paid plan or remove the paid features in order to send your survey. Enabling Paste Your Content When you choose Paste your content as your creation method, you need to select Use AI to utilize this feature. Paste your content will stay enabled and available to you until you clear your browser data. If you use a different device to access your survey, you will need to choose to Use AI from that device too to use Paste your content. Limitations At this time, any text formatting, titles or page descriptions, style elements, images or videos, page breaks, logic, and unsupported question types, won’t be captured from your document and won't be imported. Your survey is created with the following question types: Multiple choice, Checkbox, Single Textbox, Comment box, Matrix/Rating scale, and Text. A customer can paste and submit your survey up to 50 times per month. Also, please don’t paste any sensitive information, like names, into SurveyMonkey. Usage is subject to SurveyMonkey's Acceptable Uses Policy , as well as additional third party provider usage policies , and acceptable use and conduct policies. Errors If something goes wrong in converting your survey text to a survey, you’ll see an error message to provide you with info about what happened and what you can do. How We Use Your Data When Paste your content is enabled and used, your data is processed in the following ways: We use machine learning and generative AI to identify survey elements, format, and generate a survey from your pasted content within SurveyMonkey. We send the survey text you provide and an encrypted user ID to OpenAI or Azure OpenAI service to extract the survey structure, questions, text, comments, etc. and provide the feature. title: Deleting a Question
body: Deleting a Question Restoring Deleted Questions Deleting a Question Deleting a Question Restoring Deleted Questions To delete a question: On the Design Survey page, hover over the question you want to delete. Click Delete . When you delete a question, all responses associated with that question will also be deleted. Restoring Deleted Questions You can restore deleted questions within 90 days of the deletion date. You will not be able to restore deleted questions after that time frame. To restore questions that were deleted within the last 90 days: Click the Design Survey tab. Click the Trash can icon . Click a question to add it to the end of the survey. Or, drag and drop a question into the desired position elsewhere in the survey. NOTE: If you deleted questions that had collected responses, we cannot guarantee that those responses will be restored along with the question. title: Block Randomization
body: Block Randomization Block Randomization Block Randomization Block Randomization Block Randomization allows you to group pages of your survey into blocks, and then add logic to rotate, flip, or randomize the blocks. You can also add logic to the pages within a single block. This minimizes order bias in your survey. To use Block Randomization: Go to the Design Survey section of the survey. In the left sidebar, click Logic . Click Block Randomization . Create blocks. Add logic to the blocks. TIP! Your last step should be adding logic. Add all questions and pages to the survey design before creating blocks and applying logic. Creating Blocks A block is a group of consecutive pages in your survey. You can create up to 300 blocks in your survey. To create blocks: Under the LOGIC menu in the left sidebar, click Block Randomization . Click + New Block . Select the consecutive pages you want to include in the block. Some pages may be disabled if you already added logic to them that isn't compatible with Block Randomization. Click Add Block . Create more blocks, as needed. Your blocks can't be on the last page of your survey. When you're finished creating all your blocks, click Done in the bottom-left corner of the menu. Block names indicate the range of pages included in the block. For example, a block containing Page 4, Page 5, Page 6, and Page 7 of your survey would be named Block: P4-P7 . TIP! A page can only belong to one block at a time. To use the same page in multiple blocks, you can instead make a copy of the page to use in another block. Editing Blocks To edit a block: Under the LOGIC menu in the left sidebar, click Block Randomization . Click Edit Blocks . Click . next to the right of the block. Click Show block details or Break block apart . Adding Logic to Blocks You can add Block Logic to control the order in which the blocks, or pages within a block, are presented to the respondent. There are two ways to apply Block Logic: You can apply both types of Block Logic to a survey. Applying Logic Within a Single Block To apply logic within a single block: Under the LOGIC menu in the left sidebar, click Block Randomization . Under Add Block Logic, choose Within a single block . Click the block you want to apply logic to. Choose a Logic Type (see the table below for details). Under Pages Affected, choose to apply the logic to All pages in this block or Selected pages , where you can choose a subset of pages to apply the logic to. Click Apply . Logic Type Description No page randomization No logic is applied to the pages within the block. They are shown to respondents in order. Randomization Pages within the block are shown in a random order for each new respondent. Flip pages On average, half of respondents will see the pages within the block flipped. Example: 3, 2, 1 instead of 1, 2, 3. Rotate pages Each respondent will see a random first page, with the following pages of the block arranged in successive order based on the first. Example: The first respondent might see 3, 4, 5, 1, 2 within the block; the second respondent might see 2, 3, 4, 5, 1; and the third respondent might see 5, 1, 2, 3, 4. To apply logic within a single block: Under the LOGIC menu in the left sidebar, click Block Randomization . Under Add Block Logic, choose Within a single block . Click the block you want to apply logic to. Choose a Logic Type (see the table below for details). Under Pages Affected, choose to apply the logic to All pages in this block or Selected pages , where you can choose a subset of pages to apply the logic to. Click Apply . Applying Logic Across Multiple Blocks To apply logic across multiple blocks: Under the LOGIC menu in the left sidebar, click Block Randomization . Under Add Block Logic, choose Across multiple blocks . Choose a Logic Type (see the table below for details). Under Blocks Affected, choose to apply the logic to All blocks in this survey or Selected blocks , where you can choose a subset of blocks to apply the logic to. Optional: Select Limit number of blocks to display and enter a limit. Click Apply . Logic Type Description No block randomization No logic is applied across the blocks. They are shown to respondents in order. Randomize blocks Blocks are shown in a random order for each new respondent. Flip blocks On average, half of respondents will see the block order flipped. Example: 3, 2, 1 instead of 1, 2, 3. Rotate blocks Each respondent will see a random first block, with the following blocks arranged in successive order based on the first. Example: The first respondent might see 3, 4, 5, 1, 2; the second respondent might see 2, 3, 4, 5, 1; and the third respondent might see 5, 1, 2, 3, 4. To apply logic across multiple blocks: Under the LOGIC menu in the left sidebar, click Block Randomization . Under Add Block Logic, choose Across multiple blocks . Choose a Logic Type (see the table below for details). Under Blocks Affected, choose to apply the logic to All blocks in this survey or Selected blocks , where you can choose a subset of blocks to apply the logic to. Optional: Select Limit number of blocks to display and enter a limit. Click Apply . Limiting the Number of Blocks to Display If you apply logic across multiple blocks, you can also select the Limit number of blocks to display setting and enter the number of blocks you want each respondent to see. This setting can help reduce survey fatigue for any given respondent by showing them a smaller subset of blocks to answer, while still allowing you to collect responses for a larger survey. The Limit number of blocks to display setting applies to all blocks in the survey, even if the Blocks Affected setting is set to only apply logic to Selected blocks . For example, if you set a limit of 2 blocks, the respondent is shown the first 2 blocks they would have seen based on the Logic Type you applied. See the example below: Total Blocks in Survey : 4 (with no extra pages not included in a block) Number of Blocks Limit : 2 Logic Type : Rotate blocks Blocks Affected : All blocks in this survey What Respondents See : Each respondent sees the first 2 blocks they would have seen based on their position in the rotation. The first respondent sees Block 1, then Block 2, then ends the survey. The second respondent sees Block 2, then Block 3, then ends the survey. The third respondent sees Block 3, then Block 4, then ends the survey. The fourth respondent sees Block 4, then Block 1, then ends the survey. The fifth respondent sees Block 1, then Block 2, then ends the survey. If you apply logic across multiple blocks, you can also select the Limit number of blocks to display setting and enter the number of blocks you want each respondent to see. This setting can help reduce survey fatigue for any given respondent by showing them a smaller subset of blocks to answer, while still allowing you to collect responses for a larger survey. The Limit number of blocks to display setting applies to all blocks in the survey, even if the Blocks Affected setting is set to only apply logic to Selected blocks . For example, if you set a limit of 2 blocks, the respondent is shown the first 2 blocks they would have seen based on the Logic Type you applied. See the example below: Total Blocks in Survey : 4 (with no extra pages not included in a block) Number of Blocks Limit : 2 Logic Type : Rotate blocks Blocks Affected : All blocks in this survey What Respondents See : Each respondent sees the first 2 blocks they would have seen based on their position in the rotation. The first respondent sees Block 1, then Block 2, then ends the survey. The second respondent sees Block 2, then Block 3, then ends the survey. The third respondent sees Block 3, then Block 4, then ends the survey. The fourth respondent sees Block 4, then Block 1, then ends the survey. The fifth respondent sees Block 1, then Block 2, then ends the survey. The first respondent sees Block 1, then Block 2, then ends the survey. The second respondent sees Block 2, then Block 3, then ends the survey. The third respondent sees Block 3, then Block 4, then ends the survey. The fourth respondent sees Block 4, then Block 1, then ends the survey. The fifth respondent sees Block 1, then Block 2, then ends the survey. Example Block Randomization is commonly used for concept testing. Let's say you're testing three different advertisements. You'll need to create three blocks of pages, one for each ad. To show each respondent all three blocks in a random order, add logic to randomize all the blocks in the survey. All respondents will see Page 1 first and Page 8 last, and they'll see the blocks in a random order. To show each respondent only one random block, first add logic to randomize all the blocks in the survey. Then, limit the number of blocks to display to 1 . Respondents will see Page 1, then one random block selected from Block 1 OR Block 2 OR Block 3, then Page 8. Using Block Randomization With Other Logic Options You can't apply Page Randomization to any pages contained within a block—that logic option will be disabled for pages within a block. Instead, you can randomize the pages within a single block in the Block Randomization feature to achieve the same result. title: Matrix of Dropdown Menus Question
body: Matrix of Dropdown Menus Question Video Overview Creating a Matrix of Dropdown Menus Question Survey Behavior Analyzing Results Matrix of Dropdown Menus Question Matrix of Dropdown Menus Question Video Overview Creating a Matrix of Dropdown Menus Question Survey Behavior Analyzing Results Matrix of Dropdown Menus The Matrix of Dropdown Menus question allows respondents to evaluate several items using the same set of measurements by choosing from a preset list of answer choices. Video Overview Creating a Matrix of Dropdown Menus Question To add this question type: Drag and drop Matrix of Dropdown Menus into your survey from the Build section. In the Row Choices fields, enter the items you want respondents to evaluate. In the Column Choices fields, enter a label for the set of measurements you want respondents to use to evaluate the row items. Below each column choice, click Enter Answer Options and enter a list of measurements you want respondents to choose from to evaluate each row item. These are the answer options that will appear in every dropdown menu directly under that column choice. Configure any additional options. Click Save . Additional Options Under the Edit and Options tabs, you can further customize the question in the following ways: Add an "Other" Answer Option for Comments Require an Answer , and define a specific range or limit of rows that the respondent must answer Change the Question Size & Layout Sort, Randomize, or Flip Rows Learn more: Editing Questions Under the Edit and Options tabs, you can further customize the question in the following ways: Add an "Other" Answer Option for Comments Require an Answer , and define a specific range or limit of rows that the respondent must answer Change the Question Size & Layout Sort, Randomize, or Flip Rows Learn more: Editing Questions TIP! Avoid creating too many rows and columns—try not to have more than 50 answer options total. Large matrices may cause survey performance issues, and respondents may speed through the question rather than take the time to read all the answer options. Survey Behavior Before you send out your survey, preview your survey design to see what your survey will look like to respondents. If you require respondents to answer a specific number or range of rows, customize the error message to reflect the requirement so respondents will know how to answer the question correctly. Since the Matrix of Dropdown Menus can be large, keep in mind that respondents using mobile devices may have to scroll to see the whole question. Analyzing Results See example results (English only) » Charts There is a separate chart and data table for each column choice. Each chart will show how respondents evaluated each row item using the list of answer options in the dropdown menus. Learn more: Customizing Charts and Data Tables Related Articles Company SurveyMonkey About Us Jobs Blog Help SurveyMonkey Help GetFeedback Help Market Research Help SurveyMonkey Audience Help SurveyMonkey Contribute Help Wufoo Help Apply Help Support Site Status Unsubscribe Contact Us Email Opt-In Policies Legal Center Privacy Policy Cookies Notice California Privacy Notice

title: Formatting Text
body: Formatting Text Themes vs. Rich Text Editor Bold Specific Words in Question Text Supported HTML Formatting Text Formatting Text Themes vs. Rich Text Editor Bold Specific Words in Question Text Supported HTML When designing a survey, you can use the rich text editor to bold, underline, or italicize text and add images , videos , or links . Some fields have an advanced editor for more formatting options. The available options in the rich text editor vary by question type and field. To see the options available for a particular field, click directly into the field. To format text: Go to the Design Survey section. Click or highlight text in any field. Use the formatting toolbar. In some fields, you can click … to open the advanced editor. Themes vs. Rich Text Editor Themes and CSS themes ( Enterprise only ) let you apply text formatting across your entire survey. The rich text editor lets you edit text in individual fields, one place at a time. You can change the font size and style in your theme settings to control survey-wide text formatting. You can use the rich text editor to add additional formatting or to override the theme font settings for an individual text field. Save your changes to see the formatting applied by theme and the rich text editor in the survey. Formatting text using themes or the rich text editor adds HTML tags that count toward character limits . Bold Specific Words in Question Text Some standard themes have bold question text by default. In this case, you need to change the font settings of your theme and uncheck Bold under Question Text so you can go back and bold specific words in your question. Supported HTML For some parts of your survey, like the Custom Thank You , Survey Closed Message , or Email Invitations , you can use HTML to format text . title: Multiple Textboxes Question
body: Multiple Textboxes Question Video Overview Creating a Multiple Textboxes Question Survey Behavior Analyzing Results Multiple Textboxes Question Multiple Textboxes Question Video Overview Creating a Multiple Textboxes Question Survey Behavior Analyzing Results Multiple Textboxes The Multiple Textboxes question allows you to collect multiple open-ended answers with a single question. You can also configure this question to collect numerical data only. Video Overview Creating a Multiple Textboxes Question To add this question type: Drag and drop Multiple Textboxes into your survey from the Build section. Enter question text. Enter the preferred labels for each textbox. Configure any additional options. Click Save . Only Allow Numerical Data Select Only Allow Numerical Data to require people to answer with a positive or negative whole number. Only numerical digits (including ‘0’) and the minus symbol (-) are accepted. With this setting applied, survey-takers will receive an error message if they enter other characters such as commas, decimals, fractions, or percent signs. You can customize the error message that survey-takers see when an answer is not accepted. TIP! If you’d like people to enter decimal numbers within a specific range, you can use the Single Textbox question . Require a Fixed Sum This option requires that all answers add up to a fixed sum that you define. Learn More: Requiring a Fixed Sum Options Under the Edit and Options tabs, you can further customize the question in the following ways: Learn more: Editing Questions Require an Answer , and define a specific range or limit of textboxes that the respondent must answer Validate Answer for a Specific Format Change the Question Size & Layout Sort, Randomize, or Flip Textboxes Enable Question Text A/B Test Under the Edit and Options tabs, you can further customize the question in the following ways: Learn more: Editing Questions Require an Answer , and define a specific range or limit of textboxes that the respondent must answer Validate Answer for a Specific Format Change the Question Size & Layout Sort, Randomize, or Flip Textboxes Enable Question Text A/B Test Survey Behavior Before you send out your survey, preview your survey design to see what your survey will look like to respondents. Since there are so many validation options for this question type, make sure to customize the question text and error messages so respondents know how to answer the question correctly. Analyzing Results See example results (English only) » When you view your responses in the Analyze Results section, click Responses next to any textbox label to see a list of open-ended responses for that textbox. Click View respondent's answers below any comment to jump to the respondent's individual response. You can also use the text analysis features to identify and tag recurring words or themes in your open-ended text responses. Averages for Numerical Data If you selected the Only Allow Numerical Data option, we'll calculate the average for each textbox. The average is calculated as follows: Sum of numerical answers ------------------------------ Total Responses Related Articles Company SurveyMonkey About Us Jobs Blog Help SurveyMonkey Help GetFeedback Help Market Research Help SurveyMonkey Audience Help SurveyMonkey Contribute Help Wufoo Help Apply Help Support Site Status Unsubscribe Contact Us Email Opt-In Policies Legal Center Privacy Policy Cookies Notice California Privacy Notice

title: Contact Information Question (Demographic)
body: Contact Information Question (Demographic) Contact Information Question (Demographic) Contact Information Question (Demographic) The Contact Information question is no longer available to use on new surveys. Instead, use the following question types on new surveys: Name , Email address , Phone , Address . Using the Contact Information question type, you can collect respondent demographic information through a single question. Video Overview Using a Contact Information Question It isn't possible to add the Contact information question to new surveys. However, this question remains available on existing surveys. By default, the following fields are available, but you can customize the field labels to collect different pieces of information you might need: Name Company Address Address 2 City/Town State/Province ZIP/Postal Code Country Email Phone You can also choose to hide some of the available fields by deselecting the Visible checkbox to the right of each field under the Edit tab. Displaying State as a Dropdown of U.S. States By default, the State/Province field will display as an open-ended text field. However, if you know that all of your respondents live in the United States, you can choose to display the State field as Dropdown of U.S. States. This will make it easier for respondents to select the appropriate answer, and eliminate the chance of typos. Displaying Countries as a Dropdown There is no way to display the Country field as a dropdown menu, but you can add a Dropdown question type right after the Contact Information question. You can copy and paste a list of countries into a Dropdown question, or use a pre-written question from the Question Bank . Additional Options Under the Options tab, you can further customize the question in the following ways: Require an answer for all fields, or only a subset Change the question size & layout Enable question text A/B test Learn more: Editing Questions Under the Options tab, you can further customize the question in the following ways: Require an answer for all fields, or only a subset Change the question size & layout Enable question text A/B test Learn more: Editing Questions Survey Behavior Before you send out your survey, preview your survey design to see what your survey will look like to respondents. You can't validate the Contact Information question type to require respondents to answer in a specific format, length, or range. Respondents will not encounter validation error messages, but they may see an error message if they don't answer all of the required fields that you define under the Options tab. Analyzing Results When you view your results in the Analyze Results section, you can use the Tagging Responses and Word Cloud features to identify recurring words or tag responses for each textbox. Charts are not generated for this open-ended question type. Related Articles Company SurveyMonkey About Us Jobs Blog Help SurveyMonkey Help GetFeedback Help Market Research Help SurveyMonkey Audience Help SurveyMonkey Contribute Help Wufoo Help Apply Help Support Site Status Unsubscribe Contact Us Email Opt-In Policies Legal Center Privacy Policy Cookies Notice California Privacy Notice

title: Adding Tables
body: Adding Tables Editing Tables Properties Merging or Splitting Cells Managing Rows, Columns, and Tables Adding Tables Adding Tables Editing Tables Properties Merging or Splitting Cells Managing Rows, Columns, and Tables You can use the advanced rich text editor to add a table to your survey in the following supported fields: Text added from the Build section Question text for any question type Page Description To add a table: Click the ... icon in the rich text editor to open the advanced rich text editor. Click the table icon and then Insert table . Drag your cursor over the grid to choose the dimensions of the table and click to insert it. You can create a table as large as 10 x 10 cells. If you need to add more, you can insert additional rows or columns after you add the table. Click and drag any corner of the table to resize it and make it easier to add text into each cell. Enter text in the cells. Editing Tables You may need a basic understanding of HTML to use some table options. Properties Properties control the appearance of the table as a whole, an individual row in the table, or an individual cell in the table. Table Properties Table properties control the appearance of the table as a whole. To edit table properties: Select anywhere in the table. Select the Table icon and then Table properties . Option Description Width The width of the table, in pixels. Height The height of the table, in pixels. Cell spacing The space between cells, in pixels. Cell padding The space between the cell wall and the cell content, in pixels. Border The width of the border around the perimeter of the table, in pixels. Caption Inserts a center-aligned caption cell above the table. Alignment The horizontal alignment of the table within the survey page—left, center, or right. Style Enter style attributes to apply inline CSS to this table. Border color The color of the border around the perimeter of the table. Background color The background color of the entire table. Table properties control the appearance of the table as a whole. To edit table properties: Select anywhere in the table. Select the Table icon and then Table properties . Cell Properties Cell properties control the appearance of an individual cell in the table. To edit cell properties: Select the cell you want to edit. Select the Table icon > Cell > Cell properties . Property Description Width The width of the cell, in pixels. Height The height of the cell, in pixels. Cell Type Header : Designates the cell as a header cell for the row or column. Text in the cell is bold and center-aligned. Cell : A normal data cell in the table. Scope Associates this header cell with a specific set of data cells. Row : This cell provides header information for the rest of the row that contains it. Col : This cell provides header information for the rest of the column that contains it. Row group : This header cell provides header information for the rest of the row group that contains it. Column group : This header cell provides header information for the rest of the column group that contains it. H Align The horizontal alignment of the text within the cell—left, center, or right. V Align The vertical alignment of the text within the cell—top, middle or bottom. Style Enter style attributes to apply inline CSS to this cell. Border color The color of the border around the individual cell. Background color The background color of the individual cell. Cell properties control the appearance of an individual cell in the table. To edit cell properties: Select the cell you want to edit. Select the Table icon > Cell > Cell properties . Row Properties Row properties control the appearance of an individual row in the table. To edit row properties: Select the row you want to edit. Select Table icon > Row > Row properties . Property Description Row type The row type indicates what type of content the row contains: Header : Adds a thead tag around the row or rows to group them as the header content of the table. Body : Adds a tbody tag around the row or rows to group them as the body content of the table. Footer : Adds a tfoot tag around the row or rows to group them as the footer content of the table. Alignment The horizontal alignment of the text within every cell in the row—left, center, or right. Height The height of the row, in pixels. Style Enter style attributes to apply inline CSS to this row. Border color The color of the border around the perimeter of this row. Background color The background color of every cell in this row. Row properties control the appearance of an individual row in the table. To edit row properties: Select the row you want to edit. Select Table icon > Row > Row properties . Merging or Splitting Cells Merging cells combines two or more cells together. Splitting cells breaks aparted merged cells. Merging Cells To merge cells: Select the ... icon in the rich text editor to open the advanced editor. Select and drag to highlight the cells you want to merge. Select the Table icon . Select Cell . Select Merge cells . To merge cells: Select the ... icon in the rich text editor to open the advanced editor. Select and drag to highlight the cells you want to merge. Select the Table icon . Select Cell . Select Merge cells . Splitting Cells To split a cell: Select the ... icon in the rich text editor to open the advanced editor. Select the cell you want to split. Select the Table icon . Select Cell . Select Split cell . To split a cell: Select the ... icon in the rich text editor to open the advanced editor. Select the cell you want to split. Select the Table icon . Select Cell . Select Split cell . Managing Rows, Columns, and Tables Insert or delete rows and columns, or delete the entire table. Adding, Moving, or Deleting Rows To insert, move, or delete a row: Select the row you want to take action on by clicking any cell in the row. Select the Table icon > Row . Choose one of the following options from the menu. Option Description Insert row before Inserts a new row above the row that's currently selected. Insert row after Inserts a new row below the row that's currently selected. Delete row Deletes the row that's currently selected. Cut row Removes the row that's currently selected and adds it to your clipboard so you can paste it elsewhere in the table. Copy row Adds the row to your clipboard so you can paste it elsewhere in the table. Paste row before Inserts a cut or copied row above the row that's currently selected. Paste row after Inserts a cut or copied row below the row that's currently selected. To insert, move, or delete a row: Select the row you want to take action on by clicking any cell in the row. Select the Table icon > Row . Choose one of the following options from the menu. Adding or Deleting Columns To access column options: Select the column you want to take action on by clicking any cell in that column. Select the Table icon > Column . Option Description Insert column before Inserts a new column to the left of the column that's currently selected. Insert column after Inserts a new column to the right of the column that's currently selected. Delete column Deletes the column that's currently selected. To access column options: Select the column you want to take action on by clicking any cell in that column. Select the Table icon > Column . Deleting a Table To delete a table: Select the ... icon in the rich text editor to open the advanced editor. Select the table to select it. Select the Table icon . Select Delete table . To delete a table: Select the ... icon in the rich text editor to open the advanced editor. Select the table to select it. Select the Table icon . Select Delete table . title: Can I assign numerical values to answer choices?
body: Can I assign numerical values to answer choices? Can I assign numerical values to answer choices? Can I assign numerical values to answer choices? There are a few ways you can assign numerical values to answer choices to help you analyze results: Display basic statistics so each answer choice is assigned a numeric value. Using these values, we'll calculate the minimum, maximum, mean, median, and standard deviation for the question. Assign numerical values to answer choices with Rating or Ranking question types. This allows us to calculate a weighted average or ranking average for you. Convert answer choices into numerical values for Multiple Choice questions when exporting your survey results in XLS format. title: Accepting Payments with Stripe
body: Accepting Payments with Stripe Connecting to Stripe Creating Your Form Form Responses & Payment Transactions Making a Payment Accepting Payments with Stripe Accepting Payments with Stripe Connecting to Stripe Creating Your Form Form Responses & Payment Transactions Making a Payment PAID FEATURE: Accepting payments via Stripe is only available on some paid plans—see what's on your plan . If you're on an Enterprise team with data stored in our Canadian Data Center, this feature isn't available. You can see if this applies to you by checking your Account Details . Add a payment page to the end of your form or survey and accept payments through Stripe . You can either assign prices to a single question, or charge a fixed price for your entire form. Connecting to Stripe Stripe is a third-party payment processor that lets you securely accept and manage payments online. You'll need to connect a Stripe account to accept payments in SurveyMonkey. Only the form owner can connect their stripe account. You can't connect a Stripe account to forms that are shared with you. To connect to Stripe: Go to My Account in SurveyMonkey. In the Linked Accounts section, find Stripe. Sign in to an existing Stripe account, or create a new Stripe account . Stripe is free and easy to set up, but if you have any issues connecting your account you can reach out to the friendly Stripe support team. Creating Your Form Adding a Payment Page Payment pages come at the end of your form. This means people need to complete your form in order to see it. For a quick payment experience, try to make a short and simple form. To add a payment page to your form: Go to the Design Survey section. On the left side of the page, open the Options menu. Select Payment . Select Stripe . Assigning Prices You can set a fixed price so all respondents are charged the same amount, assign prices to a single question in your form, or let people pay within a range. Prices must be a whole number between $1 and $10,000 in most accepted currencies . Feel free to make changes to your prices as you need—changes that you make to your form go live as soon as you edit your form design. Charging a Fixed Price Use this option if you want everyone who completes your form to pay the same amount. This is great if you're selling tickets to an event or selling a single product. To charge a fixed price: Add a payment page to your form. Select Charge a Fixed Price . Enter a Description to confirm what people are buying. Enter a Price and choose a Currency . Click Save . Use this option if you want everyone who completes your form to pay the same amount. This is great if you're selling tickets to an event or selling a single product. To charge a fixed price: Add a payment page to your form. Select Charge a Fixed Price . Enter a Description to confirm what people are buying. Enter a Price and choose a Currency . Click Save . Assigning Different Prices Use this option to let people decide between multiple items or prices. To assign different prices: Add a payment page to your form. Select Assign prices to an existing question . Choose an existing question from your form in the dropdown menu. You can assign prices to Multiple Choice, Dropdown, and Image Choice questions. Select a Currency and assign a Price to each answer option. Click Save . Use this option to let people decide between multiple items or prices. To assign different prices: Add a payment page to your form. Select Assign prices to an existing question . Choose an existing question from your form in the dropdown menu. You can assign prices to Multiple Choice, Dropdown, and Image Choice questions. Select a Currency and assign a Price to each answer option. Click Save . Using a Sliding Scale Use this option to set a minimum and maximum amount so people can pay what they want. To use a sliding scale: Add a payment page to your form. Choose an existing question from your form in the dropdown menu. You can set a sliding scale on a Text Box or Slider question, or set a minimum and maximum amount on a Multiple Choice question if you add an "Other" option and display it as an answer choice. Select a currency and assign a minimum and maximum payment amount. Click Save . Use this option to set a minimum and maximum amount so people can pay what they want. To use a sliding scale: Add a payment page to your form. Choose an existing question from your form in the dropdown menu. You can set a sliding scale on a Text Box or Slider question, or set a minimum and maximum amount on a Multiple Choice question if you add an "Other" option and display it as an answer choice. Select a currency and assign a minimum and maximum payment amount. Click Save . TIP! If you have a limited amount of tickets or items that you want to accept payment for, you can add a quota to your form. Once the quota has been met, respondetns won't see the payment page. Currency Options People taking your form have plenty of options to pay—Stripe supports over 135 currencies and accepts major credit cards. Form Responses & Payment Transactions Collecting Responses After you design your form, create a collector to send it out and start accepting payments. Web Links are the easiest way to get started, and Email Invitations are great if you have an email list to send your form to. You can send a form with a payment page using any collector type —except for Audience, Mobile SDK, Facebook Messenger and Kiosk Survey. After a respondent submits a payment, they won't be able to return to the form even when Response Editing is on. Viewing Transactions When someone submits a payment through your form, Stripe collects all of the details from the payment page, which means SurveyMonkey never saves or stores any credit card numbers. You can go to the Analyze Results section of your form to see a limited record of your transactions. You'll find them at the very bottom of your form results. The transaction record shows: Stripe's transaction ID number The amount paid The date and time The item description The respondent's first and last name The transaction status This is only a snapshot of each payment taken at the time the form is completed. To view real-time purchase totals, make refunds, and transfer funds to your bank account, log in to Stripe . Turning Off Payments You can stop accepting payments at any time by deleting the payment page from your form or by closing your form . Deleting a payment page from your form will also delete any transaction records from previous payments in the Analyze Results section. You'll always be able to see your complete transaction record in your Stripe account. If you disconnect your Stripe account in My Account , you won't be able to collect any additional payments from forms with a payment page. Making a Payment When someone submits a payment through your form, they'll receive an email from Stripe confirming their transaction. Transactions appear on their credit or debit card statements with the name of your form. SurveyMonkey's platform allows you to integrate with third-party payment processors. Some of these payment processors may require Strong Customer Authentication (SCA) under the EU Payment Services Directive (PSD2) . People in Europe who submit payment through your form may need to provide additional authentication. It's not possible to disable this authentication when payment processors require it. If someone runs into issues making payment, they can reach out to Stripe or their card issuer for help. title: Changing the Question Size and Layout
body: Changing the Question Size and Layout Change the Layout of Answer Choices (Multiple Choice or Checkboxes) Unsupported Settings Changing the Question Size and Layout Changing the Question Size and Layout Change the Layout of Answer Choices (Multiple Choice or Checkboxes) Unsupported Settings You can change the position or layout of questions on a page to make questions appear side by side or on different parts of the page. To adjust the question layout: Click the Design Survey tab. Click a question to edit it. Click the options tab. Click Adjust Question Layout . Configure the options as needed. Click Save . The question layout options vary depending on the question type . Start Question on a New Row (Default): The question appears directly below the previous question. Place Question Next to the Previous Question: The question appears side by side with the previous question. Question Layout on Mobile Devices. For the best respondent experience, we automatically override certain layout options when you take a survey on a tablet or mobile device. For example, if you arrange questions side by side, they'll shift to one question per row on smaller screens. Change the Layout of Answer Choices (Multiple Choice or Checkboxes) You can change how the answer choices for a Multiple Choice or Checkboxes question are arranged. To change the answer choice layout: Click the Design Survey tab. Click a Multiple Choice or Checkboxes question to edit it. Click the Options tab. Select Change the Layout for How Choices are Displayed . Select the preferred layout option: 1 Column 2 Columns 3 Columns Horizontal 1 Column 2 Columns 3 Columns Horizontal Click Save . Unsupported Settings When the One Question at a Time setting is turned on you can't adjust the question layout, except on Multiple Choice and Checkbox questions. title: Survey Tooltips
body: Survey Tooltips Survey Tooltips Survey Tooltips Tooltips give survey takers more information about a specific word or phrase in your survey. For example, you can use a tooltip to define a word in your survey people may not be familiar with or give extra context about how to answer a survey question. Adding a Tooltip You can add one tooltip per survey question or additional survey text block. It’s not possible to add a tooltip to answer text, the survey title, or intro paragraphs. To add a tooltip: Go to the Design Survey section of your survey. Click a question or additional text field. Highlight the text you want to add a tooltip to. Click the Tooltip icon in the formatting toolbar. Enter your tooltip text. Click OK . Deleting a Tooltip To delete a tooltip: Go to the Design Survey section of your survey. Click the question or additional text. Highlight the text with the tooltip. Click the Tooltip icon in the formatting toolbar. Click the Delete icon. What Survey Takers See Words with tooltips added are underlined. Survey takers can hover over the word to read the tooltip. title: Can I limit the number of answer choices a respondent can select?
body: Can I limit the number of answer choices a respondent can select? Can I limit the number of answer choices a respondent can select? Can I limit the number of answer choices a respondent can select? On question types that allow multiple answer choices, rows, or textboxes, you can set a range or a limit on how many the respondent must answer. To do this, you need to make the question required to answer . Be sure to edit the default error message to explain how many answer choices respondents can or must select. title: Copying or Moving Questions
body: Copying or Moving Questions Move a Question Copy a Question Copying or Moving Questions Copying or Moving Questions Move a Question Copy a Question You can copy or move questions in the Design Survey section. Move a Question You can move a question to another position in the survey. All options configured under the Edit, Options, and Logic tabs will remain applied. If the question has logic applied, make sure to test the logic paths thoroughly before sending your survey to respondents. To move a question to another position in the survey, you can click and drag the question to the desired position in the survey and drop it into place. Or you can: Hover over the question you want to move and click Move . Select the page and position to which you want to move the question. Click Move Question . Copy a Question Copying a question will create a duplicate version of the question in the same survey. All options configured under the Edit and Options tab will carry over to the copied version. Question skip logic from the original question will not carry over to the copied version. To copy a survey question: Hover over the question you want to copy and click Copy . Select the page and position where you want the copy of the question to go. Click Copy Question . title: Adding or Editing a Logo to Your Survey Design
body: Adding or Editing a Logo to Your Survey Design Adding or Editing a Logo to Your Survey Design Adding or Editing a Logo to Your Survey Design Add Logo Add your logo to customize your survey. When you add a logo, it will appear at the top of every page in the survey. You should only add a logo that you have the right to use. When you've added a logo to your survey and send it via email invitation, we automatically add the logo to your email message . Upload Requirements Format: JPG, PNG, or GIF File Size: 1MB or less Adding a Logo To add a logo: Click the Design Survey tab. At the top of the survey, click + Logo . Upload a logo from your computer. Adjust the logo settings: Logo Size - Choose to display your logo at its Actual Size , Small (100px) , Medium (200px) , Large (300px) . Position - Choose to display your logo aligned Left , Center , or Right . Or, if using a classic theme, choose between Above Title , Below Title , or Left of Title . Descriptive Text (Alt Text): Turn this on to add text that makes your image accessible for people using a screen reader, but won't be visible on the survey page. This option isn't available if you're using a classic theme. Logo Size - Choose to display your logo at its Actual Size , Small (100px) , Medium (200px) , Large (300px) . Position - Choose to display your logo aligned Left , Center , or Right . Or, if using a classic theme, choose between Above Title , Below Title , or Left of Title . Descriptive Text (Alt Text): Turn this on to add text that makes your image accessible for people using a screen reader, but won't be visible on the survey page. This option isn't available if you're using a classic theme. Your changes will save automatically. Changing or Editing a Logo You can change your survey's logo at any time, or edit the size and position of the existing logo. To change or edit a logo: Click the Design Survey tab. Click Style . Click Your Logo . To change the logo, hover over your existing logo and click p Change logo . To edit the existing logo's size or position, use the Logo Size and Position fields. To change the logo, hover over your existing logo and click p Change logo . To edit the existing logo's size or position, use the Logo Size and Position fields. Deleting a Logo To remove a logo from a survey: Click the Design Survey tab. Click Style . Click Your Logo . Hover over your existing logo and click # Remove logo .
