title: Can I create a question that sums the numbers or shows a running total?
body: Can I create a question that sums the numbers or shows a running total? Percentages Running Total Can I create a question that sums the numbers or shows a running total? Can I create a question that sums the numbers or shows a running total? Percentages Running Total You can validate the Multiple Textboxes question type to only allow numerical data, and require all fields to add up to a fixed sum. This field will only accept positive, whole numbers. To validate a Multiple Textboxes question to require a fixed numerical sum: Click the Design Survey tab. Click a Multiple Textboxes question to edit it. Or, add a new Multiple Textboxes question type from the Build section of the left sidebar. Under the Textboxes fields, select Only Allow Numerical Data . Select Require a Fixed Sum . In the Sum of all Answers = field, enter the number that all answers must add up to. Customize the error message to be clear about the requirements of the question. Click Save . TIP! If you require a fixed sum, be sure to mention the required total in the question text itself to ensure that respondents know how to properly answer the question the first time. Percentages A common use of this feature is to ask respondents to provide answers in percentages that add up to 100%. However, the numerical data field will not accept percentage signs. We suggest adding question text instructing respondents to omit the percent sign (%) from their responses. Running Total Respondents will not see a running total update dynamically as they enter their answers, but if they enter a set of numbers that do not add up to the required fixed sum, they will receive an error message when they try to move to the next page of the survey, indicating that the choices must add up to a specific number. title: Adding Answer Choices in Bulk
body: Adding Answer Choices in Bulk What Happens to Existing Answer Choices Adding Answer Choices in Bulk Adding Answer Choices in Bulk What Happens to Existing Answer Choices If you need to add a large number of answer choices to a single question, you can copy and paste a list all at once instead of adding each choice one by one. This option is available on every question type except the Single Textbox, Comment Box, Contact Information, and Star Rating question. For Matrix of Dropdown Menus or Matrix/Rating Scale questions, you can only copy and paste row choices—not column choices. To copy and paste answer choices: Click the Design Survey tab. Click a question to edit it, or add a new question. In Edit mode, click + Bulk Answers , located at the top right of the answer choice fields. Enter each choice on a separate line. Click Save . What Happens to Existing Answer Choices In most cases, existing answer choices will be included in the textbox, and any changes you make will overwrite the existing answer choices when you click Save . However, if the question meets any of the following conditions, the existing answer choices don't appear in the Add Answers in Bulk textbox. Any new answer choices you enter will be appended after the existing answer choices: The question has already collected responses The existing answer choices have any rich text or HTML formatting The question has Question Skip Logic applied The question has a Quota applied If you wish to remove any of the original answer choices, click ➖ to the right of the answer choice you wish to delete. TIP! Copy & Paste Several Questions at a Time If you've already written a lot of questions for your survey, save time by copying & pasting the questions and answers in bulk. Learn more: Copying & Pasting Questions Related Articles Company SurveyMonkey About Us Jobs Blog Help SurveyMonkey Help GetFeedback Help Market Research Help SurveyMonkey Audience Help SurveyMonkey Contribute Help Wufoo Help Apply Help Support Site Status Unsubscribe Contact Us Email Opt-In Policies Legal Center Privacy Policy Cookies Notice California Privacy Notice

title: Navigation Buttons
body: Navigation Buttons Types of Navigation Buttons Customizing Buttons Showing or Hiding Buttons Browser Navigation Buttons Translations Legacy Navigation Buttons Navigation Buttons Navigation Buttons Types of Navigation Buttons Customizing Buttons Showing or Hiding Buttons Browser Navigation Buttons Translations Legacy Navigation Buttons People taking your survey can use these buttons to navigate through a survey and record responses input on a page. Types of Navigation Buttons Why are there two Done buttons? If you have a Custom Thank You turned on in the collector options, the page will have an additional Done button on it. There is no way to make these two buttons have different text. Customizing Buttons You can edit the button colors and text. It's not possible to change the button font. Button Text To edit the text on navigation buttons: Click the Design Survey tab. Click the navigation button you want to edit. Enter the preferred text. Click Save . Button Colors To edit the navigation button colors: Click the Design Survey tab. In the left sidebar, click Style . Click Colors . For buttons, edit Accents and Accent Text . If you're using a classic theme , you need to edit the Survey Title and Survey Title Background colors. You can't edit the button color for a couple of classic themes. Showing or Hiding Buttons Previous Button You can turn on or off Response Editing to allow or prevent respondents from editing their responses on previous pages. This setting controls whether or not the Previous button is available at the bottom of each page in your survey. To hide the Previous button, turn off Response Editing—don't allow respondents to go back and change existing responses. If you choose to hide the Previous button, you'll still see it when previewing your survey design . Collector options aren't active when using a preview link. To show the Previous button, turn on Response Editing—allow respondents to go back to previous pages in the survey and update existing responses. TIP! If you buy survey responses using SurveyMonkey Audience , we remove the Previous button from the survey, so it's not possible for respondents to go back to previous pages to edit their responses . Browser Navigation Buttons Respondents should not use browser navigation buttons to move through the survey. If a respondent clicks their web browser's Back button instead of the survey's Previous button, they can't change or save their responses on the previous page. Respondents may see a cached version of the previous page that won't accept new responses, or they may be prompted with a form resubmission error. Translations If you change the survey language , the default navigation button text will automatically change to match that language. Legacy Navigation Buttons The Exit link option is no longer available. This change shouldn’t impact your surveys, data, or the respondent’s experience when exiting a survey page. Respondents can exit surveys anytime by closing their browser tab or window. No matter how someone exits a survey page, the survey behavior is the same. Survey responses entered on the current survey page aren’t saved when the survey is exited. However, responses on previous pages remain saved. title: Daily Summary Notifications
body: Daily Summary Notifications What Emails You Get Managing Your Notifications Sharing Notifications with Others Viewing Shared Notifications Daily Summary Notifications Daily Summary Notifications What Emails You Get Managing Your Notifications Sharing Notifications with Others Viewing Shared Notifications The daily summary is an email notification sent once a day to let you know how many survey responses you got the day before. For each survey with daily summary notifications turned on, you get a one-time email confirming your first response, and then a daily email summarizing how many new responses you received. TIP! Check out the Notification Center to find your daily summary and first response messages from the last 30 days. What Emails You Get First Response Email When your survey receives its first response, you get a one-time email letting you know. You should receive this email within 15 minutes of your first response. Daily Summary Email After the first response email, you get one daily summary email on weekday mornings. It highlights all open surveys in your account and surveys shared with you. For each open survey that's collected new responses, you'll see the number of new responses since the last notification and how long the survey has been open. You only receive a daily summary if new responses have been recorded. We include responses that were collected between 12:00am and 11:59pm the previous day. Emails are sent to the account email address, in the language and time zone selected on the My Account page. TIP! Learn about other ways to get notified about survey responses. Managing Your Notifications You can turn daily summary notifications on or off for individual surveys in your account. You can also manage account-wide preferences for daily summary notifications for surveys you own. Individual Surveys To manage notifications for an individual survey: Go to the survey's Summary tab. Find Notifications in the upper-right corner. Click Edit . Under Daily summary notifications , toggle on or off. Account-Wide Preferences To manage your notifications for all existing or future surveys you own: Click your username in the upper-right corner of your account. Choose My Account . Scroll to General Preferences . Next to Response Alerts , click Edit . Change your preferences. Click Change Response Alerts . TIP! If you turned on notifications but you're not getting emails, try these troubleshooting tips . You'll still see them as messages in the Notification Center . Sharing Notifications with Others You can share daily summary notifications with anyone who has a SurveyMonkey account. If you’re on a team, you can share them with people in or outside your team—as long as you're the survey owner. To share daily summary notifications with others: Go to the survey's Summary tab. Find Notifications in the upper-right corner. Click Edit . Click Add Recipients . Enter the email addresses of the people you want to share daily summary notifications with. If you're in a team , you can also select team members from the list. Click Add . When you share daily summary notifications with someone who's not in your team , they’ll get an email notifying them that you want to share notifications. Survey Permissions When you share daily summary notifications with someone, the survey will be shared with them automatically with the following access levels: View Only permissions for survey design No access to collect responses View Only permissions for analyze results If you're part of a team, you can edit sharing permissions on surveys you own. The person you shared the survey with must have at least view only access to Analyze Results in order to receive daily summary notifications for that survey. Removing someone from shared notifications Removing someone from shared notifications also removes the shared survey from their account. To remove someone from receiving your shared daily summary notifications: Go to the survey's Summary tab. Find Notifications in the upper-right corner. Click Edit . Click Add Recipients . Click Manage Recipients . Click # next to the people you want to remove. Click Done . People you shared daily summary notifications with can also turn them off in their own account. Removing someone from shared notifications also removes the shared survey from their account. To remove someone from receiving your shared daily summary notifications: Go to the survey's Summary tab. Find Notifications in the upper-right corner. Click Edit . Click Add Recipients . Click Manage Recipients . Click # next to the people you want to remove. Click Done . People you shared daily summary notifications with can also turn them off in their own account. Viewing Shared Notifications When someone shares daily summary notifications with you, you'll get an email letting you know. Your account email address needs to match the one the notification was sent to. To view the responses and continue to get notifications, you must log in or sign up for a SurveyMonkey account and click View survey in the first notification email. This will put a View Only shared survey in your account so you can see the responses. You won’t start getting daily summary emails until you confirm by clicking View survey in the first email while you’re logged in. title: Restricting Survey Access by Password or IP Address
body: Restricting Survey Access by Password or IP Address Password Protection IP Restrictions Restricting Access to Shared Surveys Restricting Survey Access by Password or IP Address Restricting Survey Access by Password or IP Address Password Protection IP Restrictions Restricting Access to Shared Surveys You can restrict access to your survey from the collector options . If you turn on Password Protection, respondents need to enter a password in order to take the survey. If you turn on IP Restrictions, you can allow or block a list of IP addresses. TIP! Collectors are ways to send your survey. Each collector type works a little differently, so they all have different sets of options to choose from when you set them up. If you don't see this particular option in the collector type you're using, review the info on this page, and be sure to check out the help article about that collector type . Password Protection If you turn on Password Protection, when respondents click the survey link, they'll be prompted to enter a password in order to access the survey. There isn't a way to create a unique password for each respondent. To add a password to your survey: Go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Click the name of the collector and access the collector options . You may need to click Show advanced options . Turn on Password Protection . Enter the desired password. Customize the password required message and the error message that appears when respondents enter an incorrect password. The font formatting used for your survey password prompt can be controlled by setting the Answer choice font setting . Password Limitations Password Protection isn't available when In-Response Email Capture is turned on. To enable Password Protection, turn off In-Email Response Capture in your collector settings. IP Restrictions To restrict access to your survey based on the IP addresses of your respondents: Go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Click the name of the collector and access the collector options . You may need to click Show advanced options . Turn on IP Restrictions . Choose either to allow only a specific list of IP address to take your survey or to block a specific list of IP addresses from taking your survey. Enter the IP addresses. You can enter up to 4,096 characters. Click Edit "survey closed" message . If someone's IP address is blocked, they'll see this closed message . Using Wildcards in IP Addresses IP addresses are represented in dot-decimal notation—four different numbers, each ranging from 0 to 255, separated by decimal points. Each number represents 8 bits (an octet) of the IP address. Here's an example with each of the four octets shown in a different color: 172.16.254.1 You can use an asterisk (*) as a wildcard to allow or block a particular range of IP addresses by octet. Here are some examples: TIP! If you want only a particular group of people to access your survey and you don't know all the IP addresses you need to allow or block, we recommend adding a password to your survey instead. Restricting Access to Shared Surveys If you're in a team , you can share a survey with others and set permissions to limit what they can do with the survey. For example, you can give someone View Only access to the survey design, and no access to analyze results. title: Setting a Cutoff Date & Time
body: Setting a Cutoff Date & Time Response Limits Setting a Cutoff Date & Time Setting a Cutoff Date & Time Response Limits You can edit the collector options to automatically close a collector (stop collecting responses) at a certain date and time. If you have multiple collectors, you need to set a Cutoff Date and Time for each one separately. To set a Cutoff Date and Time: Go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Click the name of the collector and access the collector options . You may need to click Show advanced options . Turn on Cutoff Date and Time . Choose a date and time in the future. Click Edit "survey closed" message . Once the date and time has passed, anyone who tries to access the survey will see this closed message . TIP! Collectors are ways to send your survey. Each collector type works a little differently, so they all have different sets of options to choose from when you set them up. If you don't see this particular option in the collector type you're using, review the info on this page, and be sure to check out the help article about that collector type . Response Limits If you're using both Response Limits and a Cutoff Date and Time, whichever comes first will close the collector. title: Storing and Organizing Your SurveyMonkey Contacts
body: Storing and Organizing Your SurveyMonkey Contacts Managing Your Contacts Opted Out or Bounced Team Collaboration Storing and Organizing Your SurveyMonkey Contacts Storing and Organizing Your SurveyMonkey Contacts Managing Your Contacts Opted Out or Bounced Team Collaboration You can store and organize your Contacts within SurveyMonkey and use the Email Invitation and Text Message collectors to send surveys to groups of your contacts. SurveyMonkey doesn’t sell or use your contact’s email addresses for any reason other than to send your survey, as explained in our Privacy Notice . Managing Your Contacts To access your Contacts , log in and click your username in the top-right corner of your account. Once you have more than 500,000 contacts, you aren't able to sort by email, name, or other field. Opted Out or Bounced If you add or import an email address that bounced or opted out , the contact is automatically added to an Opted Out or Bounced group. These contacts also appear in colored font in the contact list. Team Collaboration Contacts are unique to your account. When sharing surveys , you can only send email invitations to email addresses stored in your Contacts—you can't access contacts belonging to other members of your team . title: Embedding Your Survey or Form on a Website
body: Embedding Your Survey or Form on a Website Overview Creating a Website Collector Style and Behavior Settings Collector Options Embed Tips Embedding Your Survey or Form on a Website Embedding Your Survey or Form on a Website Overview Creating a Website Collector Style and Behavior Settings Collector Options Embed Tips Overview Use a website collector to embed a survey or a button that opens a survey on your website, or popup a survey or invitation. To add one, you only need a basic understanding of HTML and access to your website’s source code. We’ll give you an embed code you can copy and paste. You can embed a survey on multiple pages of your site, if you want. Website Collector Types Modal Windows Popup Invitations and Popup Surveys show in modal windows that float above your webpage. Modal windows don't require your site visitors to load a new page, and they aren't affected by popup blockers. Cookies We use cookies to stop popups or embedded surveys from reshowing if someone already answered, declined, or closed the survey. If someone clears their cookies, visits your site using a browser that blocks or disables cookies, or the website is opened in a new browser session, the collector can’t remember whether they’ve taken the survey or declined it, so the popup may appear again allowing additional responses. Closing Your Survey When you close your survey , it continues to display on your website, unless you remove the embed code from your site. Creating a Website Collector To create a Website collector: Go to the Collect Response section of your survey. Choose Embed on a site . If you already have a collector for your survey, select Website collector . Choose a website collector type . Scroll down to edit the the style and behavior settings, and adjust the collector options. View the preview to know what your survey will look like on your website. Click Copy Code to copy and paste the embed code onto a page in your site. When embedding a survey or button , paste the script into your HTML wherever you want the survey to appear on your page. When showing a Popup invitation or Popup survey , paste the script into your HTML immediately before your closing </body> tag. When embedding a survey or button , paste the script into your HTML wherever you want the survey to appear on your page. When showing a Popup invitation or Popup survey , paste the script into your HTML immediately before your closing </body> tag. The code only needs to be added once. You don’t need to update the Embed code if you make changes to your survey or collector—your updates will display as soon as you refresh the page. Style and Behavior Settings The live survey preview updates as you customize your style and behavior settings for your survey. Settings vary by website type . Collector Options Update the collector options , which are called Settings on the Embedded button type, to customize the survey experience. Some collector options are limited on certain website collector types: Embedded surveys don't have a Survey end page option. Instant results aren't available on any website collector type. The Custom thank you includes SurveyMonkey branding at the end of an Embedded survey, even if you chose to Hide SurveyMonkey Branding . Embed Tips Please don’t edit the Embed code! The Embed code contains several lines of JavaScript and a unique ID that's tied to both your collector and your survey. You can paste the embed code on a single or multiple pages by pasting the embed code before the </body> tag. If you want all pages of your site to display the survey, button, or invitation, paste the embed code before the </header> tag. If you use templates to dynamically generate pages for your site (if you’re using Ruby, Python, PHP, ASP, or a similar technology), you can paste the Embed code snippet into its own file, then include it in your page layout. If you’re using wordpress.org, you need to be an administrator to add the code, or a super admin for multi-site wordpress.org networks. Website collectors aren’t compatible with wordpress.com. title: Survey Link Doesn’t Work
body: Survey Link Doesn’t Work Link Goes Directly to a Thank You Page Link is Broken or Opens the SurveyMonkey Homepage Closed Survey Survey Link Doesn’t Work Survey Link Doesn’t Work Link Goes Directly to a Thank You Page Link is Broken or Opens the SurveyMonkey Homepage Closed Survey Link Goes Directly to a Thank You Page If the link goes directly to a thank you page or to a message saying you've already taken the survey, then the survey is set to allow only one response per browser. Please contact the survey creator who can change the settings to turn on Multiple Responses . If you opened a survey to find responses already filled in, this is because the survey has Response Editing turned on AND Multiple Responses turned off. Please contact the survey creator who can turn off Response Editing . Link is Broken or Opens the SurveyMonkey Homepage If you're trying to access a survey and are taken to the SurveyMonkey homepage instead, this means the link you used was incorrect. Links are character and case sensitive, so an extra space or a lower-case letter in place of an upper-case letter could break the link. Rather than clicking on the hyperlink to access the survey, try copying and pasting the URL into your browser's address bar. If that doesn't work, please contact the survey creator who can give you the correct link. Closed Survey If a survey is closed, you will need to contact the survey creator to re-open the survey for you. Are you the survey creator? Please read this troubleshooting article for tips on what to do if respondents can't complete your survey . title: Instant Notifications
body: Instant Notifications What Emails You Get Setting Up Instant Notifications Sharing Instant Notifications with Others Instant Notifications Instant Notifications What Emails You Get Setting Up Instant Notifications Sharing Instant Notifications with Others ENTERPRISE FEATURE: If you're interested, contact sales . If you already have an Enterprise account, contact your Customer Success Manager. Instant notifications let you quickly see new survey responses by sending you an email and message in the Notification Center each time a complete response is submitted. Only survey owners can turn on instant notifications for their survey, but they can share those notifications with others . What Emails You Get You’ll get an email each time a new complete response to your survey is submitted, which will also show as a message in the Notification Center . The email has a link to view the individual response so you can see it without logging in to a SurveyMonkey account. The link stays active for 90 days after the notification is sent. To receive notifications for multiple surveys, you'll need to turn on instant notifications for each one. Each person receiving notifications can get a maximum of 20 instant notifications a day, across all surveys. TIP! Learn about other ways to get notified about survey responses. Setting Up Instant Notifications Instant notifications are set up for each individual survey by the survey owner. You can only turn on instant notifications for surveys you own, not on surveys that are shared with you. To turn on instant notifications for a survey you own: Go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Click Manage Notifications . Turn on instant notifications for yourself. TIP! If you turned on notifications but you're not getting emails, try these troubleshooting tips . You'll still see them as messages in the Notification Center . Sharing Instant Notifications with Others You can share instant notifications with anyone—people in or outside of your team as long as you’re the survey owner. To share instant notifications with others: Go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Click Manage Notifications . Scroll to instant notifications and click Add . Enter the email addresses of the people you want to share instant notifications with. If you're in a team , you can also select team members from the list. Click Share . When you share instant notifications with someone, they’ll get an email to let them know. They'll then start to receive emails each time a complete response is submitted, with a link to view the individual response so they can see it without logging in to a SurveyMonkey account. TIP! Track your Instant Notifications in the Notification Center . Stop Sharing Instant Notifications with Someone To remove someone from receiving instant notifications for a survey: Go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Click Manage Notifications . Scroll to instant notifications and click Recipients . Click the Trash can icon next to the people you want to remove. Click Done . To remove someone from receiving instant notifications for a survey: Go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Click Manage Notifications . Scroll to instant notifications and click Recipients . Click the Trash can icon next to the people you want to remove. Click Done . Opting Out To stop receiving instant notifications, reach out to the survey owner and they can take you off the list. To find out who the survey owner is, look for the name listed in the instant notification email. When you opt out of instant notifications, you’ll no longer receive these messages in the Notification Center . title: Editing Survey Responses
body: Editing Survey Responses Turning On Response Editing Response Editing Options How are responses saved? Hiding the Previous Button Editing Responses in Your Results Editing Survey Responses Editing Survey Responses Turning On Response Editing Response Editing Options How are responses saved? Hiding the Previous Button Editing Responses in Your Results You can allow respondents to edit their responses later. You can also edit a respondent's response in your results. Turning On Response Editing To allow respondents to edit or change their survey responses: Go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Click the name of your collector. From the collector options , click Response Editing . Choose one of the available Response Editing options for your collector type. Accepting Payments limitation Respondents won't be able to edit their responses after they submit a payment , even when response editing is on. Response Editing Options You can allow people who take your survey to edit their responses either while completing the survey or after they submit the survey, or you can prevent respondents from editing their responses after they submit them. The available Response Editing options depend on the collector type you're using. Web Link or Website Collectors The Multiple Responses setting affects your Response Editing options when using a Web Link collector or Website collector. Multiple Responses is Off If you allow one response per computer , you can allow editing even after the survey is submitted. In order for this setting to work properly, the respondent must use the same device and web browser they used to start the survey on because a cookie is stored in the respondent's browser that remembers their survey responses. Option Description On, until survey is completed or exited Respondents can change their answers on any survey page until they complete the survey or exit the survey. Respondents can return to the survey to pick up where they left off and/or edit previous responses until they click the Done button or until you close the collector . On, always Respondents can change their answers on any survey page even after they complete the survey. Respondents can return to the survey to pick up where they left off and/or edit previous responses until you close the collector . Off Respondents can’t change their answers once they leave a survey page.After respondents submit a survey page by clicking Next or Done, the Previous button is hidden. Respondents can continue to access the survey to pick up where they left off until they click the Done button or until you close the collector . Multiple Responses is On If you allow multiple responses per computer , you can allow editing during the survey, but not after the survey is submitted or exited. In order for this setting to work properly, no cookie is stored in the respondent’s browser to remember their survey responses. If the survey is accessed from the same browser multiple times, the collector registers each time as a new respondent. Option Description On, until survey is completed or exited Respondents can change their answers on any survey page until they complete or exit the survey. If respondents exit the survey and go back to it, it records a new response—it doesn't update their existing response. Off Respondents can’t change their answers once they leave a survey page.After respondents submit a survey page by clicking Next or Done, the Previous button is hidden. Respondents can continue to access the survey to pick up where they left off until they click the Done button or until you close the collector . The Multiple Responses setting affects your Response Editing options when using a Web Link collector or Website collector. Multiple Responses is Off If you allow one response per computer , you can allow editing even after the survey is submitted. In order for this setting to work properly, the respondent must use the same device and web browser they used to start the survey on because a cookie is stored in the respondent's browser that remembers their survey responses. Multiple Responses is On If you allow multiple responses per computer , you can allow editing during the survey, but not after the survey is submitted or exited. In order for this setting to work properly, no cookie is stored in the respondent’s browser to remember their survey responses. If the survey is accessed from the same browser multiple times, the collector registers each time as a new respondent. Email Invitation Collector If you're using an Email Invitation Collector, the Multiple Responses setting doesn't affect your Response Editing options. A respondent can edit their survey responses from any computer since their responses are tied to their email address and not a cookie in their browser. Option Description On, until survey complete Respondents can change their answers on any survey page until they complete the survey. Respondents can return to the survey to pick up where they left off and/or edit previous responses until they click the Done button or until you close the collector . On, always Respondents can change their answers on any survey page even after they complete the survey. Respondents can return to the survey to pick up where they left off and/or edit previous responses until you close the collector . Off Respondents can’t change their answers once they leave a survey page.After respondents submit a survey page by clicking Next or Done, the Previous button is hidden. Respondents can continue to access the survey to pick up where they left off until they click the Done button or until you close the collector . If you're using an Email Invitation Collector, the Multiple Responses setting doesn't affect your Response Editing options. A respondent can edit their survey responses from any computer since their responses are tied to their email address and not a cookie in their browser. Target Audience Collector If you buy survey responses using SurveyMonkey Audience , your survey is sent through the Target Audience Collector. We remove the Previous button from surveys sent when they're sent through Audience, so it's not possible for respondents to go back to previous pages to edit their responses. Additionally, if a respondent exits the survey, they can't access it again or pick up where they left off. If you buy survey responses using SurveyMonkey Audience , your survey is sent through the Target Audience Collector. We remove the Previous button from surveys sent when they're sent through Audience, so it's not possible for respondents to go back to previous pages to edit their responses. Additionally, if a respondent exits the survey, they can't access it again or pick up where they left off. How are responses saved? Responses are saved and submitted when a respondent clicks the Next or Done button on each page of the survey, or when they answer the first question embedded in an email invitation if In-email Response Capture is turned on and the question doesn’t have an Other Textbox or Comment field . Responses don’t automatically save as each question is answered—they are saved and submitted page by page as respondents progress through the survey. TIP! If the survey is a single page, all responses are submitted at once when a respondent clicks the Done button. If the respondent doesn’t click the Done button, they will need to take the survey again to submit their responses. Hiding the Previous Button If you choose to turn Response Editing off, respondents can still edit answers when they're on a given survey page, but not on previous pages—the Previous button is hidden from respondents when they're taking your survey. However, when previewing your survey design , you'll still be able to use the Previous button to go back and edit responses because collector options aren't active when using a preview link. TIP! If you don't allow response editing, edit the survey introduction to explain to respondents that they won't be able to go back to edit previous pages once they have submitted them. Editing Responses in Your Results Edit a survey response from the Individual Responses page in your survey results. You can edit responses from both the Table and Single view. To edit a response in Table view: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Click the Individual Responses tab. Find the response you want to edit. You can select a column header to sort responses by that column. Click the Edit button on the right side of the table. The survey will open in a new browser window or tab, based on your settings. Go through each page, editing the answers as needed. Click the Done button on the survey to save the response. To edit a response in Single view: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Click the Individual Responses tab. Use the left and right arrows to find the response you want to edit. Click the Edit button in the upper-right corner of the grey box containing the respondent's metadata. The survey will open in a new browser window or tab, based on your settings. Go through each page, editing the answers as needed Click the Done button on the survey to save the response. title: Thumbnail Image & Text
body: Thumbnail Image & Text Customizing Your Thumbnail Image & Text Thumbnail Image & Text Thumbnail Image & Text Customizing Your Thumbnail Image & Text Thumbnail Image and Text The Thumbnail Image & Text collector option lets you edit the link metadata that shows when you paste your survey link in social media, messaging apps, or texts. Metadata includes your survey title, description, and image. Customizing Your Thumbnail Image & Text To edit your survey link’s thumbnail image and text: Go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Create a Web Link collector. From the collector options, click Thumbnail Image & Text . Click Add Image to upload an image from your computer. Edit the Title . Titles can have up to 60 characters. Edit the Description . Descriptions can have up 300 characters. Click Save . Choose your other collector options . Copy the survey link and share your survey. This collector option may not be available on existing web link collectors—create a new web link collector to customize your Thumbnail Image & Text. Default Thumbnail Image & Text Unless you edit this setting or add a background image to your theme, or if you click Reset to Default , your link will show SurveyMonkey's default metadata. title: Kiosk Mode
body: Kiosk Mode Kiosk Mode Kiosk Mode PAID FEATURE: Kiosk mode is available on paid plans on the US, EU, and CA data centers — see what's on your plan . You can use kiosk mode on the SurveyMonkey Anywhere app to turn your device into a survey-taking station. Using Kiosk Mode Kiosk mode runs your survey in a loop—so each time someone finishes a survey, a new survey is ready for the next person to take. When a survey-taker completes a survey, they'll be prompted to Return to Start or Close Kiosk Mode . The completion of a survey is what causes it to loop, so if you have a Survey End Page , Custom Thank You , Instant Results or Quiz Results enabled, you won't be able to see them when using kiosk mode. Click Map questions and Market Research solutions surveys are not compatible with kiosk mode. To use kiosk mode: Log in to your SurveyMonkey account. Go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Create a Kiosk Survey collector. Download the SurveyMonkey Anywhere app and sign in. On the My Surveys page, tap on a survey title to open it. (optional) Enable offline mode to collect responses without an internet connection. Collect responses in the app. Responses will automatically sync with your SurveyMonkey account. To exit kiosk mode, tap the back button or ❌ in the upper-left corner of the survey. Kiosk Settings Inactivity Timer Passcode Lock In the SurveyMonkey Anywhere app, tap My Account . You can enable the following kiosk mode settings: Inactivity Timer : Set an inactivity timer to loop the survey back to the beginning if the survey remains inactive for the set amount of time. Passcode Lock : Set a passcode to prevent survey-takers from exiting the survey-taking experience. To exit the survey, you need to enter the 4-digit passcode. Kiosk Mode in the SurveyMonkey App We're going to be removing Kiosk Mode from the SurveyMonkey app soon. To use the new kiosk mode features, download the SurveyMonkey Anywhere app ! Using Kiosk Mode in the SurveyMonkey App Kiosk Mode runs your survey in a loop, returning to the beginning of the survey each time a response is collected. In order to run a survey using Kiosk Mode, the survey needs to be set to Allow Multiple Responses . To run a survey in Kiosk Mode using the SurveyMonkey app: In the SurveyMonkey app, select the survey you want respondents to take from My Surveys . Tap Send . Tap Kiosk Mode . Select whether you want to enable screen lock. With screen lock on, your SurveyMonkey password needs to be entered into the device to exit Kiosk Mode. If the survey doesn't already have Allow Multiple Responses setting turned on, allow this setting when prompted. To exit Kiosk Mode: Tap the back button or Exit in the top corner of your survey. Tap Close Kiosk Mode . If you have screen lock on, you’ll be prompted to enter your SurveyMonkey password. Kiosk Mode runs your survey in a loop, returning to the beginning of the survey each time a response is collected. In order to run a survey using Kiosk Mode, the survey needs to be set to Allow Multiple Responses . To run a survey in Kiosk Mode using the SurveyMonkey app: In the SurveyMonkey app, select the survey you want respondents to take from My Surveys . Tap Send . Tap Kiosk Mode . Select whether you want to enable screen lock. With screen lock on, your SurveyMonkey password needs to be entered into the device to exit Kiosk Mode. If the survey doesn't already have Allow Multiple Responses setting turned on, allow this setting when prompted. To exit Kiosk Mode: Tap the back button or Exit in the top corner of your survey. Tap Close Kiosk Mode . If you have screen lock on, you’ll be prompted to enter your SurveyMonkey password. title: Sending Multilingual Surveys by Email Invitation
body: Sending Multilingual Surveys by Email Invitation Sending Multilingual Surveys by Email Invitation Sending Multilingual Surveys by Email Invitation Beta feature : Sending a multilingual survey by email invitation is only available to some customers at this time. The multilingual Email Invitation Collector lets you send customized email invitations for your surveys in multiple languages, send follow-up reminder or thank you emails , monitor email analytics, and track who responded. How it Works There are a few steps to follow to send multilingual emails: When you’re designing your survey, enable the survey languages you want to survey respondents in. Set up your email invitation collector : Assign language codes to your contacts Enable the Translate message toggle Click on a language and customize that language version’s email message (repeat this for all your languages) Send language version email invitations to your contacts Assign language codes to your contacts Enable the Translate message toggle Click on a language and customize that language version’s email message (repeat this for all your languages) Send language version email invitations to your contacts At least one language must be enabled in the Design Surveys Option in order to display the Translate message option in your Email Invitation collector. Adding Languages to Your Contacts You need to assign a language code to your contacts so they can receive the right language version of your survey. The Language Codes article lets you know the code associated with the languages you’re sending your survey in. The Translate message toggle is enabled automatically if you’ve added at least one secondary language in the Design Survey section. When the toggle is on, you can add recipients to your email invitation via CSV file, Contacts, or manually. You can add your contact information in the following order: Composing Your Messages You can click between the language versions of your message to customize each language version’s Subject, Header, and Body. The Title of your survey automatically imports from your CSV or PO file that you set up in the Design Survey section. Selecting Your Collector Options When sending a multilingual email invitation, the Email Settings page looks a little different than the original Email Invitation. You’re able to set up the following collector options: Custom End Page Response editing Cutoff date and time Response limits Additional email settings aren’t available at this time. Sending or Scheduling Your Message You can choose to Send now or Schedule for later . Below these settings you’ll see a summary of your email invitation, including the language versions applied to the email and number of contacts to receive each language version. At this time, the recurring email option is not available. Managing Your Email Invitations At this time, it isn’t possible to Invite more contacts to multilingual email invitations. Set up a new email invitation collector to send additional invitations. After you send your email invitation, you can set up one-off follow-up emails to send reminder and thank you emails . It isn’t possible to schedule automated follow-up emails at this time. Analyzing Your Multilingual Survey Results Learn more about analyzing your multilingual survey results . title: Custom Variables
body: Custom Variables Video Overview Setting Up Custom Variables Example Limitations Custom Variables Custom Variables Video Overview Setting Up Custom Variables Example Limitations Custom Variables Custom Variables is a logic feature you can use with a Web Link collector to track data about people who take your survey. It passes data you put in your survey link into your survey results. Video Overview Setting Up Custom Variables Create custom variables when designing your survey, then add them to your Web Link collector before you send it out. Once you have responses, you can see your custom variables when you export. 1. Creating them in your survey design To add custom variables: Click the Design Survey tab. In the left sidebar, click the Logic icon. Click Custom Variables . Click + New custom variable . Set up the first variable: Variable Name (required) - This goes in the Web Link. Label (optional) - This shows in your survey results, to help you track what each variable is for. Variable Name (required) - This goes in the Web Link. Label (optional) - This shows in your survey results, to help you track what each variable is for. Click Save . 2. Adding them to your Web Link Now that you have custom variables in your survey, it’s time to create your survey link and add custom values to each variable. To create your Web Link and add values: Click the Collect Responses tab. Create a Web Link collector . Copy the survey link. The template for adding your custom values will already be added to the end of the link and will follow this format: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/your_survey?var1=[var1_value]&var2=[var2_value]&var3=[var3_value] Outside of SurveyMonkey (in Excel, Google Sheets, Numbers, etc.), replace the bracketed values with the values you want to pass through the URL. Custom variables are case sensitive, so make sure they match what you entered in the Design Survey section. Send each link to the people you want to take the survey. TIP! If you set the Survey End Page to redirect respondents to the website of your choice, custom variables will also pass through to the redirect URL. 3. Viewing them in your results In the Analyze Results tab, you can filter by custom variables . You can see custom variables at the end of each row in All Responses Data XLS or SPSS export types . Example Let's say you want to send out a short employee survey to three members of your Research department. Instead of asking each respondent to fill out their name, department, and title in the survey itself, you want to track this information about them through the survey link using Custom Variables. Here's how you would do this, from beginning to end: Design Survey Create 3 variables based on the respondent information you want to pass through the survey link. Variable Name: n Label: Name Variable Name: dept Label: Department Variable Name: t Label: Title Collect Responses Create a Web Link Collector. When you view the link, the template for adding your custom values will already be appended to the end of it: Outside of SurveyMonkey, create a unique link for each respondent by replacing the bracketed values with each person's Name, Department, and Title. Send each unique link to each respective respondent. https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/your_survey? n = Lizzie & dept = Research & t = Intern https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/your_survey? n = Jenna & dept = Research & t = Analyst https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/your_survey? n = Hailee & dept = Research & t = SurveyDesigner Analyze Results Download an All Responses Data XLS, or SPSS export to see the custom variables paired with each response. In the spreadsheet, the results for this one-question survey will look like this: Limitations URL Length Web Link collectors can attach up to 100 custom variables to the URL. So you don't exceed universal URL length limitations, we suggest URLs remain under 2,000 characters to maintain functionality with popular web browsers. Web Link collectors can attach up to 100 custom variables to the URL. So you don't exceed universal URL length limitations, we suggest URLs remain under 2,000 characters to maintain functionality with popular web browsers. Forbidden Characters and Variable Names You can't use the following in Variable Names, Variable Labels, or as values inserted into the survey link template: Letters with accents (for example, À, É, ï, ó, Û, ñ, or ÿ) Special characters like: - – — # ? & ; You can't use the following in Variable Names: sm mode c cid rid r s sv pID s_mod PREVIEW_MODE Fmt prizeshown Token Disqualify overquota lang javascript You can't use the following in Variable Names, Variable Labels, or as values inserted into the survey link template: Letters with accents (for example, À, É, ï, ó, Û, ñ, or ÿ) Special characters like: - – — # ? & ; You can't use the following in Variable Names: sm mode c cid rid r s sv pID s_mod PREVIEW_MODE Fmt prizeshown Token Disqualify overquota lang javascript No Way to Automatically Insert Values There is no way to automatically insert values into the survey link template within SurveyMonkey. You will need to do this manually, or run your own script to insert the values into the survey link template, outside of SurveyMonkey. If you are uncomfortable with this approach, consider using the Email Invitation Collector to track custom data about respondents. There is no way to automatically insert values into the survey link template within SurveyMonkey. You will need to do this manually, or run your own script to insert the values into the survey link template, outside of SurveyMonkey. If you are uncomfortable with this approach, consider using the Email Invitation Collector to track custom data about respondents. Collector Options Custom variables don't work with Recurrences . Turn off the Recurrence collector option to make sure your custom variables work properly. Custom variables don't work with Recurrences . Turn off the Recurrence collector option to make sure your custom variables work properly. Deletion Custom variables cannot be deleted once responses have been collected. Custom variables cannot be deleted once responses have been collected. title: Tracking Email Invitations
body: Tracking Email Invitations Opened & Clicked Through Rates Invitation Tracking Setting Invitations Chart Responses Chart Common Questions Tracking Email Invitations Tracking Email Invitations Opened & Clicked Through Rates Invitation Tracking Setting Invitations Chart Responses Chart Common Questions If you send your survey via email invitation , you can track how many people opened your invitation, clicked through to the survey, responded to your survey, or opted out of your survey in the Overview tab of the collector. TIP! Follow these steps to set up your Email Invitation Collector before sending your survey so you can track respondents. Opened & Clicked Through Rates By tracking the opened and clicked through rates of your email invitations, you can identify where respondents need help and send more effective follow-up emails. Opened Rate Opened Rate = # Opened / # Total Invitations Your Opened rate is the percentage of recipients who opened the email invitation in their email client. The opened rate helps you measure which subject lines or email delivery times entice people to open the email invitation. To improve your opened rate: Send reminder messages . Write compelling subject lines. Schedule invitations when people are more likely to take surveys . Opened includes both recipients who only opened the invitation AND recipients who opened the invitation and clicked through to the survey. To find the number of people who opened the email invitation but did not click through, simply subtract the number of clicked through from the number of Opened. Opened Rate = # Opened / # Total Invitations Your Opened rate is the percentage of recipients who opened the email invitation in their email client. The opened rate helps you measure which subject lines or email delivery times entice people to open the email invitation. To improve your opened rate: Send reminder messages . Write compelling subject lines. Schedule invitations when people are more likely to take surveys . Opened includes both recipients who only opened the invitation AND recipients who opened the invitation and clicked through to the survey. To find the number of people who opened the email invitation but did not click through, simply subtract the number of clicked through from the number of Opened. Clicked Through Rate Clicked Through Rate = # Clicked Through / # Total Invitations Your clicked through rate is the percentage of recipients who clicked through to the survey by clicking the Begin Survey button (or clicked the survey link). The clicked through rate helps you measure which email content inspires action—in this case, getting your recipients to click the Begin Survey button. To improve your clicked through rate: Make sure your content is easy to understand and concise. Provide a compelling reason to take the survey—explain what the survey's about, how long it will take, and how you'll act on the results. Clicked Through Rate = # Clicked Through / # Total Invitations Your clicked through rate is the percentage of recipients who clicked through to the survey by clicking the Begin Survey button (or clicked the survey link). The clicked through rate helps you measure which email content inspires action—in this case, getting your recipients to click the Begin Survey button. To improve your clicked through rate: Make sure your content is easy to understand and concise. Provide a compelling reason to take the survey—explain what the survey's about, how long it will take, and how you'll act on the results. Click-to-Open Rate Click-to-Open Rate = # Clicked Through / # Opened Your click-to-open rate is the percentage of recipients who clicked through to the survey from the opened email. Click-to-Open Rate = # Clicked Through / # Opened Your click-to-open rate is the percentage of recipients who clicked through to the survey from the opened email. Invitation Tracking Setting Invitation Tracking Track how many people opened your invitation and clicked through to your survey in the Overview tab of the collector. You need to keep Invitation Tracking turned on—it's turned on in the collector options by default. Invitation Tracking has two settings: On, show how many people opened your email invitation and clicked through to your survey Off, don’t show how many people opened your email invitation and clicked through to your survey You can't edit this setting once you schedule or send your first invitation in the collector. If you turned off Invitation Tracking, you're not able to turn it back on . Opened and clicked through data will still be collected in the backend, but you won't be able to see it in your collector. See Information about Page Tags in our Privacy Notice for more info. Invitations Chart Opened & Clicked-Through Rates The Invitations chart tracks how recipients interact with your email invitations. This chart includes useful data like how many recipients opened the email invitation and how many recipients clicked through to your survey. The minimum number of recipients who opened the email invitation in their email client—more people may have opened the email invitation because: Open data can't be tracked if recipients don't download images in their email client. Opened data can't be tracked for messages you send as plain text . Recipients you send plain text messages to are counted as Unopened unless they click through. If they click through, they are counted as both Opened and Clicked through. Responses Chart The Responses chart tracks how recipients interact with your survey. This chart includes useful data like how many people responded to the survey, how many people completed the survey, and how many people only partially completed the survey. TIP! You can calculate your survey response rate by dividing the number of Total Invitations by the number of Total Responses. In general, you can expect a low response rate if your survey is long, your survey language is complicated, or you send your survey to the wrong audience. Read our tips to ensure you're doing all you can to get the best response rate possible . Common Questions How do I view individual recipients or responses? From the Recipients tab of your Email Invitation Collector, you can see exactly which recipients have or haven't taken your survey. Use the drop-down menus to filter by: All Recipients All Responded Complete Responses Partial Responses Not Responded Opted Out Bounced It's not possible to filter by Opened, Clicked Through, or Unopened. You can also view individual responses from the Analyze Results section of your survey. Under the Individual Responses tab, you'll see the email address and response status tied to each individual response. From the Recipients tab of your Email Invitation Collector, you can see exactly which recipients have or haven't taken your survey. Use the drop-down menus to filter by: All Recipients All Responded Complete Responses Partial Responses Not Responded Opted Out Bounced It's not possible to filter by Opened, Clicked Through, or Unopened. You can also view individual responses from the Analyze Results section of your survey. Under the Individual Responses tab, you'll see the email address and response status tied to each individual response. What if a recipient opts out? Recipients can opt out from your email invitations at any time. The number of Opted Out recipients appears below the Invitations chart, separate from the total number of invitations you sent. This is because: Recipients who opt out may have opened the email invitation or clicked through before opting out. Recipients who opt out may have responded to your survey before opting out. Recipients may have previously opted out from your email invitations. Example Status A recipient opens the email invitation and immediately clicks the opts out link. • Opted Out • Opened • Not Responded A recipient opens the email invitation, clicks the Begin Survey button, and completes the survey. Then the recipient clicks the opt out link. • Opted Out • Opened • Clicked Through • Complete A recipient clicks the opt out link from a previous message you sent in a different collector. Then you add them to a new message and send the message. • Opted Out • Unopened* • Not Responded * We don't send messages to email addresses that have previously opted out, but we still include them in your Total Invitations as Unopened and in the Recipients tab as Not Responded. Recipients can opt out from your email invitations at any time. The number of Opted Out recipients appears below the Invitations chart, separate from the total number of invitations you sent. This is because: Recipients who opt out may have opened the email invitation or clicked through before opting out. Recipients who opt out may have responded to your survey before opting out. Recipients may have previously opted out from your email invitations. * We don't send messages to email addresses that have previously opted out, but we still include them in your Total Invitations as Unopened and in the Recipients tab as Not Responded. What if I send a single recipient multiple messages? The Invitations and Responses charts only count each recipient once. No matter how many messages you send to an individual recipient through the collector, they're only counted once in the charts. Example Status You send a recipient an Invitation message, but they don't open it. Then you send them a Reminder message and they do open it. • Opened You send a recipient an Invitation message, but they don't open it. Then you send them a Reminder message and they open it and click the Begin Survey button. • Opened • Clicked Through You send a recipient an Invitation message, but they don't open it. Then you send them another Invitation message and they do open it. • Opened The Invitations and Responses charts only count each recipient once. No matter how many messages you send to an individual recipient through the collector, they're only counted once in the charts. Why don't I see Opened or Clicked Through in my chart? Opened, unopened, and click-through rates are available on Advantage plans or higher—get more info on your plan . Additionally, if you turned Invitation Tracking off, you can't turn it back on once you schedule or send a message in the collector. Opened, Clicked through, and Unopened may not be available in some of your older Email Invitation Collectors. This tracking feature was launched in June 2015. After the feature was added to your SurveyMonkey account, any new Email Invitation Collector you created from can include this tracking data. However, we can't retroactively include this data to older Email Invitation Collectors since tracking wasn't available when those messages were sent. Opened, unopened, and click-through rates are available on Advantage plans or higher—get more info on your plan . Additionally, if you turned Invitation Tracking off, you can't turn it back on once you schedule or send a message in the collector. Opened, Clicked through, and Unopened may not be available in some of your older Email Invitation Collectors. This tracking feature was launched in June 2015. After the feature was added to your SurveyMonkey account, any new Email Invitation Collector you created from can include this tracking data. However, we can't retroactively include this data to older Email Invitation Collectors since tracking wasn't available when those messages were sent. Can I track invitations but still keep their responses anonymous? Even if Anonymous Responses is turned on, you can still track email invitations. This info is tied to the email invitation, not to survey results. Even if Anonymous Responses is turned on, you can still track email invitations. This info is tied to the email invitation, not to survey results. title: Managing Survey Collector Options
body: Managing Survey Collector Options Accessing Collector Options Complete List of Collector Options Managing Survey Collector Options Managing Survey Collector Options Accessing Collector Options Complete List of Collector Options Collectors are ways to send your survey. Each collector type works a little differently, so they all have different sets of options to choose from when you set them up. Collector options are survey settings that enable you to customize the survey-taking experience for your respondents. These settings affect who can access your survey, how many times respondents can take the survey, and what respondents see when they're done. Accessing Collector Options To access your collector options, go to the Collect Responses section of your survey and click the name of the collector. TIP! Collector options are collector-specific, not survey-wide. If you have multiple collectors, you need to customize the settings for each one separately. Complete List of Collector Options The collector options available depend on the collector type you're using. If you don't see a particular option in the collector type you're using, it means it isn't available for that collector type. Learn more in the articles linked below, and be sure to check out the help article about the collector type you're using. Additionally, some collector options aren't available on all SurveyMonkey plans . If a particular feature isn't available on your plan, you'll see the option to upgrade when trying to use the feature. Related Articles Company SurveyMonkey About Us Jobs Blog Help SurveyMonkey Help GetFeedback Help Market Research Help SurveyMonkey Audience Help SurveyMonkey Contribute Help Wufoo Help Apply Help Support Site Status Unsubscribe Contact Us Email Opt-In Policies Legal Center Privacy Policy Cookies Notice California Privacy Notice

title: Notification Center
body: Notification Center Types of Notification Survey Notification Types Collaboration Notifications Types Not Receiving Notifications Notification Center Notification Center Types of Notification Survey Notification Types Collaboration Notifications Types Not Receiving Notifications Keep track of your most recent messages in the Notification Center. With clickable links in your messages, you can quickly navigate to action items, making it even easier to manage feedback, and collaborate with your teammates. Types of Notification There are 3 areas covered by the Notification Center: Surveys Collaboration Account The Notification Center is shown on all pages in the top right corner as a bell icon . When you have unread messages, you'll see the number circled in red. Reading your messages: Select the Bell icon from the main navigation. Click on the link in the message to be taken to the actionable page. You can also Mark all as read . TIP! Both read and unread messages will stay in your Notification Center for 30 days. Survey Notification Types There are a few ways to be notified of new survey responses: Collaboration Notifications Types Not Receiving Notifications If you've turned on notifications but aren't receiving emails, here are a couple of things you can try. Check your account email address Make sure your account email address in My Account is up to date and only you have access to it. Avoid using generic, role-based, or list-serv email addresses like info@, admin@, or sales@yourcompany.com. Notifications won't send to these types of addresses. You can update your account email address at any time. Check your email filters It's possible that your email filter or firewall is blocking notifications. You can add SurveyMonkey domains to your allow list to help them come through. title: Recurring Web Link Surveys
body: Recurring Web Link Surveys How It Works Scheduling a Recurrence Getting Your New Web Links Editing Your Recurrence Analyzing Your Results Recurring Web Link Surveys Recurring Web Link Surveys How It Works Scheduling a Recurrence Getting Your New Web Links Editing Your Recurrence Analyzing Your Results Recurring Surveys Sending your survey via email? Learn more about sending a recurring email invitation . How It Works Setting up a recurrence makes it easier to regularly share the same survey and gather data over time. This collector option saves you time by automatically creating new Web Links , called Occurrences, at a frequency you choose. What's cool about this setting is that you can easily filter your results by each occurrence to see how people responded differently over time. 1. Design your survey 2. Create a Web Link Collector 3. Turn on Recurrence in your collector options 4. Get email notifications when each new Web Link is ready to share with respondents 5. Share the new link Scheduling a Recurrence To create a recurrence: Go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Add a Web Link collector. From the Collector Options, click Recurrence and select On . Select the frequency that the recurrence repeats —daily, weekly, monthly, or quarterly. Choose all other recurrence details, like when the recurrence repeats, how it's determined, and when it ends. (Optional) Edit the Reminder Email Address . Review your Recurrence Summary and click Continue . Click Save on the confirmation window to re-direct to My Recurrences. Once on My Recurrences , you can set up the rest of your collector options in the Template , or grab the link to your survey in the Occurrence. Tracking Respondents Web Link Collectors track IP addresses, but this information can't really help you track respondents . If you want to be able to match each response with the person who submitted it, add required questions to your survey to collect identifying information from respondents. What does "Repeat By" do? When you set up a monthly or quarterly recurrence, the Repeat By setting defines when in the month or quarter you want to receive your new web link. For example: To get a new web link on the 15th of every month, choose Day of the Month. In the Start Date field, pick the 15th on the calendar. To get a new web link on the 2nd Wednesday of every month, choose Day of the Week. In the Start Date field, pick the 2nd Wednesday on the Start Date calendar. When you set up a monthly or quarterly recurrence, the Repeat By setting defines when in the month or quarter you want to receive your new web link. For example: To get a new web link on the 15th of every month, choose Day of the Month. In the Start Date field, pick the 15th on the calendar. To get a new web link on the 2nd Wednesday of every month, choose Day of the Week. In the Start Date field, pick the 2nd Wednesday on the Start Date calendar. Getting Your New Web Links Getting My New Web Link You can copy your new web link from the reminder email, or from the collector in your account. Each new web link is called an Occurrence. Each Occurrence name includes a number so it's easy to tell them apart. To get your new web link: Go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Click the name of your Recurring collector. Collectors with a Recurrence are marked with this icon in your collector list: From My Recurrences , click on the Occurrence you want to access. Copy the URL. Share the link. Reminder Email We'll send a reminder email each time a new web link is created. The email is sent to the address entered in the Reminder Email field during setup. By default, the owner email address is pre-populated in that field, but it can be changed. We recommend sending reminder emails to the person responsible for sharing the survey link. The reminder email can only be sent to 1 person and you can't customize the content of the email. Editing Your Recurrence Editing a Recurrence Any edits you make to the Recurrence Template affect future Occurrences only. To edit your Recurrence: Go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Click the name of the recurring collector you want to edit. Collectors with a Recurrence are marked with this icon in your collector list: Click on the Template nickname to open it. Open your collector options and edit the recurrence options. Click Save . Auto-Save You have to click Save when you turn on a Recurrence or edit options, but your changes are auto-saved when you turn off a Recurrence. Closing a Survey All Occurrences stay open until you close them. Turning off a Recurrence stops any future Occurrences from being created. If a collector had a Recurrence turned on at any point, you won't be able to delete the collector —it remains in your collector list. All Occurrences stay open until you close them. Turning off a Recurrence stops any future Occurrences from being created. If a collector had a Recurrence turned on at any point, you won't be able to delete the collector —it remains in your collector list. Renaming Occurrences The default name of each Occurrence includes a sequential number based on when the web link was created, but you can give it a custom nickname if you’d like. To rename an Occurrence: Go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Click the name of the Recurring collector. Click the Occurrence nickname. Click the name of the Occurrence Web Link. Edit the name and click Save . The default name of each Occurrence includes a sequential number based on when the web link was created, but you can give it a custom nickname if you’d like. To rename an Occurrence: Go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Click the name of the Recurring collector. Click the Occurrence nickname. Click the name of the Occurrence Web Link. Edit the name and click Save . Analyzing Your Results To focus in on the results of a specific Occurrences in the Analyze Results section, you can filter by collector . If you want to export your results , we suggest an All Responses Data export in XLS format so you can easily sort and filter your responses by collector.
