title: Survey Response Statuses
body: Survey Response Statuses Individual Response Statuses Survey Response Statuses Survey Response Statuses Individual Response Statuses You can find the total number of responses to your survey in your survey's Summary tab. A survey response is one survey taker's submission of a survey, whether they completed the survey or only partially completed it. Responses are recorded in the Analyze Results section of your survey when survey takers click the navigation buttons in the survey. Responses are recorded when a survey taker completes a page of the survey and clicks the Next button to continue to the next page. Responses are recorded when a survey taker finishes the survey and clicks the Done button. If a respondent clicks Next or Done and they haven't answered a required question or they haven't properly answered a question with validation , they will see an error message. Their responses won't be recorded until they answer the question and click Next or Done again. Individual Response Statuses In the Individual Responses tab of your survey results, each response will have one of the following statuses: Respondents with complete responses may have skipped required questions in the survey due to logic in your survey design. Complete responses also include respondents who skip questions that weren't required. TIP! While response statuses are not included in exports, you can filter your survey results by response status or completeness to export results by response status. title: Benchmark Data
body: Benchmark Data Your Profile & Organization Shared Surveys Opting Out of Benchmarks Benchmark Data Benchmark Data Your Profile & Organization Shared Surveys Opting Out of Benchmarks Benchmark data comes from SurveyMonkey customers who used Question Bank questions in their surveys. Organizations of all shapes and sizes use Question Bank, like local coffee shops, schools, and Fortune 500 companies. To calculate a SurveyMonkey Global Benchmark for each question, we (1) find an average response for each individual survey, then (2) add up those individual scores to generate an average across all surveys. We categorize responses into comparison groups based on factors like industry, size, and location to provide more targeted benchmarks. To focus on a particular segment of the SurveyMonkey Global Benchmark, you can buy Industry Benchmarks that only contain the responses from these comparison groups. To preserve privacy , responses for a given question are aggregated and de-identified to create a set of average statistics about that question—we don't disclose any individual responses, personal information, or organization names. Benchmark data is refreshed quarterly (every 3 months). TIP! You can buy Industry Benchmarks to help you narrow down the types of organizations included in a benchmark, like country, organization size, or industry. Your Profile & Organization When using SurveyMonkey, you may be asked to provide some profile information about yourself or your organization, such as your organization name or the industry you work in. Profile information allows us to: Customize your experience using Question Bank by showing you suggested questions. Create benchmarks from aggregated information about your Question Bank responses. Show you relevant benchmarks for certain Question Bank questions. You may be required to provide profile information in order to access certain benchmarks. You can edit your profile info anytime. To edit your profile: Go to My account . Scroll to General Preferences to find Profile . Edit the info about your survey intent and select Next . Select the types of surveys you want to send and select Next . You can also Delete your profile info at anytime. Shared Surveys If you're part of a team , you can share surveys with others. People with Full Access permissions can view all benchmarks (free or paid) on surveys shared with them. People with View Only access can only see the SurveyMonkey Global Benchmark on surveys shared with them. People don't need to complete their profile to view benchmarks on surveys shared with them. Benchmark data collected from Question Bank questions being used in shared surveys is attributed to the profile information in the survey owner's account, not to accounts a survey is shared with. Opting Out of Benchmarks If benchmarks are enabled in your account, survey responses to Question Bank questions you have used may be included in benchmarks on a de-identified and aggregated basis. You'll also be able to access benchmarks on eligible questions. You can opt out of contributing your responses to benchmarks. If you disable benchmarks, your survey responses will be excluded from the benchmarks the next time the system refreshes them—typically every week. Additionally, you'll no longer be able to view benchmarks if you haven't purchased benchmarks. To exclude your data from benchmarks: Log in and go to My Account . Scroll to the Data Features section. Click Edit next to Access to Benchmarks . Select Off . Click Save . For additional information about how we handle your personal information and data, please see our Privacy Notice . title: Sentiment Analysis
body: Sentiment Analysis Video Overview Using Sentiment Analysis Uncategorized Responses Filtering by Sentiment Exporting Sentiments Sentiment Analysis Sentiment Analysis Video Overview Using Sentiment Analysis Uncategorized Responses Filtering by Sentiment Exporting Sentiments PAID FEATURE: The features listed below are paid features. Some are only available on particular paid plans—see what's on your plan . Sentiment Analysis automatically categorizes your text responses to reveal the emotion behind what people are saying. This feature can be used for all open-ended text except for Multiple Textboxes and the Contact Information question type. English only: Sentiment Analysis is available for English responses only. If you have data stored in our Canadian Data Center, this feature isn't available. You can see if this applies to you by checking your Account Details . Video Overview Using Sentiment Analysis You need full access to a survey to turn on Sentiment Analysis. Once you turn it on, Sentiment Analysis will be active for all open-ended questions in your survey. Teams and Enterprise plans: If Sentiment Analysis is blocked, your primary admin may have turned off access . Ask your admin for access to this feature. To turn Sentiment Analysis on: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Scroll to a question with text responses. Go to the Responses tab of your question. Select Analyze sentiment from the banner. If you're using Sentiment Analysis for the first time, you'll see a confirmation message. Select Continue . Select the Responses tab to view sentiments. Responses are categorized as Positive , Neutral , Negative , or Undetected , and a corresponding icon appears next to the response. If you need to change a response's sentiment to one that's more accurate, you can click the sentiment icon to select a new one. Disabling Sentiment Analysis Sentiment Analysis works for all open-ended questions in your survey. If you turn off Sentiment Analysis, sentiments will be removed from all survey questions. To turn off Sentiment Analysis: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Select the gear icon in the toolbar. Toggle off the Sentiment Analysis option. Uncategorized Responses If your survey has already collected a lot of responses before you turn Sentiment Analysis on, responses might appear uncategorized for a few minutes while it works to process and categorize them. If a response is categorized as Undetected , we didn't have enough information to categorize it. Filtering by Sentiment You can filter responses by sentiment within a question or across your entire survey. Filtering within a question When you filter by sentiment within a question, you're displaying text responses to a question categorized with a specific sentiment. For example, if you want to only see responses from people who answered a question positively. To filter by sentiment within a question: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Scroll to a question with text responses. Go to the Responses tab. Click Filter by Sentiment . Select which sentiments you want to display. Click Apply . This shows you only responses categorized with that sentiment. You can also choose to display any responses with undetected sentiments. When you filter by sentiment within a question, you're displaying text responses to a question categorized with a specific sentiment. For example, if you want to only see responses from people who answered a question positively. To filter by sentiment within a question: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Scroll to a question with text responses. Go to the Responses tab. Click Filter by Sentiment . Select which sentiments you want to display. Click Apply . This shows you only responses categorized with that sentiment. You can also choose to display any responses with undetected sentiments. Filtering across a survey When you filter by sentiment across a survey, you're displaying responses to each question in your survey from people who responded to a question with a specific sentiment. For example, if you want to see how people who responded negatively to a question responded to the rest of your survey. To filter by sentiment across an entire survey, create a Filter rule to filter by sentiment. When you filter by sentiment across a survey, you're displaying responses to each question in your survey from people who responded to a question with a specific sentiment. For example, if you want to see how people who responded negatively to a question responded to the rest of your survey. To filter by sentiment across an entire survey, create a Filter rule to filter by sentiment. Exporting Sentiments To export your survey results with sentiment categories included: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Click Save As at the top of the page. Click Export file. Select the Summary Data export type. Choose XLS . Select Open-ended responses , and click Export . Select Exports in the toolbar, then click the export to download the file to your computer. Exports are stored here for 14 days. title: Combining or Hiding Answer Choices
body: Combining or Hiding Answer Choices Combine Answer Choices Hide Answer Choices with No Responses Combining or Hiding Answer Choices Combining or Hiding Answer Choices Combine Answer Choices Hide Answer Choices with No Responses You can combine or hide answer choices in a chart for closed-ended question types with a single answer choice allowed. Combine Answer Choices To combine or hide answer choices: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Scroll to the chart you want to hide answer choices from. Click the answer choice from the data table below the chart. Select either Exclude from total or Hide and recalculate . We'll recalculate the data for you. (If you don't see the option, the feature isn't available for the question type.) If combining, select the answer choices and rename the label. You can also filter by combined answer choices. To uncombine or unhide answer choices, click the appropriate answer choice and select Uncombine data or click Show beneath the data table. Combining and hiding answer choices only affects the display of your charts—it doesn't affect the raw data or survey design. These combined labels can't be used to create filters, compare rules, or show rules. Hide Answer Choices with No Responses Hide answer choices that didn't receive any responses from your chart. If you hide zero-response answer choices, they won't appear in PDF or PowerPoint exports of summary data. To hide answer choices that didn't receive any responses: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Scroll to the chart you want to hide answer choices from. Select Customize , then go to the Display Options . Select Zero-response answer choices . The following question types aren't supported: Best/Worst Scale, Matrix, Matrix Dropdown, NPS, Ranking, Slider, Star Rating Related Articles Company SurveyMonkey About Us Jobs Blog Help SurveyMonkey Help GetFeedback Help Market Research Help SurveyMonkey Audience Help SurveyMonkey Contribute Help Wufoo Help Apply Help Support Site Status Unsubscribe Contact Us Email Opt-In Policies Legal Center Privacy Policy Cookies Notice California Privacy Notice

title: Viewing a Specific Comment in the Analysis
body: Viewing a Specific Comment in the Analysis Viewing a Specific Comment in the Analysis Viewing a Specific Comment in the Analysis Click the Individual Responses tab and use the left and right arrow buttons to browse through individual answer sets, including open-ended comments. To view all open-ended comments for a question: Find the question in the Question Summaries tab. Click Responses to show all comments. Click View respondent's answers to see the respondent's answers to the rest of the questions in the survey. If you'd like to focus your analysis on a specific open-ended question, create a Show rule and choose to show only that question. Show rules also carry over to the Individual Responses tab. title: Get Quick Insights with Analyze with AI
body: Get Quick Insights with Analyze with AI Survey Requirements Feature Availability and Settings Using Analyze with AI Asking Useful Questions Get Quick Insights with Analyze with AI Get Quick Insights with Analyze with AI Survey Requirements Feature Availability and Settings Using Analyze with AI Asking Useful Questions Analyze with AI helps you find key insights and trends in your survey data by responding to your questions with charts and insight summaries. With Analyze with AI, you can: Uncover insights based on responses, timeframes, and more in seconds Ask for comparisons, or information about specific segments Visualize data points based on your results Export and share any charts that Analyze with AI creates for you How it works: Analyze with AI helps you segment, summarize, and visualize your survey responses to quickly gather insights. It doesn’t modify anything in your survey, such as applying filters to responses on the page, editing charts, or building dashboards. It draws insights from all of your results, regardless of any filters you’ve applied. What it can analyze: Analyze with AI can analyze these question types and data: Multiple Choice Checkbox Dropdown NPS Star Rating Matrix/Rating Scale Ranking Matrix of Dropdown Menus Comment Box (if responses are tagged) Single Text Box (if responses are tagged) Basic demographic information (for surveys sent via SurveyMonkey Audience ) How to analyze Comment Box and Single Text Box: Analyze with AI can only analyze open-ended text responses if they’re tagged. If you have access to Sentiment Analysis or Thematic Analysis , Analyze with AI can generate sentiments and themes for deeper insights into open-ended responses. You’ll also see any tags or themes that Analyze with AI created on the Question Summaries page. Analyze with AI also supports existing tags that you’ve created via Sentiment Analysis, Thematic Analysis, rule-based tagging , or manual tagging . Survey Requirements Analyze with AI is available for surveys that meet these requirements: The survey language is in English Your survey has between 1 and 10,000 responses Limitations Analyze with AI can’t answer questions about your account or offer product support. Analyze with AI can’t answer questions about logic, advanced branching, or piping that have been applied to your survey. The feature may not be able to answer questions about complex custom variables or custom data added to your collectors. Analyze with AI can’t answer questions about “Other” textbox responses from Multiple Choice, Checkboxes, and Star Rating Scale question types. Certain survey use cases are not permitted—for details, please see SurveyMonkey's Acceptable Uses Policy , as well as additional third party provider usage policies , and acceptable use and conduct policies Feature Availability and Settings Analyze with AI is only available to some customers in supported regions. The way you access this feature depends on your plan: Individual plans : If Analyze with AI is available for your plan, you can access it at any time. Teams and Enterprise plans : Your Primary Admin determines whether your team can access Analyze with AI . For details on the terms that apply to the use of this feature, please see our Self-Serve AI Service-Specific Terms and SurveyMonkey Enterprise Service-Specific Terms . HIPAA and Enhanced Sensitive Data Protection : Analyze with AI isn’t available to HIPAA-enabled accounts, or those with the Enhanced Sensitive Data Protection feature enabled. Additionally, based on your plan type, Analyze with AI may set limitations on the number of questions available per survey. Analyze with AI is also subject to fair use of the feature, so your account may be temporarily disabled if we notice abnormal activity. How Your Data is Processed Analyze with AI uses Azure Open AI service or Open AI to generate insights about your survey. Your content isn’t used to train these third party providers’ models. Learn more about how this feature processes your data . Don’t include sensitive or personal information in your questions – you are responsible for the information you enter in Analyze with AI. Analyze with AI’s answers may have limitations based on the survey data or how you phrased your questions. Review the results carefully. Use of this feature is subject to additional terms, as described in our Service-Specific Terms . Using Analyze with AI To use Analyze with AI: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. To include open-text questions in your analysis, make sure to tag text responses. If you have access to Sentiment Analysis or Thematic Analysis , Analyze with AI can tag your responses for you. You can also use rule-based tagging or manual tagging . Select Analyze with AI in the top right corner of the Question Summaries page. If you don’t see the Analyze with AI option, the feature isn’t available for your survey or account. Accept the terms and conditions. Type your question, or select View suggestions and select a suggested question. Select Send to ask your question. Understanding and Rating Answers Analyze with AI provides a text explanation in each answer. Some answers include a chart or table. Hover over the info icon below the chart to learn how Analyze with AI got this result. You can also see the survey questions that Analyze with AI used for its answer. You can rate the answer to let us know if it was helpful or accurate. Select the thumbs up or thumbs down button to rate the answer. You can also leave a comment about your negative rating or submit your feedback via the feedback form. Your ratings help us improve Analyze with AI and provide more relevant answers in the future. Asking Useful Questions Here are a few tips to improve the answers you get from Analyze with AI. Use the terms “responses” and “respondents” carefully. Use respondents to ask about the total number of individuals. Use responses If you want the number of votes or choices. Use respondents to ask about the total number of individuals. Use responses If you want the number of votes or choices. Use terms and concepts from your survey. This helps Analyze with AI understand what data to find and analyze for you. For example, if your survey is about a specific product or industry, ask questions that include the product or industry in your survey. This helps Analyze with AI understand what data to find and analyze for you. For example, if your survey is about a specific product or industry, ask questions that include the product or industry in your survey. Be specific. Clearly define what specific aspect of the data you are inquiring about. Example : Don’t ask what the “best product” is. Instead, you can ask, “Which product has the highest satisfaction level?" Clearly define what specific aspect of the data you are inquiring about. Example : Don’t ask what the “best product” is. Instead, you can ask, “Which product has the highest satisfaction level?" Avoid general questions. Instead, target specific questions, metrics, or trends. Example : If you’re asking about NPS scores, don’t ask, “How much positive feedback did we get?” Instead, ask about the percentage of promoters. Instead, target specific questions, metrics, or trends. Example : If you’re asking about NPS scores, don’t ask, “How much positive feedback did we get?” Instead, ask about the percentage of promoters. Use clear and direct language. Avoid jargon or overly complex terms unless they are directly relevant to your survey. Avoid jargon or overly complex terms unless they are directly relevant to your survey. Quantify when possible. Ask for numbers or percentages to get more specific results. Example : "What percentage of respondents were very satisfied with the product quality?" Ask for numbers or percentages to get more specific results. Example : "What percentage of respondents were very satisfied with the product quality?" Ask for comparative analysis If you’re interested in trends, comparisons, or changes, specify the exact parameters you want compared. Example: "Compare the satisfaction levels between different age groups." If you’re interested in trends, comparisons, or changes, specify the exact parameters you want compared. Example: "Compare the satisfaction levels between different age groups." Focus on actionable insights. Ask for actionable insights or recommendations. Example: "Based on the survey responses, what areas should we focus on to improve customer satisfaction?" Ask for actionable insights or recommendations. Example: "Based on the survey responses, what areas should we focus on to improve customer satisfaction?" Consider data breakdown Specify if you need a breakdown of responses by certain demographics or categories. Example: "What are the satisfaction levels by geographic region?" Specify if you need a breakdown of responses by certain demographics or categories. Example: "What are the satisfaction levels by geographic region?" Seek clarifications on anomalies If you notice any unusual patterns or outliers in your data, ask for clarifications or deeper analysis. Example: "Why might there be a higher dissatisfaction rate among customers aged 18-24?" If you notice any unusual patterns or outliers in your data, ask for clarifications or deeper analysis. Example: "Why might there be a higher dissatisfaction rate among customers aged 18-24?" Ask a different question when you get the wrong result. If Analyze with AI doesn’t answer your question with the right information, ask again in a different way. Use the thumbs up and thumbs down to rate the responses so we can improve Analyze with AI. If Analyze with AI doesn’t answer your question with the right information, ask again in a different way. Use the thumbs up and thumbs down to rate the responses so we can improve Analyze with AI. title: PDF Exports
body: PDF Exports All Summary Data All Individual Responses PDF Exports PDF Exports All Summary Data All Individual Responses Exports You can export your survey results as a PDF (Portable Document Format). PDF exports are ideal for printing and sharing since they require no additional analysis or editing. See example exports » To export your survey results: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Click Save As at the top of the page. Click Export files . Select an export type: All Summary Data or All Individual Responses . Choose PDF , select your export options, then select Export . To download your export, select Exports in the toolbar, then select the export. Exports are stored in the Exports menu for 14 days. All Summary Data All Summary Data exports organize survey results by question summaries. The PDF export includes the exact charts, tables, and open-ended responses you see in the Question Summaries tab. Make sure to select include open-ended responses when exporting to see answers from Comment Boxes, Textboxes, or questions where Other was an answer option or comment field. You have to option to start each question on a new page , which adds a page break after each question. To export the results of an individual question rather than the entire view, click Export at the top of a question rather than Export All at the top of the page. To get the most out of your PDF export, learn more about creating custom charts . All Individual Responses All Individual Responses exports organize survey results by respondent. The same export formats are available for both All Responses Data and All Individual Responses. The All Individual Responses export type simply pre-selects PDF so you can quickly download the same information you see in the Individual Responses tab. You can export up to 3000 answers at a time, so, if you have a survey with 10 questions, you could export up to 300 complete responses at a time. You can export the answers for a single respondent under the Individual Responses tab. Click Export in the upper-right corner of the response. title: Exporting an Individual Question
body: Exporting an Individual Question Export a Summary Export Raw Data Exporting an Individual Question Exporting an Individual Question Export a Summary Export Raw Data Exports Export a Summary To export a summary of an individual question: Click the Analyze Results tab of your survey. Find the question you want to export. In the top right corner of the chart, select Save As . Select Question summary data . Choose the format and any special options. Select Export . Export Raw Data To export all the raw data of an individual question, export your results with a Show rule applied: Click the Analyze Results tab of your survey. From the left sidebar, click +Show . Select the question you'd like to include in the Show rule. Click Apply . Only the selected question will show in the results summary on the right side of the page. To export that question, in the upper-right corner, click Save As at the top of the page. Click Export file . Choose All responses data . In the Export Survey Data prompt, choose an export format. Click Export . title: Creating Views
body: Creating Views Types of Views Creating a Saved View Managing Saved Views Sharing & Exporting Views Creating Views Creating Views Types of Views Creating a Saved View Managing Saved Views Sharing & Exporting Views A view is a snapshot of survey data made up of rules you apply to your survey results. You can create a Saved View to easily go back to see sections of your data at any time, without having to recreate them. For example, say you sent out a customer satisfaction survey that included questions about which store location the customer visited. You can break down the survey results using rules, then create a Saved View for each store location and easily switch between each Saved View to better understand the feedback. Types of Views Creating a Saved View Saved Views To create a Saved View: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Select Rules from the toolbar, then apply rules to your survey results. Once you have a combination you like, click Save As in the upper-right corner of the screen. Select New View . Your Saved View will show up in the Saved Views section of the sidebar. TIP! If your survey is shared with your team , your Saved View is visible to anyone the survey is shared with. Managing Saved Views To edit or delete a view: Select Saved Views from the toolbar. Click the three dots menu next to a view to rename, copy, or delete it. A green check mark ✅ next to a view means the view is active. You can toggle a view on and off by clicking its name. If you add or delete a rule while a Saved View is active, you will see Save and Revert buttons appear next to the it. Click Save to save the new rule to that Saved View. Click Revert to revert back to the Saved View as it was before. Sharing & Exporting Views Sharing a View with a Link You can share a link to a Saved View. This creates a shared data page . Exporting a View Exports You can export your survey results with rules applied by either exporting the Current View or a Saved View. To export a view: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Click Saved Views from the toolbar. Click the three dots menu next to the view you want to export. Select Export view . Choose either Summary data or All responses data . Select the file format and settings you want. Click Export . Select Exports from the toolbar, then click the export to download the file to your computer. Exports are stored here for 14 days. title: Show Rules
body: Show Rules Creating a Show Rule Managing Show Rules Exporting & Sharing Show Rules Show Rules Show Rules Creating a Show Rule Managing Show Rules Exporting & Sharing Show Rules Show rules let you focus on specific parts of your survey results. Choose which pages or questions you want to see, and we'll hide the rest. You can only create one show rule at a time. Creating a Show Rule To create a show rule: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Select Rules from the toolbar, then click + Show . Choose the criteria you want to focus on. Click Apply . At the top of the page, you'll see the number of responses included in your rule compared to the total number of responses you received. You'll see any active rules at the top of the page. We'll also show the number of responses included in your rule, compared to the number of responses in your survey. Managing Show Rules To manage show rules: Select Rules from the toolbar. Click the three dots menu next to a show rule to unapply, edit, rename, or delete it. You can't copy a show rule. Click the name of the rule to turn it on or off. A green check mark ✅ next to a rule means that the rule is active. You'll also see any active rules at the top of the page. Exporting & Sharing Show Rules You can export your results with rules applied or share your survey results with other people. Save multiple rules together as a view to easily access different sections of your data. title: Shared Data Pages
body: Shared Data Pages Creating a Shared Data Page Customizing a Shared Data Page Commenting on a Shared Data Page Sharing a Shared Data Page Shared Data Pages Shared Data Pages Creating a Shared Data Page Customizing a Shared Data Page Commenting on a Shared Data Page Sharing a Shared Data Page You can use shared data pages to share your survey results without giving people access to a survey in their account. See an example » Shared data pages are great if you want to easily share your results with someone. If you want to create a customizable report and add additional context to your results, you can create a results dashboard . Creating a Shared Data Page Share the saved view selected in the Analyze Results section of your survey as a link. If you make visual changes to custom charts after you create a link, you’ll need to make a new shared data page link. To create a shared data page: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Select Share , then select New Shared data link . The page opens in a new tab. Customize the shared data pages' share settings , then select Get Link. Copy your link, then select Save . From the Analyze Results section, you can access your shared data links by selecting Share > Previous shared data link . Once a shared data page is open, you can select Share Settings to make changes. People can bookmark or copy and paste the link to share your shared data pages. To share a protected version of your results, select password protection in the share settings. Customizing a Shared Data Page Hide Branding (Shared Data Pages) White Label URL You can customize the following information: Using a White Label URL To use the white label URL for your shared data page: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Select Shared Data in the toolbar. Find the shared data page you want, then select the More icon next to it. Select Manage Share Settings . Select Get Link . Select Customize . Choose between the www.surveymonkey.com and www.research.net domains using the dropdown. Select Save . To use the white label URL for your shared data page: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Select Shared Data in the toolbar. Find the shared data page you want, then select the More icon next to it. Select Manage Share Settings . Select Get Link . Select Customize . Choose between the www.surveymonkey.com and www.research.net domains using the dropdown. Select Save . Commenting on a Shared Data Page Get feedback or work with others by inviting people to comment on your shared data page. Viewers need a SurveyMonkey account to leave comments on a shared data page. When someone tries to leave a comment, they'll be prompted to sign in to their account. It's not possible to turn off commenting on a shared data page. Sharing a Shared Data Page You can create a link for your shared data page and share your survey results. Anyone can view this page, even if they don't have a SurveyMonkey account. If your survey is still open and collecting responses, the shared data page will update within a few minutes with new responses. To share a link to your shared data page: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Select Share , then select Previous shared data link . Select the shared data page to open it in a new tab. Select Copy . Share your link with others. TIP! If you're on a team, you can share surveys with others and give them access to the Analyze Results section in their own account. Limiting Access to a Shared Data Page Password Protecting Shared Results You can limit access to your shared data page by adding password protection or turning off sharing. Adding password protection You can password protect your shared data page. Anyone you share the link with will need to enter the password to access it. You can change the password at any time. Anyone you've previously shared the shared results page with will be prompted to enter the new password if they visit the link or refresh their browser. To password protect your shared data page: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. In the toolbar, click Shared Data . Find the shared data page you want and select the More icon next to it. Select Manage Share Settings . Select Password Protection . Enter a password. Select Get Link . Select Save . You can password protect your shared data page. Anyone you share the link with will need to enter the password to access it. You can change the password at any time. Anyone you've previously shared the shared results page with will be prompted to enter the new password if they visit the link or refresh their browser. To password protect your shared data page: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. In the toolbar, click Shared Data . Find the shared data page you want and select the More icon next to it. Select Manage Share Settings . Select Password Protection . Enter a password. Select Get Link . Select Save . Turn off sharing If you need to limit access to a shared data page after you've shared it, you can add a password or turn sharing off. Anyone you've previously shared the dashboard with won't be able to access the shared data page if they visit the link or refresh their browser. To turn sharing off: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. In the toolbar, select Shared Data . Find the shared data page you want and click the More icon next to it. Select Turn sharing off . If you need to limit access to a shared data page after you've shared it, you can add a password or turn sharing off. Anyone you've previously shared the dashboard with won't be able to access the shared data page if they visit the link or refresh their browser. To turn sharing off: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. In the toolbar, select Shared Data . Find the shared data page you want and click the More icon next to it. Select Turn sharing off . title: Excluding Respondents who Skipped Questions
body: Excluding Respondents who Skipped Questions Excluding Respondents who Skipped Questions Excluding Respondents who Skipped Questions To hide or filter out respondents that skipped a particular question, create a Filter by Question and Answer with every answer choice to that question included as the filter criteria. This will ensure that only respondents that answered the question will be included in the filtered view. Any respondent that did not select an answer choice for the question will be excluded from that view. When a filter is applied, only the responses that meet the defined filter criteria will show in the response summary on the right side of the page. title: Analyzing Text Responses
body: Analyzing Text Responses Analyzing Text Responses Analyzing Text Responses You can find insights and trends in your text responses by using our text analysis features: Related Articles Company SurveyMonkey About Us Jobs Blog Help SurveyMonkey Help GetFeedback Help Market Research Help SurveyMonkey Audience Help SurveyMonkey Contribute Help Wufoo Help Apply Help Support Site Status Unsubscribe Contact Us Email Opt-In Policies Legal Center Privacy Policy Cookies Notice California Privacy Notice

title: CSV Exports
body: CSV Exports All Summary Data All Responses Data Opening a CSV CSV Exports CSV Exports All Summary Data All Responses Data Opening a CSV Exports You can export your survey results as a CSV (Comma Separated Value). CSV exports open in spreadsheet software programs, like Excel or Numbers. See example exports » To export your survey results: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Select Save As at the top of the page. Select Export files . Select an export type: All Summary Data or All Responses Data . Choose CSV , select your export options, and click Export . To download your file, select Exports in the toolbar, then select the export. Exports are stored in the Exports menu for 14 days. All Summary Data All Summary Data exports organize survey results by question. Depending on question type , the CSV export includes: The text of the question and answer options The response count and percentage per answer choice The number of respondents who answered and the number who skipped the question Make sure to select include open-ended responses when exporting to see answers from Comment Boxes, Textboxes, or questions where Other was an answer option or comment field. This will download additional spreadsheets for each open-ended response you have. You'll notice the export comes with two file types: CSV and XLS. Both contain the same information. The difference is that CSVs are saved in plain text with fields separated by commas, while XLS files may contain rich text and separate fields by cells. Unless you know you need a CSV file, open the XLS files—they are typically easier for most people to use. All Responses Data All Responses Data exports organize survey results by respondent. CSVs are saved in plain text with fields separated by commas. Opening a CSV In most cases, you can open a CSV by double-clicking it. This will open your default spreadsheet program. In some cases, you may need to use the Text Import Wizard to help you open the file. Make sure to select Delimited , Comma , and Text in the prompts. Use the Text Import Wizard if: You used Unicode in your survey and the characters aren't displaying correctly The data is displaying all in one column Data from your survey is being converted into a date when it should be a fraction or score Related Articles Company SurveyMonkey About Us Jobs Blog Help SurveyMonkey Help GetFeedback Help Market Research Help SurveyMonkey Audience Help SurveyMonkey Contribute Help Wufoo Help Apply Help Support Site Status Unsubscribe Contact Us Email Opt-In Policies Legal Center Privacy Policy Cookies Notice California Privacy Notice

title: Missing Survey Responses
body: Missing Survey Responses When are responses recorded? What account are you logged into? Did you send the preview link? Design Issues Missing Survey Responses Missing Survey Responses When are responses recorded? What account are you logged into? Did you send the preview link? Design Issues When are responses recorded? As long as you send out the correct survey link, responses are saved and recorded in the Analyze Results section of your survey whenever: A survey taker completes a survey page and clicks the Next button to continue to the next page. A survey taker finishes the survey and clicks the Done button. A survey taker answers the first question embedded in an email invitation when In-email response capture collector option is set to on and the question doesn’t have an Other Textbox or Comment field . What account are you logged into? If you're not seeing any responses at all , make sure you're logged in to the correct account. If you have multiple accounts, you need to be logged in to the account where you created the survey. Did you send the preview link? Check the survey link you sent out. Responses don't record using the preview link . You'll know if you sent the preview link if the URL has the word "preview" anywhere in it. If you're using an Email Invitation Collector , the correct unique link is sent automatically when you send the message. If you're using a Web Link Collector , click on its name from the Collect Responses section of your survey to find the correct link. Design Issues The design of your survey may affect the results or your survey takers' ability to submit responses. Click a topic below for more information: My survey has required questions Questions that are required to answer can sometimes confuse survey takers. If someone clicks Next or Done and they haven't answered a required question, their responses from that page won't be recorded until they answer the question and click Next or Done again. Questions that are required to answer can sometimes confuse survey takers. If someone clicks Next or Done and they haven't answered a required question, their responses from that page won't be recorded until they answer the question and click Next or Done again. My survey has question validation If you set a specific number range or character limit for an open-ended question, customize the error message to be specific about these requirements. This helps survey takers know what to do to successfully advance through the survey. If someone clicks Next or Done but they haven't answered the question properly, their responses from that page won't be recorded until they answer the question properly and click Next or Done again. If you set a specific number range or character limit for an open-ended question, customize the error message to be specific about these requirements. This helps survey takers know what to do to successfully advance through the survey. If someone clicks Next or Done but they haven't answered the question properly, their responses from that page won't be recorded until they answer the question properly and click Next or Done again. My survey has Skip Logic If you included Skip Logic in your survey design, there may be logic on a question or page that is directing respondents backwards in the survey. This can create an endless loop that blocks survey takers from finishing the survey. Test each logic path using the preview link to confirm everything is set up correctly. You can edit a live survey , even if you already sent it out. If you included Skip Logic in your survey design, there may be logic on a question or page that is directing respondents backwards in the survey. This can create an endless loop that blocks survey takers from finishing the survey. Test each logic path using the preview link to confirm everything is set up correctly. You can edit a live survey , even if you already sent it out. My survey is long Pages that are too long can overwhelm survey takers. If you included required questions or question validation in the design, survey takers might not be able to find which question is causing the error if the page is too long. If someone exits the survey without clicking Next or Done, their responses from that page won't be recorded. Design your survey using multiple shorter pages so responses are saved more often. Pages that are too long can overwhelm survey takers. If you included required questions or question validation in the design, survey takers might not be able to find which question is causing the error if the page is too long. If someone exits the survey without clicking Next or Done, their responses from that page won't be recorded. Design your survey using multiple shorter pages so responses are saved more often. Track your respondents so you can see who has or hasn't submitted a survey response. Tracking must be set up before you send out your survey. title: Filtering by Open-Ended Comments or Text
body: Filtering by Open-Ended Comments or Text Filter by Tags Filter by Question and Answer Filtering by Open-Ended Comments or Text Filtering by Open-Ended Comments or Text Filter by Tags Filter by Question and Answer You can filter your survey results by specific words or phrases people may have used in open-ended responses. Filter by Tags You can use the text analysis features to identify and tag recurring words or phrases in your open-ended text responses, then filter by those tags. Filter by Question and Answer Since survey takers may have used synonyms, misspelled words, or abbreviated terms, we recommend filtering by multiple words or phrases. When creating a filter, separate the words or phrases you want to filter for by commas. The filtered view will include responses that match any of the answer criteria defined in the filter. You can filter by the following open-ended question types: Numerical Textboxes - Choose the row to filter by, and choose to filter results that are Greater than , Less than , or Equal to the value you enter. Single Textbox or Comment Box - Enter word(s) or a phrase you'd like to filter by and choose to include responses that match All Words , Any Words , or the Exact Phrase . Multiple Textboxes - Choose the row to filter by, and enter a word or phrase. Choose to include responses that match All Words , Any Words , or the Exact Phrase . Contact Information - Choose the row to filter by, and enter a word or phrase. Choose to include responses that match All Words , Any Words , or the Exact Phrase . Date and/or Time - Enter the date and/or time you'd like to filter by, and choose to include responses that were submitted Before , After , or Exactly on that date and/or at that time. title: SPSS Exports
body: SPSS Exports SPSS Exports SPSS Exports SPSS Export You can export your surveys results to use in SPSS (Statistical Package for the Social Sciences)—a popular computer program used for statistical analysis. See example exports » SPSS exports are available for All Responses Data exports. All Responses Data exports allow you to see the complete answer set for each respondent. To export your survey results: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Select Save As at the top of the page. Select Export files . Select the All Responses Data export type. Choose SPSS , select your export options, and click Export . To download your file, select Exports from the toolbar, then select the export. Exports are stored here for 14 days. The export includes SAV file. We recommend using SPSS 17.0.1 or greater to open the file. The following information will help you get started analyzing in your SPSS program: Variable View vs. Data View The Variable View defines each question and answer choices. The Data View is a spreadsheet-style view with all the responses. Questions are labeled as q0001, q0002, q0003, and so on. You can edit these labels in the cells of the Variable View, which updates the column headers of the Data View. Answer choices are assigned both a numeric value and a variable label name. Use the Variable View to reference the values and names. In the Data View, click View > Value Labels in the toolbar to show the variable label names instead of the numeric values. The Variable View defines each question and answer choices. The Data View is a spreadsheet-style view with all the responses. Questions are labeled as q0001, q0002, q0003, and so on. You can edit these labels in the cells of the Variable View, which updates the column headers of the Data View. Answer choices are assigned both a numeric value and a variable label name. Use the Variable View to reference the values and names. In the Data View, click View > Value Labels in the toolbar to show the variable label names instead of the numeric values. Measure & Question Types Measure Measure is determined from the question type . Scale = Ranking and Numerical Textbox questions Nominal = all other question types Multiple Choice SPSS assigns a numeric value to answer choices, which you can reference in the Variable View. If multiple answers are allowed, the data will be separated into multiple columns in the Data View since multiple answers cannot exist in one cell. Ranking and Matrix Questions The data is separated into multiple columns (as many columns as you have in your question). SPSS assigns the numeric value by the weighted value, which is not necessarily how you have the answer choices ordered in the survey. This means column one is whatever answer choice was assigned the weight of 1 in the survey, column two is the answer choice with the weight of 2, and so on. The N/A column is coded as 0. If you assigned the weight of 0 to another answer choice, the cell will show .00 and you'll need to manually fix this. Measure Measure is determined from the question type . Scale = Ranking and Numerical Textbox questions Nominal = all other question types Multiple Choice SPSS assigns a numeric value to answer choices, which you can reference in the Variable View. If multiple answers are allowed, the data will be separated into multiple columns in the Data View since multiple answers cannot exist in one cell. Ranking and Matrix Questions The data is separated into multiple columns (as many columns as you have in your question). SPSS assigns the numeric value by the weighted value, which is not necessarily how you have the answer choices ordered in the survey. This means column one is whatever answer choice was assigned the weight of 1 in the survey, column two is the answer choice with the weight of 2, and so on. The N/A column is coded as 0. If you assigned the weight of 0 to another answer choice, the cell will show .00 and you'll need to manually fix this. Skipped Responses Skipped answers are assigned the value of "." in the Data View. This is defined as a SYSMIS in the export. Skipped answers are assigned the value of "." in the Data View. This is defined as a SYSMIS in the export. title: Viewing Benchmarks in Survey Results
body: Viewing Benchmarks in Survey Results How to Use Benchmarks Showing and Hiding Benchmarks Analyzing Benchmarks Why can't I see benchmarks? Viewing Benchmarks in Survey Results Viewing Benchmarks in Survey Results How to Use Benchmarks Showing and Hiding Benchmarks Analyzing Benchmarks Why can't I see benchmarks? Benchmarks give context to your survey results by allowing you to compare your results to others who used the same Question Bank questions as you. Free Global Benchmarks appear in your survey results if at least one Question Bank question you used has a benchmark. You can also buy more specific Industry Benchmarks to focus on a particular industry. How to Use Benchmarks Creating a Survey To see free Global Benchmarks in your results: Create a benchmarkable survey . Send your survey . Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. You'll see a Benchmarks option in the toolbar. If you haven't completed your profile yet, click Complete Profile at the top of the page. You need to complete your profile before you can view benchmarks. Browse the questions in your survey for the benchmark icon and show benchmarks! TIP! You can see benchmarks even if you haven't collected any survey responses! Just create a survey using benchmarkable questions , then head straight to the Analyze Results section of the survey. Paid Benchmarks You can buy Industry Benchmarks for specific comparison groups to help you narrow down the types of organizations included in a benchmark, like country or industry. On some plans, you get a paid Industry Benchmark for free ! Showing and Hiding Benchmarks You can see benchmarks in the Analyze Results section of any of your surveys in which you used benchmarkable questions . TIP! You can also buy Industry Benchmarks for specific comparison groups to help you narrow down the types of organizations included in a benchmark, like country or industry. Shared Surveys People can see benchmarks on surveys shared by you . Basically, if you can see benchmarks, so can they! Analyzing Benchmarks Chart Types After showing benchmarks, click Chart Type above a benchmarkable question to choose your preferred chart type. A horizontal or vertical bar chart that gives you a side-by-side comparison of your results for each answer choice against the results for each answer choice in the benchmark. A box plot of the weighted average for a particular question against the quartiles of benchmark. A gauge chart specific to the NPS question that compares your NPS against the NPS and quartiles of the benchmark. A skinny donut chart specific to the Top 2 Box Score. A horizontal or vertical bar chart specific to the Top 2 Box Score. After showing benchmarks, click Chart Type above a benchmarkable question to choose your preferred chart type. A horizontal or vertical bar chart that gives you a side-by-side comparison of your results for each answer choice against the results for each answer choice in the benchmark. A box plot of the weighted average for a particular question against the quartiles of benchmark. A gauge chart specific to the NPS question that compares your NPS against the NPS and quartiles of the benchmark. A skinny donut chart specific to the Top 2 Box Score. A horizontal or vertical bar chart specific to the Top 2 Box Score. Using Quartiles to See Where You Stand The box-and-whiskers plot and the gauge chart display quartiles of the benchmark. Knowing which quartiles you fall between allows you to better understand where you stand in comparison to the organizations included in the benchmark. Quartile Description Minimum The lowest score in the benchmark. Lower Quartile 75% of organizations have scores that are higher than this number Median 50% of organizations have scores that are higher than this number Upper Quartile 25% of organizations have scores that are higher than this number Maximum The highest score in the benchmark If your score falls between the lower quartile and the median , it's in the bottom 25-50% of all organizations in the benchmark. If your score falls between the median and the upper quartile , it's in the top 50-75% of all organizations in the benchmark. If your score falls between the upper quartile and the maximum , it's in the top 25% of all organizations in the benchmark. The box-and-whiskers plot and the gauge chart display quartiles of the benchmark. Knowing which quartiles you fall between allows you to better understand where you stand in comparison to the organizations included in the benchmark. If your score falls between the lower quartile and the median , it's in the bottom 25-50% of all organizations in the benchmark. If your score falls between the median and the upper quartile , it's in the top 50-75% of all organizations in the benchmark. If your score falls between the upper quartile and the maximum , it's in the top 25% of all organizations in the benchmark. Top 2 Box Score Top 2 Box Score is the percentage of respondents who selected one of the top two answer options for a question. For any eligible question, you'll see the percentage of your respondents who chose the top two answers compared to the percentage of respondents in the benchmark who chose the top two answers—so you can easily benchmark yourself against leaders in your industry. To use Top 2 Box Score: Show benchmarks. In the upper-right corner of the question, click Chart Type . Choose one of the Top 2 Box Score charts. Click Save . The Top 2 Box Score is only available for benchmarkable, Likert Scale questions, and benchmarks must be turned on to use it. Top 2 Box Score is the percentage of respondents who selected one of the top two answer options for a question. For any eligible question, you'll see the percentage of your respondents who chose the top two answers compared to the percentage of respondents in the benchmark who chose the top two answers—so you can easily benchmark yourself against leaders in your industry. To use Top 2 Box Score: Show benchmarks. In the upper-right corner of the question, click Chart Type . Choose one of the Top 2 Box Score charts. Click Save . The Top 2 Box Score is only available for benchmarkable, Likert Scale questions, and benchmarks must be turned on to use it. Applying a Compare Rule If you add a Compare Rule to your survey results, you can compare different response groups to the benchmark. For example, let's say you want to compare customer feedback about two different store locations. Add a Multiple Choice question to your survey asking respondents to select the store location they visited. Apply a Compare Rule to that question. Browse the benchmarkable questions in your survey—you'll see a side-by-side view of the results from those two stores and the benchmark. If you add a Compare Rule to your survey results, you can compare different response groups to the benchmark. For example, let's say you want to compare customer feedback about two different store locations. Add a Multiple Choice question to your survey asking respondents to select the store location they visited. Apply a Compare Rule to that question. Browse the benchmarkable questions in your survey—you'll see a side-by-side view of the results from those two stores and the benchmark. Exporting Benchmark Data If you have a paid Industry Benchmark, you can export a CSV of raw benchmark data. To export a CSV: Select Benchmarks from the toolbar. Click the three dots to the right of a benchmark in the left sidebar and Download CSV . If you have a paid Industry Benchmark, you can export a CSV of raw benchmark data. To export a CSV: Select Benchmarks from the toolbar. Click the three dots to the right of a benchmark in the left sidebar and Download CSV . Analyze Tools Restrictions When benchmarks are turned on, some analyze features may behave differently: Benchmark data and charts are not included in exports of your survey results, shared data pages, or Data Trends. If you add a Filter rule, only your survey data is filtered—the benchmark data is not filtered. If you save a View with benchmarks turned on, the Filter or Show rules applied are saved as normal. Benchmark visibility is controlled by the button directly above the question chart and is not dependent on the View applied. Hiding all benchmarks allows you full access to your analyze tools. When benchmarks are turned on, some analyze features may behave differently: Benchmark data and charts are not included in exports of your survey results, shared data pages, or Data Trends. If you add a Filter rule, only your survey data is filtered—the benchmark data is not filtered. If you save a View with benchmarks turned on, the Filter or Show rules applied are saved as normal. Benchmark visibility is controlled by the button directly above the question chart and is not dependent on the View applied. Hiding all benchmarks allows you full access to your analyze tools. Why can't I see benchmarks? In the following cases, you might not be able to view benchmarks or you may see a display warning: If you're part of a team , you can view benchmarks on surveys shared with you , as long as the survey owner can view benchmarks (you don't have to complete your profile or opt in). If you're the survey owner, you can't show benchmarks if you've opted out of benchmarks or if you haven't completed your profile. You won't be able to see a benchmark if you changed the question type or edited the number of answer options for the question. You can still see a benchmark if you edited the question text. However, your comparisons might not be valid for benchmarks since your questions may have been interpreted differently by your respondents than by others who saw the questions as they were originally written. To preserve anonymity and to provide accurate comparisons, we have requirements on how much benchmark data we need in order to display benchmarks for a particular question. We're working hard to make sure that we have coverage in all of the questions we offer benchmarking. You can hide the benchmark for that question to see your results instead. title: PPT (PowerPoint) Exports
body: PPT (PowerPoint) Exports Creating the Presentation You Need Template and Branding Limitations PPT (PowerPoint) Exports PPT (PowerPoint) Exports Creating the Presentation You Need Template and Branding Limitations Exports Hide Branding (PPT Exports) You can export your survey results as a presentation file for Microsoft PowerPoint (PPT). PPT exports contain presentation slides of your survey results and include the questions, charts, and data tables you see when analyzing your results. See example exports » To export your survey results as a presentation: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Select Save As at the top of the page. Select Export files . Select the All Summary Data export type. Choose PPT , select your export options, then select Export . To download your export, select Exports in the toolbar, then select the file you want to download. Exports are stored in the Exports menu for 14 days. Creating the Presentation You Need You can choose which data to include in your presentation. You can also edit several charts in your exported presentation. Exporting charts and data tables: You can choose to export the charts, data tables, or both. Editing slides : Make changes to text, colors, charts, or tables after exporting the file. You can edit the charts associated with all question types within the presentation except for the following, which will be exported as images. Matrix of Dropdown Menus question type Net Promoter® Score question type Click Map question type Charts displaying a weighted average Charts with a translation other than English Charts with a Compare rule applied Charts with combined or hidden answer values Matrix of Dropdown Menus question type Net Promoter® Score question type Click Map question type Charts displaying a weighted average Charts with a translation other than English Charts with a Compare rule applied Charts with combined or hidden answer values Template and Branding Hide Branding (PPT Exports) Some paid plans have more options when exporting their presentation. Uploading a custom presentation template : With an Enterprise plan , you can upload a custom presentation template to keep exports uniform and on-brand for your organization. Learn how to add a presentation template . Hiding SurveyMonkey branding : PPT exports include default SurveyMonkey branding in the footer throughout the presentation. You can remove SurveyMonkey branding on some paid plans . Limitations You may need PowerPoint 10 or later to open the PPT file. Pie and donut charts export with a legend rather than data labels, even when the Labels field is set to Labels . The following question types can’t be exported into a presentation. Single textbox Multiple textboxes Comment box Text A/B test Image A/B test File upload Contact information Date/ time Single textbox Multiple textboxes Comment box Text A/B test Image A/B test File upload Contact information Date/ time TIP! To export everything you see in the Question Summaries tab, including A/B Tests and open-ended responses, try the PDF export . title: Thematic Analysis
body: Thematic Analysis Feature Availability and Settings How Your Data is Processed Using Thematic Analysis Thematic Analysis Thematic Analysis Feature Availability and Settings How Your Data is Processed Using Thematic Analysis Beta : Thematic Analysis is a new feature, and we're working hard to improve it. Share your feedback to help us make this feature better! Thematic Analysis automatically groups text responses by key themes, allowing you to: Reduce time spent organizing data into meaningful categories Understand the most common themes across your open-ended responses Feature Availability and Settings Thematic Analysis works with text responses from Comment Box and Single Text Box questions. Limitations Certain survey use cases are not permitted—for details, please see SurveyMonkey's Acceptable Uses Policy , as well as additional third party provider usage policies . Thematic Analysis isn’t available to HIPAA-enabled accounts, or those with an Enhanced Sensitive Data Protection account. Thematic Analysis works for responses created in English only. Thematic Analysis is available to accounts in the US Data Center . How Your Data is Processed When you turn on Thematic Analysis for a survey, the feature uses AI to analyze your responses and identify common themes. Your data remains private and secure during and after use of this feature. Learn more about how this feature processes your data . Using Thematic Analysis You’ll only see the Thematic Analysis option if it’s available on your plan. For Teams and Enterprise accounts, your admin controls whether you have access to this feature. To turn on Thematic Analysis: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Find a question with open text responses. Select the Thematic Analysis tab. Select Generate themes . If this is your first time using Thematic Analysis on the question, you’ll see a confirmation message. Select Continue . We’ll start generating themes based on your open-ended responses. Review the themes we applied to your responses. You can also enable Sentiments to better understand your respondents’ feelings while responding to your survey. Regenerating Themes If you collect more responses, generate themes again to apply them to your new responses. To regenerate themes, select Regenerate themes in the Thematic Analysis tab. You’ll see this option after collecting new open-ended responses. Filtering Responses After we tag your responses, you can view your open-ended responses and filter them by theme in the Thematic Analysis page. To view themed responses and filter by theme: In the Analyze Results section of your survey, find a question with text responses that you applied themes to. Go to the Thematic Analysis tab, then select View details . Check the boxes for the themes you want to display. Exporting Responses with Themes To export responses for your question: In the Analyze Results section of your survey, find a question with text responses that you applied themes to. Go to the Thematic Analysis tab, then select View details . Select Export . We’ll save the export to your device as a .zip file. The export includes the following data: Respondent ID Response date Response text Tags applied Themes applied Response sentiment (if you’ve enabled Sentiment Analysis) Related Articles Company SurveyMonkey About Us Jobs Blog Help SurveyMonkey Help GetFeedback Help Market Research Help SurveyMonkey Audience Help SurveyMonkey Contribute Help Wufoo Help Apply Help Support Site Status Unsubscribe Contact Us Email Opt-In Policies Legal Center Privacy Policy Cookies Notice California Privacy Notice

title: Payment Processing Times
body: Payment Processing Times Payment Processing Times Payment Processing Times Processing Times The time it takes to process your payment depends on the payment method you used. It can also vary by bank and country. You'll need to add the SurveyMonkey invoice number on a check, or wire transfer so we can tie it to your account and get your payment all sorted. These are the average processing times from when you send your payment: Proof of Payment If the average processing time has passed and you're still waiting for your paid features to be turned on in your account, sorry about that! Please send an email on over to our support team with your proof of payment so we can help you track it down. Please include all of the following info in your email (depending on your payment method, of course): Payment cash date (the date funds were withdrawn from and cleared your bank account) Payment amount Payer name Payer reference number The SurveyMonkey bank account number you sent the payment to Your SurveyMonkey invoice number Remitter name or the name on the checking account Check number Amount of the check Address the check was sent to Date the check was cashed Your SurveyMonkey invoice number Payment cash date Payment amount Payer name Payer reference number Related Articles Company SurveyMonkey About Us Jobs Blog Help SurveyMonkey Help GetFeedback Help Market Research Help SurveyMonkey Audience Help SurveyMonkey Contribute Help Wufoo Help Apply Help Support Site Status Unsubscribe Contact Us Email Opt-In Policies Legal Center Privacy Policy Cookies Notice California Privacy Notice

title: Canceling or Deleting Your SurveyMonkey Account
body: Canceling or Deleting Your SurveyMonkey Account Subscription Cancellation Policy Canceling Auto-Renew Special Cancellation Cases Deleting an Account Troubleshooting Tips Refunds Inactive Accounts Canceling or Deleting Your SurveyMonkey Account Canceling or Deleting Your SurveyMonkey Account Subscription Cancellation Policy Canceling Auto-Renew Special Cancellation Cases Deleting an Account Troubleshooting Tips Refunds Inactive Accounts Subscription Cancellation Policy To ensure your access to paid features is never interrupted, paid plans are subscriptions that auto-renew by default. You can cancel auto-renew at any time to downgrade your subscription at the end of your paid time. Canceling auto-renew prevents your payment method from being charged at your next billing date, or if you pay by invoice, prevents your next invoice from being issued. Your current subscription (the time you already paid for) isn't affected, so you'll continue to be able to access and benefit from paid features until the plan downgrades on your next billing date . If you're located in the European Union and upgraded a new account within the past 14 days, you may also want to review our European Union Subscription Cancellation Policy . Canceling Auto-Renew Follow the steps below to cancel your subscription if you have your own plan or if you're the Primary Admin of a team . To cancel auto-renew: Review the below info on Special Cancellation Cases in case they refer to you. Log in to your SurveyMonkey account. Select your Profile circle in the upper-right corner. Select My Account . Select the Billing Details tab. Under the Billing Profile section, go to Auto-renew. Select the link next to the auto-renew setting to cancel auto-renew and follow the steps. Make sure to review the cancellation terms and date your account will downgrade. Switch to Invoicing Pay by Invoice to get an invoice to pay for your renewal instead of being charged automatically on your next billing date. What happens when I downgrade? When your plan downgrades , your plan type changes to Basic (our free plan). If you're canceling a team, all accounts will downgrade and the team will be dissolved. Special Cancellation Cases Outstanding Invoices If you currently have an unpaid invoice, you won't see the option to cancel auto-renew. Please contact us to cancel your account. Sales-Assisted Accounts If you worked with our sales team to set up your account, please contact us to cancel your account. HIPAA-Enabled Accounts If you cancel a HIPAA-enabled account , we'll place your account into a suspended state at the end of your billing cycle. We'll retain the account for the period of time stated in the BAA to provide you with an opportunity to renew it. At the end of the suspension period, we'll close the account and delete all data in it. iOS App Accounts If you purchased a SurveyMonkey plan through the SurveyMonkey mobile app for iOS, billing is managed by Apple instead of SurveyMonkey. You'll need to cancel your subscription on their platform instead of in SurveyMonkey. Deleting an Account Deleting an account is permanent. Once an account is deleted, it can't be restored. You can delete your own account, as long as you're not on a team . When you delete your account or an account in your team, the account is disabled immediately. You won’t be able to log in or access its content, invoices, or payment history. All data will be permanently removed from our system within 90 days. We are currently updating the way you log in to your account . Choose the option below that best applies to you. I log in with the new login process, Google, Facebook, LinkedIn, or Microsoft Log in to your SurveyMonkey account on a desktop or laptop. Select your Profile circle in the upper-right corner and select My Account . Scroll to the bottom of the page and select Permanently delete account . After reviewing the information, select all checkboxes and select Next to request a code to confirm account deletion. Check your email inbox for code. Enter code and select Delete account . Log in to your SurveyMonkey account on a desktop or laptop. Select your Profile circle in the upper-right corner and select My Account . Scroll to the bottom of the page and select Permanently delete account . After reviewing the information, select all checkboxes and select Next to request a code to confirm account deletion. Check your email inbox for code. Enter code and select Delete account . I log in with my username, and have not switched to the new login process Log in to your SurveyMonkey account on a desktop or laptop. Select your Profile circle in the upper-right corner and select My Account. Scroll to the bottom of the page and select Permanently delete account . After reviewing the information, select all checkboxes and enter your password. Select Yes, delete this account to confirm . Log in to your SurveyMonkey account on a desktop or laptop. Select your Profile circle in the upper-right corner and select My Account. Scroll to the bottom of the page and select Permanently delete account . After reviewing the information, select all checkboxes and enter your password. Select Yes, delete this account to confirm . If you're looking to exercise your right to be forgotten or to make a data deletion request under privacy laws, review our request process . Troubleshooting Tips I haven’t changed over to the new login process, and don’t know my password to delete my account If you don't know your password, you’ll need to create a new one before you can delete your account. Log out and reset your password . We’ll send a reset link to the email address on file for the account so you can create a password to use when deleting the account. If you don't know your password, you’ll need to create a new one before you can delete your account. Log out and reset your password . We’ll send a reset link to the email address on file for the account so you can create a password to use when deleting the account. I have multiple accounts using the same email address Accounts can only be canceled or deleted individually. If you have multiple SurveyMonkey accounts with the same email address, canceling or deleting one won't affect the others. If you delete a SurveyMonkey account linked to your Contribute or Rewards account, those will be deleted at the same time. Accounts can only be canceled or deleted individually. If you have multiple SurveyMonkey accounts with the same email address, canceling or deleting one won't affect the others. If you delete a SurveyMonkey account linked to your Contribute or Rewards account, those will be deleted at the same time. I can't select the confirmation button The Yes, Delete This Account button will be disabled until you select all the checkboxes and enter your password. The Yes, Delete This Account button will be disabled until you select all the checkboxes and enter your password. I need to delete my account using the SurveyMonkey app on iOS You can delete your account from your My Account Page on iOS. You can delete your account from your My Account Page on iOS. Refunds We don't automatically refund you for any remaining time when you cancel a subscription or delete an account. In most cases, canceling auto-renew before the end of your subscription means you'll have access to paid features until the end of your subscription term. If you only need a paid plan for a short amount of time, we offer a monthly plan . In accordance with our terms of services , when you cancel your subscription, previous charges won't be refunded unless legally required. Consumers in the European Union have refund rights described in our European Union Subscription Cancellation Policy . If you're located in another region where we're legally required to issue a refund on an early cancellation, or you have any questions about cancellations or refunds, please contact us . If you delete your individual account, you'll lose access to paid time left in your plan. During the deletion process, you're asked to explicitly agree to forfeit the remaining time in your current paid subscription and acknowledge that you won't be refunded for this unused time. If you delete an account on your team, you won't lose access to paid time left for their seat. Instead, their seat becomes available, and you can invite another person to the team at no additional cost . Inactive Accounts If you haven't logged into your free SurveyMonkey or SurveyMonkey Contribute account for more than 3 years we consider the account inactive and it will be permanently deleted. Log in to your account to maintain access—you may need to reset your password after a long period of inactivity.
