title: SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Web Link Encryption
body: SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Web Link Encryption Before you Start Map Your Survey to Salesforce Create a Salesforce Web Link Collector Turn on Encryption and Copy Link Get an Encryption Key Set up Encryption in Salesforce Send your Survey SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Web Link Encryption SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Web Link Encryption Before you Start Map Your Survey to Salesforce Create a Salesforce Web Link Collector Turn on Encryption and Copy Link Get an Encryption Key Set up Encryption in Salesforce Send your Survey Get the integration! SurveyMonkey for Salesforce is an Enterprise add-on. Contact Sales or your Customer Success Manager (CSM). The integration setup is only available in English. If you’re sending a web link from the Salesforce integration , you can encrypt custom variables. Encryption protects user data by preventing respondents from seeing or editing the custom variables in your web link. Need more help with the Salesforce integration? Check out our Getting Started guide >> There are a few steps you need to take to set up encryption: Map your survey to Salesforce Create a web link collector in the Salesforce integration Turn on encryption Get an encryption key from your Primary Admin (this may be you) Set up encryption in Salesforce (we’ll provide instructions below) Send your survey Read these instructions to get started. Work with a Salesforce administrator to complete these steps, if possible - you may need to build custom code for your environment. SurveyMonkey’s support team can’t consult on coding issues in Salesforce. Before you Start Reach out to your Customer Success Manager to get the Encryption feature enabled. You’ll only need to get it enabled once. Map Your Survey to Salesforce Create your survey mappings. You can use our managed package or create your own mappings to standard and custom Salesforce objects. Learn how >> Create a Salesforce Web Link Collector Create a web link collector in the Salesforce integration. Make sure to add any custom variables you’d like to collect from your respondents. Learn how >> Turn on Encryption and Copy Link Once you’ve created your web link, toggle on the option to Encrypt custom variables . We’ll show you an encrypted version of your survey link to send. However, this link won’t work until you set up encryption in Salesforce. You’ll see instructions to set up encryption and a code sample. Copy this code sample to use later. You can always come back to this page and copy it later. Get an Encryption Key from your Primary Admin Ask your Primary Admin to create an encryption key and provide it to you. To generate an encryption key: As a Primary Admin, go to the header and select My Team > Settings . Select Encryption key for Salesforce at the bottom of the page (you may need to scroll). Select Generate key . Copy the key and provide it to the person setting up encryption in Salesforce. They’ll add this key to the encryption code in Salesforce. Make sure to store the key somewhere safe – we won’t show it again once you leave the encryption key page. If you lose this key, the Primary Admin can generate a new one later. Set up Encryption in Salesforce To set up encryption in Salesforce: From the web link collector page in the Salesforce integration, copy the code sample. This is the encryption code you’ll use in Salesforce. In Salesforce, create a custom field called SM_CV_ENCRYPTED_Data on the object that triggers your survey. For example, if your survey is sent when a Case is closed, place this custom field on the Case object. Make sure your encryption code references and places encrypted values in this field. In Salesforce , create an apex trigger that encrypts your custom variables when the event that triggers your survey occurs (for example, if your survey is sent when a Case is closed, make sure your trigger encrypts custom variables when this event happens). Or, paste the code sample from the Salesforce integration page and replace SM_ENCRYPTION_KEY with the encryption key your Primary Admin provided. IMPORTANT! If you want to use the code sample we provide, read the information on using the code below. Considerations For Using Sample Code We provide sample code for this trigger when you turn on encryption. However, there are a few things to keep in mind when using this code: Make sure to review the trigger and update it for your environment as needed. For example, you may want to update the trigger for the survey. This code only references the object you map your survey to (for example, if you map your survey to the Case object and then add mappings to the Account object, the sample code will only reference the Case object). If you map your survey to multiple objects, you’ll need to write custom code or update the sample to meet your needs. This code places encrypted data in the SM_CV_ENCRYPTED_Data field on your object. If you don’t have a field with this name on your object, the code won’t work. Send your Survey Set up any automations you need to send your survey link. If you’re sending this link from Salesforce, you’ll want to create an email template with your link, set up an email alert, and create a flow to send your survey. Learn how >> Related Articles Company SurveyMonkey About Us Jobs Blog Help SurveyMonkey Help GetFeedback Help Market Research Help SurveyMonkey Audience Help SurveyMonkey Contribute Help Wufoo Help Apply Help Support Site Status Unsubscribe Contact Us Email Opt-In Policies Legal Center Privacy Policy Cookies Notice California Privacy Notice

title: Zoom Integration
body: Zoom Integration Connecting your SurveyMonkey Account Creating and Sending a Survey During a Zoom Meeting What Attendees See Zoom Integration Zoom Integration Connecting your SurveyMonkey Account Creating and Sending a Survey During a Zoom Meeting What Attendees See Enterprise feature: If you're interested in an Enterprise plan, contact sales . Limitations : This integration is available for US Data Center accounts only, set up is only available in English, and the integration can't be used with Zoom webinars. SurveyMonkey's Zoom integration lets you get real-time input from people attending your Zoom meeting. You can create a new survey or use a pre-existing survey from your SurveyMonkey account directly in a Zoom meeting to capture feedback. You can share the results during the meeting or review them later in your SurveyMonkey account. Jump to... Connecting your SurveyMonkey Account Creating or Sharing a Survey During a Zoom Meeting What Attendees See Connecting your SurveyMonkey Account To get the integration and connect your SurveyMonkey account: Open up Zoom and start a meeting. Click Apps at the bottom of your meeting. Search for the SurveyMonkey integration and click Connect . Follow the prompts to login to your SurveyMonkey account. This account is where your response data and surveys from the app will be stored. Go back to the Zoom meeting and click Complete to finish the login process. TIP! Zoom has different access requirements for apps depending on settings in your Zoom account. Learn more Disconnecting and Uninstalling the App To disconnect your SurveyMonkey account, open the SurveyMonkey app while in a Zoom meeting and click your username in the upper right corner, and click Disconnect . You'll be able to reconnect that SurveyMonkey account, or connect to a different one anytime. To uninstall the SurveyMonkey app entirely, go to the My Apps page of the SurveyMonkey App directory and click Remove next to the Zoom app. Creating and Sending a Survey During a Zoom Meeting Only the meeting organizer can create and send surveys during the meeting. Choose to create a new survey or share a pre-existing survey from your SurveyMonkey account. If you create a survey in Zoom, you are limited to only certain question types. To use all question types and logic options, or to edit an existing survey, create or edit the survey in your SurveyMonkey account before your meeting. To create or choose a survey, and share it in Zoom: Start a Zoom meeting, click the Apps icon at the bottom of the meeting screen, and open the SurveyMonkey app in the side panel. Choose an existing survey from your surveys list or click +New to create a new survey. If you create a new survey, choose to: Start from scratch: Select the question type you want to use, then write your questions and answer choices. When making a survey with multiple questions, click Add more questions . From Template: Choose a pre-written survey template. Start from scratch: Select the question type you want to use, then write your questions and answer choices. When making a survey with multiple questions, click Add more questions . From Template: Choose a pre-written survey template. Click Set options . You can make the survey anonymous, set a time limit, or automatically share results with attendees. Click Share survey at the bottom of the page. Once the host shares the survey in the Zoom meeting, all participants are notified to install or open the app to take the survey. Attendees are able to take the survey in the meeting. Depending on the options you set, the survey closes automatically after the timer counts down or the meeting organizer can close it manually at any time. Click Share to share the results with the attendees or Done if you want results to be private. You can resend a survey you created in a past Zoom meeting, however you aren’t able to edit any of the questions or answer choices. If you choose to share results from a survey that has responses from a previous meeting, only results from this meeting are displayed to attendees. When sharing results in Zoom, some question types don’t display, but you can click on the View full results at SurveyMonkey link. The meeting organizer can view results from all previous meetings combined in your SurveyMonkey account on the survey's Analyze Results page. Each time you share the survey in a meeting, a new collector is created. To see each meeting's results separately, set up a filter by collector . Available Question Types You can use the following question types for your survey or poll: Checkboxes Comment Box Dropdown Menu Multiple Choice Single Text Box Slider Star Rating You can use the following question types for your survey or poll: Checkboxes Comment Box Dropdown Menu Multiple Choice Single Text Box Slider Star Rating What Attendees See Meeting attendees don’t need to have a SurveyMonkey account or be logged in to Zoom to take a survey or view results. During the meeting, the organizer shares an invite to install the SurveyMonkey app. This also notifies attendees to open the SurveyMonkey app and take the survey. The survey opens in a panel on the right side of their Zoom meeting screen. If the survey isn't shared yet, attendees see a message to wait for the organizer to share the survey. After attendees submit their response, a thank you message appears. If the organizer shares the results, the screen will refresh to display the results. title: Post Responses Automatically in Microsoft Teams
body: Post Responses Automatically in Microsoft Teams Post Responses Automatically in Microsoft Teams Post Responses Automatically in Microsoft Teams Connect your SurveyMonkey account with Microsoft Teams so you can automatically post survey responses in a Microsoft Teams public channel or chat, in real time. You can set up the workflow so all responses post to Microsoft Teams or set conditions based on a specific set of responses to target notifications and encourage the right people to take action. Connecting SurveyMonkey to Microsoft Teams is helpful for initiating action to follow up with customers or employees to improve trends based on their responses to your survey, or to share feedback to offer transparency to your team or just to the right people. Automating responses in Microsoft Teams is only possible for Complete responses . Connecting SurveyMonkey and Microsoft Teams to share responses You can set up automations so survey responses post in Microsoft Teams. To set up your survey to send Microsoft Teams messages with your survey responses: Select a survey from Home . From the Connect Apps tab, locate Microsoft Teams under the Discover tab. Select a quick action, Post to channel or Post to chat . Select Connect to link your SurveyMonkey account to Microsoft Teams, if this is the first time you’re connecting.. Select Allow to give SurveyMonkey access to your Microsoft Teams workspace. Select Allow to give SurveyMonkey access to your Microsoft Teams workspace. Search for the Microsoft Teams Team or Chat you want to reach. Search for the Microsoft Teams Channel you want to post to. Enter an Optional Message to send along with the response in Microsoft Teams to provide context. Toggle whether to Link to response on SurveyMonkey.com. (Optional) To Include survey data , select the + and select + Add more data to add up to 5 selections. Once all relevant data is selected, select Apply. (Optional) By default, all new responses will be shared in Microsoft Teams. If you want to Target specific responses , select + , then Add filter to set up your filter criteria. Select a question to base your filter on. Select the criteria for the responses you want to target. Update the response options to include in your filter. Select Add . To add additional filters, select + Add new filter and repeat steps 1-4. Select Apply . Select a question to base your filter on. Select the criteria for the responses you want to target. Update the response options to include in your filter. Select Add . To add additional filters, select + Add new filter and repeat steps 1-4. Select Apply . Select Activate . An overview of all Microsoft Teams quick actions you set up are available in the Manage tab, within Connect Apps. You can select the toggle to disable or enable an automation. Or, you can select … to Edit action , Manage connection , or Delete an automation. TIP! Feel free to create multiple workflows to deliver to various channels or use filters to customize the information getting sent to Microsoft Teams. Condition Limitations When you add a filter to a quick action, most questions are available to filter by, except: Date/Time Click map Text Image File upload Text A/B Image A/B Accepting payments via Stripe or PayPal When you add a filter to a quick action, most questions are available to filter by, except: Date/Time Click map Text Image File upload Text A/B Image A/B Accepting payments via Stripe or PayPal Automated Responses in Microsoft Teams Any new responses matching your targeting criteria post to your channels or chats, in real time. The message you set up displays and may have a link to view the individual response, which opens a Shared data page in a new tab. Manage Your Microsoft Teams Connections You can view and manage your connected apps and actions from the Manage tab, under Connect Apps. You can select Manage connections to either Reauthenticate , which refreshes your existing connection, or fully uninstall the Microsoft Teams app by selecting Delete . You can also select the toggle to turn an action on or off, or click the … to Edit action or Delete it permanently. title: Sending Surveys via Mailchimp
body: Sending Surveys via Mailchimp Sending Surveys via Mailchimp Sending Surveys via Mailchimp Mailchimp and SurveyMonkey combined forces to provide more ways for you to email surveys to your friends, customers, employees, fans, and more. You can design a survey in SurveyMonkey and then distribute it through a SurveyMonkey email template in Mailchimp. When you send your survey with Mailchimp you are sending out a Web Link Collector . By default, this collector is set to allow respondents take your survey once per computer . Get Started! Visit the Mailchimp help center to setup the integration in your Mailchimp account. Response Tracking and Analysis The survey responses you collected with the Mailchimp integration can only be viewed in your SurveyMonkey account. SurveyMonkey doesn't automatically record the email address associated with the Mailchimp list that distributed the survey. Survey responses will be anonymous unless you can add a question to the survey to collect identifying information . From the Reports section in your Mailchimp account, you can view SurveyMonkey Stats to see who received, started, or completed the survey. If you want to view someone's survey response, you can click through to SurveyMonkey. To access an individual response in SurveyMonkey from Mailchimp: From your Campaigns list, click View Report for a SurveyMonkey campaign. Click the Analytics 360 tab and scroll to SurveyMonkey Stats . You may need to authorize this feature to begin collecting data. Click View response next to the email address of the response you want to view and you'll be taken to the response in SurveyMonkey. Please note, it can take at least three hours from the time you sent your Mailchimp campaign to begin collecting data. In addition, you can send follow-up emails in Mailchimp: to those that have not started to those that have started but did not finish TIP! Visit the Mailchimp help center for more on survey reporting features and integration support. title: SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Creating Reports and Dashboards
body: SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Creating Reports and Dashboards Using Salesforce Dashboards Using SurveyMonkey Views and Dashboards SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Creating Reports and Dashboards SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Creating Reports and Dashboards Using Salesforce Dashboards Using SurveyMonkey Views and Dashboards Get the integration ! SurveyMonkey for Salesforce is an Enterprise add-on. Contact Sales or your Customer Success Manager (CSM). Limitation: The integration setup is available in English only. If you use our SurveyMonkey for Salesforce integration, you can use your survey data to report on trends in Salesforce. Learn more about the SurveyMonkey for Salesforce integration . Once you've mapped your survey to Salesforce , you can build custom reports and dashboards for the responses you’ve captured in Salesforce. Using Salesforce Dashboards There are many ways to report on survey response data within Salesforce. Once you’ve created reports, you can create Salesforce Dashboards based on those reports. You can edit, delete, and add new Reports and Dashboards within Salesforce as needed. Example : You want to create a dashboard for case closed surveys. You may want to plot a dashboard by agent, ticket type, and case reason. This can help you analyze NPS and CSAT scores across different variables in Salesforce. Applying Formulas to Data You can also use formula fields to categorize your data in reports. For example, if you map Net Promoter® Score (NPS) to Salesforce, you can create a formula to categorize scores as promoter, passive, or detractor. To do this: Add a formula field to the object you map NPS data to. Create a formula that categorizes the NPS scores: Score of 9 or 10 is categorized as Promoter Score of 7 or 8 is categorized as Passive Score of 6 or less is categorized as Detractor Score of 9 or 10 is categorized as Promoter Score of 7 or 8 is categorized as Passive Score of 6 or less is categorized as Detractor Learn more about tracking NPS in Salesforce . Or, use our sample formula to group NPS responses. The custom formula field on your object will translate the numerical score into a NPS category. You can then use the NPS data to create custom reports or dashboards that group responses by Promoter, Detractor, or Passive categories. SurveyMonkey Support can’t consult on coding issues. Reach out to your Salesforce administrator for help implementing these features. These examples help you get started with our Salesforce integration and you may need to make changes for your organization Learn more : Measuring Net Promoter® Score with the Salesforce Integration Measuring Customer Satisfaction (CSAT) with the Salesforce Integration Using SurveyMonkey Views and Dashboards There are a few ways to analyze and share your results in SurveyMonkey: Use filters and compare rules to drill into your data and understand how different variables affected your survey results. Create views that keep your filters and compare rules applied/ For example, you can filter a case closed survey by different locales, then save views for each locale. Set up custom dashboards to share results with stakeholders. Customize the charts on your dashboard to share the most useful data with your colleagues. Example : Based on an age demographic question, you want to view how survey takers age 25+ impacted the results. Use compare rules to show the difference between 2 age groups. The charts will be split into each of those 2 age groups, so you can see how anyone over the age of 25 impacted the survey compared to anyone below the age of 25, all in one nice view Related Articles Company SurveyMonkey About Us Jobs Blog Help SurveyMonkey Help GetFeedback Help Market Research Help SurveyMonkey Audience Help SurveyMonkey Contribute Help Wufoo Help Apply Help Support Site Status Unsubscribe Contact Us Email Opt-In Policies Legal Center Privacy Policy Cookies Notice California Privacy Notice

title: Microsoft Power BI Integration
body: Microsoft Power BI Integration Video Overview Connecting SurveyMonkey and Power BI Common Questions Microsoft Power BI Integration Microsoft Power BI Integration Video Overview Connecting SurveyMonkey and Power BI Common Questions SurveyMonkey's Microsoft Power BI integration lets you connect SurveyMonkey response data to Power BI Desktop. Power BI lets you create data models, visually display your data with charts and graphs, and create reports. To access all the latest features and reduce the risk of issues with existing reports generated in Power BI Desktop, download the latest version . Get the integration! The Microsoft Power BI integration is available as an Enterprise add-on. Contact sales » The integration setup is only available in English. Video Overview Connecting SurveyMonkey and Power BI To push SurveyMonkey response data to Power BI Desktop: Log in to your SurveyMonkey account. Go to the SurveyMonkey App Directory and download the Microsoft Power BI integration. Click Authorize to let Power BI import SurveyMonkey data. Click Authorize again. Copy the Access Token . Open Power BI Desktop. From the Home tab, click Get Data and select More . Search for SurveyMonkey and click Connect . Paste the Access Token from step 4 and click OK . Click Connect . Select the surveys you want to push survey data to Power BI and click Load . Check out the Power BI Documentation for more info on how to use Power BI. TIP! You can share reports and collaborate using Power BI Service. Common Questions IMPORTANT: At this time, only Power Users on an Enterprise plan can access the Microsoft Power BI integration. Are question numbers included in responses pulled into Microsoft's Power BI app? At this time, question numbers don’t display in XLS exports of Individual Responses or for responses pulled into Microsoft’s Power BI app. At this time, question numbers don’t display in XLS exports of Individual Responses or for responses pulled into Microsoft’s Power BI app. How do I refresh my data set in Microsoft Power BI? The SurveyMonkey Power BI integration is only supported for Power BI Desktop on a Windows PC. You can manually refresh data in Power BI Desktop by selecting Refresh on the Home ribbon. To schedule recurring refreshes, publish your data from Power BI Desktop to PowerBI.com. Get Your Access Token for the SurveyMonkey Power BI Integration To find your SurveyMonkey access token: Go to My Apps from the SurveyMonkey App Directory. Search for Microsoft Power BI in the App Directory. Click Visit Site and then Authorize . Your access token appears on the screen. Copy the access token for step four in the Refreshing Your Dataset instructions below. Refreshing Your Dataset Before refreshing your data, use the steps above to get your access token. To refresh your dataset: Log into PowerBI.com after your data set is published from Power BI Desktop. Use the same credentials from Power BI Desktop. Go to Datasets under My workspace Click ... next to the dataset you want to refresh. Select Schedule refresh . Under Data source credentials , enter your SurveyMonkey access token in the Account key field. If your credentials are invalid, click Edit credentials . Once your credentials are accepted, click Scheduled refresh . Select the frequency and time zone then click Apply . TIP! Repeat these steps for each data set you want to refresh. The SurveyMonkey Power BI integration is only supported for Power BI Desktop on a Windows PC. You can manually refresh data in Power BI Desktop by selecting Refresh on the Home ribbon. To schedule recurring refreshes, publish your data from Power BI Desktop to PowerBI.com. Get Your Access Token for the SurveyMonkey Power BI Integration To find your SurveyMonkey access token: Go to My Apps from the SurveyMonkey App Directory. Search for Microsoft Power BI in the App Directory. Click Visit Site and then Authorize . Your access token appears on the screen. Copy the access token for step four in the Refreshing Your Dataset instructions below. Refreshing Your Dataset Before refreshing your data, use the steps above to get your access token. To refresh your dataset: Log into PowerBI.com after your data set is published from Power BI Desktop. Use the same credentials from Power BI Desktop. Go to Datasets under My workspace Click ... next to the dataset you want to refresh. Select Schedule refresh . Under Data source credentials , enter your SurveyMonkey access token in the Account key field. If your credentials are invalid, click Edit credentials . Once your credentials are accepted, click Scheduled refresh . Select the frequency and time zone then click Apply . TIP! Repeat these steps for each data set you want to refresh. title: SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Measuring Net Promoter® Score
body: SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Measuring Net Promoter® Score Creating a Survey Object in Salesforce Grouping NPS Responses Totaling NPS Scores Creating a Custom Report Type for NPS Scores Calculating NPS Scores Mapping NPS Scores from SurveyMonkey to Salesforce SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Measuring Net Promoter® Score SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Measuring Net Promoter® Score Creating a Survey Object in Salesforce Grouping NPS Responses Totaling NPS Scores Creating a Custom Report Type for NPS Scores Calculating NPS Scores Mapping NPS Scores from SurveyMonkey to Salesforce Get the integration ! SurveyMonkey for Salesforce is an Enterprise add-on. Contact Sales or your Customer Success Manager (CSM). Limitation: The integration setup is only available in English. If you use our Salesforce integration, you can create Net Promoter® Score (NPS) surveys and map the survey responses directly into Salesforce. You can use Salesforce reporting to calculate NPS and create dashboards to display key customer feedback. Learn more about the SurveyMonkey for Salesforce integration . This article walks you through the following steps to set up NPS reporting in Salesforce: Create a custom Salesforce object, or add fields to your existing one Add a formula to group NPS responses Total the NPS scores Create a custom NPS report type Calculate NPS scores using your report and a summary formula This is just one way to set up NPS tracking in Salesforce – your NPS program should be customized to fit your organization’s needs. SurveyMonkey can’t consult on coding issues in your Salesforce environment. Reach out to your Salesforce administrator for help implementing these features. These examples help you get started with our Salesforce integration, and you may need to make changes for your organization. Creating a Survey Object in Salesforce If you don’t already have a custom response object, create a new custom object in Salesforce. In this case, we've named our object NPS Responses. Or, you can use the same object you already use for survey responses. Your custom response object should contain the following fields: Survey Name (Text) Contact (Lookup relationship – Contact) Email (Email) Net Promoter Score (Number) Comments (Long Text) NPS Response URL (Text, URL) NPS Grouping (Formula, result: Text) Promoter (Formula, result: Number) Passive (Formula, result: Number) Detractor (Formula, result: Number) Grouping NPS Responses On your custom object, add a formula field for NPS Grouping. NPS Grouping is a formula that categorizes survey takers as Promoters (9 & 10), Passives (7 & 8), or Detractors (6 & below) based on their Net Promoter Score. You can decide to display images or text in this field. For example, you can use stars, hearts, or other icons to help people quickly identify scores. Use one of the formulas below to use NPS Grouping on your object. NPS Grouping with Images Use this formula in your field to add images to each NPS grouping. You can replace the file path (for example, "/servlet/servlet.FileDownload?file=015o0000001blTH") with a different image. NPS Grouping without Images Use this formula to group NPS scores without using images. Totaling NPS Scores Add the Promoter, Passive, and Detractor fields to total the number of responses you’ve received for each NPS grouping. You need these grouping totals to calculate NPS in Salesforce. These fields don’t need to be visible on the page layout to add their totals together. Use these formulas to total the number of responses for each group: Promoter : IF(Net_Promoter_Score__c > 8, 1, 0) Passive : IF(AND(Net_Promoter_Score__c > 6, Net_Promoter_Score__c < 9), 1, 0) Detractor : IF(Net_Promoter_Score__c < 7, 1, 0) Creating a Custom Report Type for NPS Scores Create a custom report type in Salesforce for your NPS object. You’ll use this report to calculate your NPS score. Calculating NPS Scores To calculate NPS scores in Salesforce: Create a new Salesforce summary report using your NPS report type. You can choose to summarize NPS by Survey Name, or filter the report to only show specific Surveys. Write a summary formula in your report to calculate your score. The formula below is an example of an NPS calculation formula. Make sure to update the formula with the correct object name and field names based on how it’s been set up in your environment. We recommend selecting Grand Total Only when applying the formula. NPS Calculation Formula Mapping NPS Scores from SurveyMonkey to Salesforce Now that your Salesforce environment is ready, you can map your NPS survey into Salesforce. In SurveyMonkey, open the Salesforce integration , then map your response data to the corresponding Salesforce fields. For example, you can map the survey name, NPS score, and any comments to your custom Salesforce fields. When you've finished setting up mappings, you can start collecting responses. title: SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Lightning Flows and Components
body: SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Lightning Flows and Components Set up Lightning Flows Send Surveys via SurveyMonkey Lightning Component Take or Send Surveys via Lightning Flow SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Lightning Flows and Components SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Lightning Flows and Components Set up Lightning Flows Send Surveys via SurveyMonkey Lightning Component Take or Send Surveys via Lightning Flow Get the integration! SurveyMonkey for Salesforce is an Enterprise add-on. You need to have the Salesforce integration to use Lightning Flows. Contact Sales or your Customer Success Manager (CSM). Limitations : Lightning Flows and Components aren't available to customers storing data in the EU data center and the integration setup is only available in English. If you use our Salesforce integration and use Salesforce Lightning Experience, you have access to our Lightning flows and Lightning Components. The Lightning flow lets Salesforce users take or send in-the-moment surveys directly from Account, Contact, or Lead objects. Salesforce users can take a survey within Salesforce, for example, to provide feedback that a customer gave a rep over the phone. The SurveyMonkey Lightning Component lets Salesforce users send a survey to one or more Contacts off the Case or Contact objects, or to a Lead off any other object. A common use case is to send ad-hoc surveys to Contacts in Salesforce related to an Case. The Survey Response Visualization Lightning component lets you see the responses from the survey that were completed via the component or flow. Response data is stored in SurveyMonkey Response records, which are related to the object the survey was sent from. Set up Lightning Flows Use the SurveyMonkey Setup Assistant from the App menu to set up your System Connections and create and manage survey sets for Lightning Flows. Users need permission to set up Lightning pages and Lightning setup—contact your Salesforce administrator if you need assistance. To set up your System Connections and Lightning Flow Management: In Salesforce, click the App Launcher icon. Click SurveyMonkey Setup . In the Setup Assistant , click Get Started next to System Connections . Click Authorize and follow the instructions to set up a connection to Salesforce. Click Next . Click Authorize and check the Create or edit survey responses in your account checkbox. Follow the instructions to establish a connection to SurveyMonkey. Click Next . Your System connection is now complete. Select Continue . Click + Add Survey Set to create a new survey set (you may need to refresh the page to see your surveys). If you want to edit a Survey set, click the (pen) Edit icon. Create a Survey Set Name . Select the Objects to Map —Contact, Lead, or Case. Select surveys from All Available Surveys , click > the arrow to move them to the Surveys In This Set field. You’ll need to update your survey set if you add additional surveys. Click Create Set . Send Surveys via SurveyMonkey Lightning Component Sending the survey from the component creates a new email invitation collector to send the survey and it uses default SurveyMonkey branding. To add the component: Go to a record for the object you want to add the SurveyMonkey flow to send or take surveys. Click Setup (the gear icon). Click Edit Page . Scroll down to the Custom—Managed Components section. Drag and drop the SurveyMonkey and/or Survey Response Visualization components where you want them on the page layout. Click Save . You may have to click Activate if you don’t see the component on the page. Take or Send Surveys via Lightning Flow To add the flow: Go to a record for the object you want to add the SurveyMonkey flow to send or take surveys. Click Setup (the gear icon). Click Edit Page . Scroll up to the Standard section. Drag and drop Flow onto the page to open the right side option. Click on the default option to display the dropdown. Select surveyMonkeyFlow . Check Pass Record ID into the Variable checkbox. Select Save . title: Using Zapier with SurveyMonkey
body: Using Zapier with SurveyMonkey Using Zapier with SurveyMonkey Using Zapier with SurveyMonkey The Zapier integration is available to customers on any data center. Zapier allows you to integrate SurveyMonkey with hundreds of other apps to automate tasks in your workflow. You can use SurveyMonkey triggers, actions, and searches to: Trigger each time a new complete survey response comes in Trigger when your survey gets a certain kind of answer Set up an action that sends a survey Set up an action that adds a contact to your SurveyMonkey contact list TIP! You can also set up instant or smart notifications in SurveyMonkey to customize how you get notified about new survey responses. Below are some popular ways to use SurveyMonkey with Zapier. Get Email Notifications for Every Complete Response You can use Zapier to trigger a custom email for each and every new complete response . This zap offers lots of opportunity for customization: Insert answer text from SurveyMonkey into the subject and body of the email. Send notifications to multiple email addresses. Only trigger a notification when a response meets certain criteria. Only trigger a notification when a certain collector receives a new response. You can choose to send emails from a zapiermail.com address, connect your Gmail account, or connect your email account using SMTP. Use this zap » You can use Zapier to trigger a custom email for each and every new complete response . title: SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Measuring Customer Satisfaction (CSAT)
body: SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Measuring Customer Satisfaction (CSAT) Create a CSAT Survey Create a Survey Object in Salesforce Set Up Mappings Send Your Survey Create Salesforce Reports and Group Responses SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Measuring Customer Satisfaction (CSAT) SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Measuring Customer Satisfaction (CSAT) Create a CSAT Survey Create a Survey Object in Salesforce Set Up Mappings Send Your Survey Create Salesforce Reports and Group Responses Get the integration ! SurveyMonkey for Salesforce is an Enterprise add-on. Contact Sales or your Customer Success Manager (CSM). Limitation: The integration setup is only available in English. If you use our Salesforce integration, you can measure customer satisfaction (CSAT) score and report on the results in Salesforce. Learn more about the SurveyMonkey for Salesforce integration . CSAT helps you understand a customer’s experience with a specific interaction or transaction, such as contacting support or making a purchase. You can use CSAT with other metrics to understand the full customer experience with your brand. The CSAT question looks like the example below: Overall, how would you rate your satisfaction with our company? Very Satisfied Somewhat Satisfied Neither Satisfied Nor Dissatisfied Somewhat Dissatisfied Very Dissatisfied This guide helps you calculate and report your CSAT scores in Salesforce. Use these formulas to calculate the CSAT score from your surveys and build reports and dashboards in Salesforce. Calculating CSAT Scores Calculate CSAT as a percentage of satisfied responses (people who selected 4 or 5). Satisfied scores are a more accurate predictor of customer retention. To calculate CSAT score: Take the number of respondents who answered 4 and 5. Divide that number by the total number of survey responses. Multiply by 100 to see the percentage of satisfied customers. The formula for CSAT scores looks like this: (Number of satisfied customers (4 and 5) / Number of survey responses) x 100 = % of satisfied customers Example : 500 people responded to a CSAT survey. 68 were Very Satisfied (score 5), and 74 were Somewhat Satisfied (score 4). Add the number of Satisfied and Somewhat Satisfied responses to get 142. Divide 142 by the total number of responses (500). You get .284 . Multiply .284 by 100 to get 28.4%. This is your CSAT score. The equation would look like this: (142 / 500) x 100 = 28.4% Measuring CSAT with Salesforce You can track CSAT scores in Salesforce to include them in dashboards and reports. There are a few steps to complete to set up CSAT in Salesforce: Create your CSAT survey. (Optional) Create a survey object in Salesforce. Map your survey to the survey object. Send your survey to start collecting responses. Create a CSAT report in Salesforce with a summary formula. Create a CSAT Survey Create a survey with a 5-point scale question. There are 2 ways to build this question: Use a Matrix/Rating Scale question type, and select the checkbox to Make this a single-row rating scale . This will add weights to each answer option. Use a Multiple Choice question type and enable scoring. Your question should include the following answer choices: Very Satisfied (score = 5) Somewhat Satisfied (score = 4) Neither Satisfied Nor Dissatisfied (score = 3) Somewhat Dissatisfied (score = 2) Very Dissatisfied (score = 1) You can also use a CSAT survey template to quickly build a CSAT survey. (optional) Create a Survey Object in Salesforce Create a custom object to hold CSAT responses from your survey. You’ll map survey responses to this object using the Salesforce integration. If you already have a survey object, make sure you have fields to hold your CSAT score (ex: 5) and the label (ex: Very Satisfied). When creating your survey object: Include a field for every survey question/answer you want to map to Salesforce. Use our field mapping guide to understand which field types you need to include on your object. Include a field for each custom variable in your survey. Set Up Mappings In the SurveyMonkey Salesforce integration, map your survey to your survey object in Salesforce. Use our field mapping guide to understand which field types you can map responses to. Send Your Survey When you finish creating mappings, send your survey using the methods available in the Salesforce integration. You can either: Create a weblink to send any way you want. Send an email from SurveyMonkey using a Salesforce outbound message. When someone takes your survey, their responses will be mapped to Salesforce. You can then create reports and dashboards to track CSAT in Salesforce. Create Salesforce Reports and Group Responses In SurveyMonkey, you can always view your responses in the Analyze Results section of your survey. Review question summaries, track data trends over time, or drill into individual responses . However, if you create reports in Salesforce, you can group customers by CSAT score. You can use this data to quickly find unsatisfied customers. SurveyMonkey can’t consult on coding issues in your Salesforce environment. Reach out to your Salesforce administrator for help implementing these formulas. These examples help you get started with our Salesforce integration, and you may need to make changes for your organization. To report on CSAT scores in Salesforce: Create a custom report type in Salesforce for your survey object. You’ll use this report to calculate your CSAT score. Create a new Salesforce summary report using your new report type. You can choose to summarize CSAT by Survey Name, or filter the report to only show specific Surveys. Write a summary formula in your report to calculate your score. The formula below is an example of a CSAT calculation formula. Make sure to update the formula with the correct object name and field names based on how it’s been set up in your environment. We recommend selecting Grand Total Only when applying the formula. Your survey respondents will be grouped by score on the report. Summary Formula Related Articles Company SurveyMonkey About Us Jobs Blog Help SurveyMonkey Help GetFeedback Help Market Research Help SurveyMonkey Audience Help SurveyMonkey Contribute Help Wufoo Help Apply Help Support Site Status Unsubscribe Contact Us Email Opt-In Policies Legal Center Privacy Policy Cookies Notice California Privacy Notice

title: Automate with Quick Actions in Connect
body: Automate with Quick Actions in Connect Quick Actions What’s the difference between apps with quick actions and integrations? Navigating the Connect Apps tab Manage your Quick Actions Automate with Quick Actions in Connect Automate with Quick Actions in Connect Quick Actions What’s the difference between apps with quick actions and integrations? Navigating the Connect Apps tab Manage your Quick Actions The Connect apps section of your survey is the place to connect your survey data to your business apps to automate data sharing, collaborate smarter, and save time. Automating with quick actions helps to improve information sharing, iterate on survey feedback, and save time. Quick Actions Quick actions are simple automations that connect SurveyMonkey responses to popular business apps, like: Post notifications to Slack or Microsoft Teams to share targeted data with the right people, as responses roll in. Posting to these apps can help surface new ideas, channel feedback, or escalate something so teams can take action faster. Export responses to Excel or Google Sheets to share in-the-moment data with your team, which you can merge with other key data for deeper insights. Data selection and filtering When setting up quick actions, you can choose whether to act on all response data or target responses when a respondent selects a specific answer. Targeting the response data helps you channel the right survey data to the right people, making your quick action more relevant, usable, and efficient. What’s the difference between apps with quick actions and integrations? You can find all apps with quick actions in Connect apps , along with some integrations. The lightweight quick actions let you easily automate useful tasks, like creating notifications for visibility, further analysis, or prompt follow-up action. Setting up quick actions could improve your team’s collaboration and amplify your impact, all within SurveyMonkey. Only some integrations are accessible from Connect apps, but all integrations are available in the SurveyMonkey App Directory . You may need to install these integrations outside of SurveyMonkey. There are 200+ pre-built integrations helping you connect with popular CRMs, marketing automation tools, and BI platforms. Navigating the Connect Apps tab From the Connect apps Discover tab, search or browse the quick actions or explore some integration offerings. Select Manage to monitor or edit any quick actions you’ve already set up. Managing your Quick Actions Within the Connect apps space, you can manage and monitor all your actions, in one place. Selecting the green toggle will deactivate the action, but remain listed as a connected app that you can tap to re-activate. You can select the three dots menu (...) to edit a quick action’s set up, or Delete or Reauthenticate the app. If you want to manage an integration you previously installed, select the SurveyMonkey App Directory ’s tile that’s specific to that integration. title: Microsoft Teams Integration
body: Microsoft Teams Integration SurveyMonkey Setup Polling, Surveying, or Quizzing Your Team Sharing Results in a Tab Microsoft Teams Integration Microsoft Teams Integration SurveyMonkey Setup Polling, Surveying, or Quizzing Your Team Sharing Results in a Tab Limitations: This integration is available for US data center accounts only and the setup is only available in English. SurveyMonkey's integration with Microsoft Teams lets you: Add a personal app or use a messaging extension to create, view, edit, or share polls, surveys, or quizzes, and results Create, collect, and view responses directly in a Microsoft Teams channel, group chat, or private chat Share survey results collected in Microsoft Teams or SurveyMonkey in a Channel tab Set up notifications to let the team know when there are new responses or comments TIP! Based on your SurveyMonkey plan, you may need to upgrade to use some features or view all responses. Video Overview SurveyMonkey Setup Connecting your account The first time you install the SurveyMonkey app in Microsoft Teams, you need to log in to your SurveyMonkey account to connect to Microsoft Teams. Your account will store any polls, surveys, quizzes, and responses created and collected in Microsoft Teams. You can view results in the Analyze Results section of SurveyMonkey or a Microsoft Teams channel, chat, tab, or personal App. Adding SurveyMonkey as a Personal App The SurveyMonkey personal app is a private space for you to create, share, edit, or analyze results of all your polls or surveys. To add SurveyMonkey as a personal app: Click ... on the left side panel of Microsoft Teams. You can find all your apps here. Search for and select SurveyMonkey. Click Add to install and authorize your SurveyMonkey account. TIP! You can pin your SurveyMonkey personal app for easy access to your polls or surveys. Click ... on the left side panel, right-click on the SurveyMonkey icon, and select Pin. The SurveyMonkey personal app will appear on the left side panel. Adding SurveyMonkey as a Messaging Extension You can create and share a poll , survey , or quiz with others through a conversation in a channel, group chat, or private chat. To add SurveyMonkey as a messaging extension: Click New Conversation within a Microsoft Teams channel, or if you’re in a chat, move on to the next step. Click ... from the message menu. Search for and select SurveyMonkey. Click Add to install and authorize your SurveyMonkey account. TIP! You can pin your SurveyMonkey messaging extension for easy access to your surveys. Click ... on the bottom panel, right-click on the SurveyMonkey icon in the search modal, and select Pin. The SurveyMonkey messaging extension will appear on the bottom panel. Polling, Surveying, or Quizzing Your Team Creating a Poll, Survey, or Quiz You can create a poll, survey, or quiz to get feedback from your team. Share your poll, survey, or quiz with others in a channel, group chat, or private chat. To create and share a poll, survey, or quiz: Open SurveyMonkey in the personal app or messaging extension in a Microsoft Teams channel or chat. Click New and choose to create a poll, survey, or quiz, or start from a template. Add a Title . Select a Question type from the dropdown—Multiple choice, Dropdown, Checkbox, Comment box, Star rating, or Slider. Add your Question . Add your answer Choices . If you’re creating a quiz, assign points to answer choices in Score . If you want the question to be Required , click the toggle on. Click + Add Question to add additional survey or quiz questions. View the live Preview to make sure it looks good. Click Share . Click the toggles to control your settings. Keep responses anonymous : Don’t track and store info that identifies the survey takers. Schedule closing : You set when to close the survey. Keep responses anonymous : Don’t track and store info that identifies the survey takers. Schedule closing : You set when to close the survey. Click Share to teams and add a message to include with the card on the selected channel or chat. If you’re working from the Personal app, you can share the survey to multiple teams or channels. To share wherever you want, you can Copy URL . Your team can take the poll, survey, or quiz from the SurveyMonkey card added to the Microsoft Teams channel or chat to take it without having to leave Microsoft Teams. You can Edit any poll, survey, or quiz as long as there are only supported question types and no logic. Otherwise, you can edit the survey in SurveyMonkey. TIP! When you create a poll in Microsoft Teams, a web link collector is generated and can’t be edited. Errors may occur if you make changes to the web link. Viewing Results Open SurveyMonkey in the personal app or messaging extension and click Results to view charts right in Microsoft Teams. If your survey includes unsupported question types or logic, you can view results in SurveyMonkey. TIP ! If you are using the Free SurveyMonkey plan or are a Casual user, you'll be prompted to view results in your browser. Sharing Results in a Tab You can add a tab to any Microsoft Teams space to share results from surveys, polls, and quizzes created in either Microsoft Teams or SurveyMonkey. If you don't have access to this feature, you may need to update your Microsoft Teams app. From the Microsoft Teams channel menu, click the + Plus Icon. Use the search bar to find SurveyMonkey. Once a tab is added, you can update the default tab name. Check the box next to Post to channel about this tab if you want to let members know about the new tab. Click Save . Click + Share survey to tab and select which survey, poll, or quiz results you want to share. You can do this multiple times to share results from multiple surveys in one place, or share different results in different tabs. (Optional) Configure additional options like including Open-Ended responses, Data Trends, or Individual Responses with your survey results. Once you've added a survey to the tab, click on the survey card to view the results. Select the ... Icon to remove the card, or view more analytics in SurveyMonkey. title: SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Creating a Case Closed Survey
body: SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Creating a Case Closed Survey Create Your Survey (Optional) Create Custom Objects and Fields in Salesforce Set Up Salesforce Survey Mappings Add Custom Variables to Your Survey Design an Email Template in Salesforce Create a Case Closed Flow in Salesforce Set Conditions for your Case Closed Survey SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Creating a Case Closed Survey SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Creating a Case Closed Survey Create Your Survey (Optional) Create Custom Objects and Fields in Salesforce Set Up Salesforce Survey Mappings Add Custom Variables to Your Survey Design an Email Template in Salesforce Create a Case Closed Flow in Salesforce Set Conditions for your Case Closed Survey Get the integration ! SurveyMonkey for Salesforce is an Enterprise add-on. Contact Sales or your Customer Success Manager (CSM). Limitation: The integration setup is available in English only. If you use our SurveyMonkey for Salesforce integration, you can set up a survey that gets sent to customers after someone closes a case in Salesforce. Learn more about the SurveyMonkey for Salesforce integration . Automate your survey distribution to collect timely customer feedback and take action. You can use the Salesforce integration to send CSAT surveys after a customer interacts with your support team. We'll use a CSAT survey in this example, but case closed workflows can work with other kinds of surveys, like Customer Effort Score (CES) or Net Promoter Score (NPS). Create Your Survey Create the survey you want to send when someone closes a case. Keep the following in mind: Start with a rating question, such as a Multiple Choice, Rating, or NPS question. To create a CSAT question, use a Multiple Choice or Matrix/Rating Scale question type with a 5-point scale. If you use a Multiple Choice question, enable scoring . If you use a Matrix/Rating Scale question, add weights to the answer choices . If you use a Multiple Choice question, enable scoring . If you use a Matrix/Rating Scale question, add weights to the answer choices . It's best to use 3-4 questions in your survey. (Optional) Create Custom Objects and Fields in Salesforce You can create a custom object in Salesforce to hold your survey responses. If you’re using our managed package or already have an object set up, skip this step. When creating your custom object: Custom objects typically have a lookup relationship with a standard object. Lookup relationships are like a parent/child relationship between your custom survey object and any other standard or custom object in Salesforce. For example, you can create a lookup relationship between the custom CSAT Survey object and the Case object. Create a custom field for each survey answer you’ll map to the object. For example: Create a number field to hold the CSAT score. Create a text field to hold an open-text answer. Create a text field to hold the label for your CSAT question. Create a number field to hold the CSAT score. Create a text field to hold an open-text answer. Create a text field to hold the label for your CSAT question. Set Up Salesforce Survey Mappings In SurveyMonkey, create survey mappings to push responses to your custom Salesforce object. You can either: Use our managed package , which creates an object and mappings for you. Create your own mappings to a custom object. To set up mappings: Open the Salesforce integration. Connect your survey to your Salesforce environment if you haven't already. Create your mappings. Learn more about creating mappings Once you save your mappings and send your survey, we push any new survey responses to the Salesforce object you chose. Add Custom Variables to Your Survey Add the Case ID variable to your survey link to relate survey responses with the case. You can also add custom variables for other data you want to track. Learn how to add custom variables to your survey link . Design an Email Template in Salesforce Your case closed email is the main piece of the Salesforce flow . When your support agent closes a case, the flow sends the survey to the case contact. There are a few ways to send a survey over email: Include your survey link in the body of a Salesforce email template in your outbound message. Create a SurveyMonkey Email Invitation and send your survey through Salesforce. Create a Case Closed Flow in Salesforce Once you create your email template in Salesforce, you can build the Salesforce flow. Use your outbound message in the flow to trigger your survey. Learn more about creating flows in Salesforce . Set Conditions for your Case Closed Survey If you send surveys after every case is closed, your customers may experience survey fatigue and stop responding to surveys. You can use conditions in your Salesforce flow to limit how often you send surveys. For example, you can send the survey in the following conditions: Only for a certain number of cases (Example: every 6th case closed). Only after a period of time (Example: if the survey taker hasn't submitted a response in 7 days). Only for Certain Number of Cases You might want to trigger a survey for a certain number of cases only (Ex: every 4th case). To do this, you'll need to use formulas and workflow rules in Salesforce. Add an auto-number field to the Case object to assign each case a numeric value. To do this, add an auto-number field to the Case object. This field assigns each case a numeric value of {0}. Adding an auto-number field assigns a whole number to each case. Use a Salesforce MOD formula to return the case number to 0 whenever it is divisible by 10. The end result will be a revolving set of numbers from 1-10 that resets to 0 whenever the case number hits 10. The screenshot below shows a formula set up for our environment. The Survey_Send_Number__C field is the auto-number field we set up earlier. The 6 is the number to divide by. In this case, every 6th case will receive a survey. Create a flow with a condition that sends the survey when that MOD formula equals 0 (which will only happen every 6th case). This will be our workflow rule criteria. Only After Certain Time Periods You can limit how often surveys are sent to individual respondents to only send a survey after someone hasn’t completed a survey for a certain time period. To do this, use custom mappings to map the Response Created Date or Response Modified Date attribute to Salesforce. The Completion Time attribute tells Salesforce when your recipient last completed a survey. Then, create a trigger in Salesforce to check the Completion Time before sending a survey. To only send surveys after a certain time period: In Salesforce, create a date field on the Contact object. In SurveyMonkey, go to the Salesforce integration. Create a custom mapping to map Response Create or Response Modified to the date field on the Contact object. In Salesforce, create a trigger to distribute the survey based on these rules. The trigger needs to do 3 actions: Check the date on the contact for the case in question If the date is more than a certain time period (ex: 7 days) before the current date, send the survey. Otherwise, do nothing. If there is no date at all, send the survey. Check the date on the contact for the case in question If the date is more than a certain time period (ex: 7 days) before the current date, send the survey. Otherwise, do nothing. If there is no date at all, send the survey. title: Export Responses to Microsoft Excel
body: Export Responses to Microsoft Excel Exporting to Microsoft Excel Editing Quick Actions Managing Microsoft Excel Connections Export Responses to Microsoft Excel Export Responses to Microsoft Excel Exporting to Microsoft Excel Editing Quick Actions Managing Microsoft Excel Connections In SurveyMonkey's Connect Apps tab, you can integrate your SurveyMonkey account with Microsoft Excel to export survey responses to a new worksheet saved to OneDrive . This automation can help you share data across silos, merge responses with your data, slice and dice, or kick off other automated processes. Exporting to Microsoft Excel With the Microsoft Excel automation, you can: Create a new sheet that automatically updates with new responses Use existing sheet to update your existing workbook as new responses come in Create a New Sheet To automatically create a new sheet in Microsoft Excel: Select a survey from Home . From the Connect Apps tab, locate Microsoft Excel under the Discover tab. Select Create new sheet . If it's the first time you're connecting, select Connect to link your SurveyMonkey account to Microsoft Excel. If it's the first time you're connecting, select Connect to link your SurveyMonkey account to Microsoft Excel. Enter a Workbook name . This is the name we'll save your new workbook under. Manage the conditions for your quick action: Choose the data to include : Select Include survey data to choose the questions, answers, and metadata you want to send to the sheet. If you include open text questions, select I understand to acknowledge that respondent data exported may include personal identifying information. Filter the responses : Select Target specific responses to specify which responses will trigger this quick action. Choose the data to include : Select Include survey data to choose the questions, answers, and metadata you want to send to the sheet. If you include open text questions, select I understand to acknowledge that respondent data exported may include personal identifying information. Filter the responses : Select Target specific responses to specify which responses will trigger this quick action. Select Activate . A new Microsoft Excel worksheet is generated once a respondent completes your survey. The worksheet will seamlessly update as more results roll in. The worksheet can be accessed in My Files within OneDrive . Condition Limitations When you add a filter to a quick action, most questions are available to filter by, except: Date/Time Click map Text Image File upload Text A/B Image A/B Accepting payments via Stripe or PayPal When you add a filter to a quick action, most questions are available to filter by, except: Date/Time Click map Text Image File upload Text A/B Image A/B Accepting payments via Stripe or PayPal Use Existing Sheet To automatically update an existing sheet in Microsoft Excel: Select a survey from Home . From the Connect Apps tab, locate Microsoft Excel under the Discover tab. Select the down arrow on the button, then select Use existing sheet . If it's the first time you're connecting, select Connect to link your SurveyMonkey account to Microsoft Excel. If it's the first time you're connecting, select Connect to link your SurveyMonkey account to Microsoft Excel. Select the Workbook ID of the workbook you want to update. Manage the conditions for your quick action: Choose the data to include : Select Include survey data to choose the questions, answers, and metadata you want to send to the sheet. If you include open text questions, select I understand to acknowledge that respondent data exported may include personal identifying information. Filter the responses : Select Target specific responses to specify which responses will trigger this quick action. Choose the data to include : Select Include survey data to choose the questions, answers, and metadata you want to send to the sheet. If you include open text questions, select I understand to acknowledge that respondent data exported may include personal identifying information. Filter the responses : Select Target specific responses to specify which responses will trigger this quick action. Select Activate . Your Microsoft Excel spreadsheet is updated with new responses as respondents complete your survey. Condition Limitations When you add a filter to a quick action, most questions are available to filter by, except: Date/Time Click map Text Image File upload Text A/B Image A/B Accepting payments via Stripe or PayPal When you add a filter to a quick action, most questions are available to filter by, except: Date/Time Click map Text Image File upload Text A/B Image A/B Accepting payments via Stripe or PayPal Editing Quick Actions An overview of all Microsoft Excel quick actions you set up are available in the Manage tab within Connect Apps. You can select the toggle to disable or enable an automation. Or, you can select … to Edit action , Manage connection , or Delete an automation. Managing Microsoft Excel Connections You can view and manage your connected apps and actions from the Manage tab, under Connect Apps. You can select Manage connections to either Reauthenticate , which refreshes your existing connection, or fully uninstall the Microsoft Excel app by selecting Delete . You can also select the toggle to turn an action on or off, or click the … to Edit action or Delete it permanently. title: SurveyMonkey API
body: SurveyMonkey API Mobile SDK Integrations SurveyMonkey API SurveyMonkey API Mobile SDK Integrations SurveyMonkey has an API that you can use to create apps from scratch and automate your team’s workflows. If you’re a US data center customer, access the Developer Portal at https://developer.surveymonkey.com/ If you are a European data center customer, access the Developer Portal at https://developer.eu.surveymonkey.com / Questions for our API support team? Contact us . Mobile SDK SurveyMonkey's Mobile SDK lets app developers integrate SurveyMonkey surveys and responses into their iOS or Android apps. Integrations SurveyMonkey partners with other platforms to provide pre-built apps that empower you to quickly integrate with other popular tools. Visit our App Directory to browse available apps. TIP! Have a question about an integration? Visit the integration’s listing in the App Directory for guidance on which platform can best support you. title: OneDrive Integration
body: OneDrive Integration Sharing a SurveyMonkey File from OneDrive OneDrive Integration OneDrive Integration Sharing a SurveyMonkey File from OneDrive SurveyMonkey's integration with Microsoft OneDrive lets you store a file of your survey or results in OneDrive. You can then share this asset just like you would any other file in OneDrive. Install the integration from our App Directory . The integration setup is only available in English. Sharing a SurveyMonkey File from OneDrive You can share your .survey or .results files just like you would any other file in OneDrive . However, what the person you're sharing with can see when they open it depends on the permissions they have for the survey in SurveyMonkey. If you're sharing a .survey or .results file with someone who is a Full access collaborator on your SurveyMonkey team , they'll have access to the survey or results within their SurveyMonkey account. If you're sharing it with someone who isn't on your team, .survey files will open in a preview and test view and .results files will open as a shared data page . To share a survey or results: Install the OneDrive integration . Choose Surveys or Surveys + Responses . Search for and select the survey you want to share with OneDrive. To share responses, select a collector or Select All for all collectors. Click Select a folder to choose the OneDrive location to save the survey or responses to. Log into OneDrive to view the survey or individual responses where you saved them. Select the three dots (...) next to a survey or response to open and view it within SurveyMonkey. TIP! Creating a survey you want to share with your SurveyMonkey team? Learn how to manage viewing and editing permissions . title: Marketo Integration
body: Marketo Integration Survey Requirements Connecting a Survey to Marketo Mapping Actions Options Query Mappings Field Mapping Managing Connected Surveys Marketo Integration Marketo Integration Survey Requirements Connecting a Survey to Marketo Mapping Actions Options Query Mappings Field Mapping Managing Connected Surveys Marketo Our Marketo integration lets you sync your SurveyMonkey response data with your leads in Marketo. You can use it to create or update leads in Marketo from contact information collected in SurveyMonkey, attach survey response data from SurveyMonkey to existing leads in Marketo, and trigger email campaigns based on certain response conditions. Get the integration! The Marketo integration is available as an add-on at an additional cost. Contact sales » Survey Requirements When you build your survey think about how it should map to your Marketo fields. For example: If you're mapping to a date field in Marketo, make sure that your survey includes a Date/Time question. If you want a survey to create new leads, make sure your survey includes questions like Name , Email address , Phone , or Address . Connecting a Survey to Marketo Once your survey and Marketo account are ready, follow these steps to link a survey to Marketo: Log in to SurveyMonkey. Click the grid icon in the top right corner and select Integrations & Plug-Ins . Click Marketo. Click Connect Survey . Choose your survey from the dropdown menu. Select a Mapping Action and review its options. If you're updating leads, create your Query Mappings . If you're using Marketo to send out your campaign, keep the SurveyMonkey Field Marketo Lead Id mapped to the Marketo Lead Field Id . If you're distributing the survey in another way, read more about Query Mappings . Select your Field Mapping , or how the response fields from your survey should map to each Marketo lead. Select or create a collector for the integration to use and click Save . Copy and paste the survey URL into your Marketo email or landing page template. Existing survey responses that were collected before connecting with Marketo will not populate in Marketo. Mapping Actions Options TIP! SurveyMonkey's custom activities let you create Smart Lists in Marketo to segment leads based on how they answered questions in your survey. When you create a Smart List, use the Survey Name, Question Name, and Question Response values from the Survey Answer activity to build your filter. For example, create a Smart List that filters for leads that answered a 9 or 10 to the Net Promoter Score question—making them a Promoter of your brand. Query Mappings SurveyMonkey uses your Query Mapping criteria to determine which lead to update. If you're using Marketo to send out your survey, leave the SurveyMonkey Field Marketo Lead Id mapped to the Marketo Lead Field Id . If you're distributing your survey in another way, you'll need to map a survey field to another field in Marketo that'll let the integration look up your leads by that field to figure out which one to update. For example, if you want to use an email address, select the SurveyMonkey question that collects an email address and map it to the Marketo field that stores it. Whatever you choose should be unique, if you have multiple leads with the same email address, you may want to map a second value to look leads up by, like, name. This way you can create a unique combination. Add more mappings to your lookup by clicking Add Field Mapping . If the integration comes up with more than one lead that matches your Query Mapping criteria, it'll log it in your Error Log. Field Mapping The Field Mappings table lets you map how the integration syncs the answers from your survey to your leads in Marketo. The Hidden Mappings table lets you map custom values to Marketo fields to be passed with each response—for example send a value describing or coding your survey's audience. When mapping fields remember that: The fields must match in data type, so a date field in Marketo should match a Date/Time question in SurveyMonkey and an email field in Marketo should match a question asking for an email address in SurveyMonkey. If you've turned on the option to overwrite existing data, a respondent leaving a mapped question blank could result in data loss. You can avoid this by making mapped questions required or setting a default value for the mapping. You can make a question required directly from the mapping page by clicking the yellow triangle icon next to the mapping. Any field you've set to be blocked in Marketo can't be overwritten, even if you've turned on the overwrite existing data option. Not all survey questions need to be mapped to a lead field. The responses to unmapped questions are available in Analyze and, if you're using the sync SurveyMonkey Answers option, in your lead's Action Log in Marketo. When you map to a boolean field in Marketo, it's set to True if any answer is selected or entered—you won't be able to determine what the answer is. Only map to a boolean field if you just want to capture if a particular optional question was answered or not. TIP! To create and map a Yes/No question, add a multiple choice question to your Survey, label your answer options Yes and No, and map these options to text fields in Marketo. To set a default value to pass if a question isn't answered: Click the Set default value icon (which looks like a pencil and paper) to the right of the mapped value you want to set a default for. Enter your desired value into the Default Value box. Click the Set default value icon (which looks like a pencil and paper) to the right of the mapped value you want to set a default for. Enter your desired value into the Default Value box. Managing Connected Surveys You can view and manage your connected surveys from the main page of the integration where they're listed in a table. TIP! Use the Audit Log to jump directly to a lead in Marketo by clicking Lead Id or jump directly to the response in Analyze by clicking Respondent Id .
