title: SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Managed Package
body: SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Managed Package Installing the Managed Package Objects in the Managed Package Mapping to the SurveyMonkey Response Object Customizing Page Layouts in Salesforce Creating Reports and Dashboards in Salesforce SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Managed Package SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Managed Package Installing the Managed Package Objects in the Managed Package Mapping to the SurveyMonkey Response Object Customizing Page Layouts in Salesforce Creating Reports and Dashboards in Salesforce Salesforce If you use our Salesforce integration, SurveyMonkey's managed package for Salesforce offers a simple way to push survey responses into your Salesforce organization. Learn more about the SurveyMonkey for Salesforce integration . Our Managed Mapping package creates two new objects in your Salesforce environment and maps survey responses to them. You can also relate these records to other Salesforce records, like a Contact or Account record, to show survey data wherever you need it. Installing the Managed Package The first time you use managed mapping, you’ll need to install a small package in your Salesforce organization. To install the Managed Mapping package, choose the Sync all responses to SurveyMonkey’s Response object option on the Object Mapping page. Learn more TIP! To install the managed package in a sandbox environment, change the subdomain in the installation link to “test” – for example, test.salesforce.com Objects in the Managed Package The SurveyMonkey managed package includes 2 objects: SurveyMonkey Survey Response : The parent object, Each time some submits a survey response, we create a new record on the Survey Response object. Each Survey Response record contains information about the response submission (not the answers within the response). SurveyMonkey Response : The child object. For every survey question someone submits, we create a new record on the Response object. Each Response record contains full details of the survey question and the respondent’s answer. In Salesforce, you can add a lookup field to the page layout to reference the parent Survey Response record. Object Fields SurveyMonkey Survey Response Components (Parent Object) The following fields are available on the Survey Response object. Component Name Type Survey ID Custom Field Survey Name Custom Field Response ID Custom Field Response Status Custom Field Lead Custom Field Recipient ID Custom Field Contact Custom Field Edit URL Custom Field Collector ID Custom Field Collector Name Custom Field Analyze URL Custom Field Case Custom Field Account Custom Field Survey Response Layout Page Layout The following fields are available on the Survey Response object. SurveyMonkey Response Components (Child Object) The following fields are available on the Response object. Page ID Custom Field NPS Normalized Custom Field Opportunity Custom Field Other ID Custom Field Other Text Custom Field Contact Custom Field Edit URL Custom Field Lead Custom Field NPS Label Custom Field Collector ID Custom Field Collector Name Custom Field Column ID Custom Field Column Name Custom Field Analyze URL Custom Field Case Custom Field Choice ID Custom Field Choice Name Custom Field Account Custom Field Survey Name Custom Field Response Custom Field Row ID Custom Field Row Name Custom Field Survey ID Custom Field Recipient ID Custom Field Response ID Custom Field Response Number Value Custom Field Response Text Custom Field Question ID Custom Field Question Name Custom Field Question Type Custom Field Random Assignment ID Custom Field Random Assignment Text Custom Field Survey Response Custom Field NPS Score Custom Field Page Name Custom Field Survey Monkey Response Answer Layout Page Layout The following fields are available on the Response object. Mapping to the SurveyMonkey Response Object You can map survey data to different fields and lookup fields on the SurveyMonkey Response object. You can also add lookup fields to the SurveyMonkey Response object. You can use these lookup fields to bring in data from other objects . Learn how to map the SurveyMonkey Response object to lookup fields . Customizing Page Layouts in Salesforce To better view a contact’s survey responses in Salesforce, your admin can add the Response object to the Contact Page Layout. After changing the page layout, you can view someone’s survey responses on their Contact record. To customize the Contact Page Layout in Salesforce: In Salesforce Setup , go to Object Manager . Go to the Contact object, then select Page Layouts . Select Contact Layout . In the Contact Layout box, select Related Lists . Drag the Survey Response label to the area below, then save your page layout. Creating Reports and Dashboards in Salesforce Managed Mappings push data to Salesforce so you can build Salesforce Reports and Dashboards. Talk to your Salesforce representative to learn how to implement reporting in your Salesforce organization. Each answer value is stored in one or more fields on the SurveyMonkey Response object. Build your reports based on the appropriate fields on the object. For example, if you’re reporting on numeric data, you’ll want to use the Number field. You can also filter Salesforce reports to only include certain questions. Enabling Reporting To create reports, you need to enable reporting on your Survey Response, and Response objects. To enable reporting for your objects in Salesforce: In Salesforce, go to the object. Select Edit . Check the box to Allow Reports , then Save . Creating Reports Once you've enabled reporting on both objects, you can create your report in Salesforce. Select the SurveyMonkey Responses report type. Related Articles Company SurveyMonkey About Us Jobs Blog Help SurveyMonkey Help GetFeedback Help Market Research Help SurveyMonkey Audience Help SurveyMonkey Contribute Help Wufoo Help Apply Help Support Site Status Unsubscribe Contact Us Email Opt-In Policies Legal Center Privacy Policy Cookies Notice California Privacy Notice

title: Post Responses Automatically in Slack
body: Post Responses Automatically in Slack Connecting SurveyMonkey and Slack to share responses in Slack Automated Responses in Slack Manage Your Slack Connections Post Responses Automatically in Slack Post Responses Automatically in Slack Connecting SurveyMonkey and Slack to share responses in Slack Automated Responses in Slack Manage Your Slack Connections Connect your SurveyMonkey account with Slack so you can automatically post survey responses in public or private Slack channels, in real time. You can set up the workflow so all responses post to Slack or set conditions based on a specific set of responses to target notifications and encourage the right people to take action. Connecting SurveyMonkey to Slack is helpful for initiating action to follow up with customers or employees to improve trends based on their responses to your survey, or to share feedback to offer transparency to your team or just to the right people. Automating responses in Slack is only possible for Complete responses . Connecting SurveyMonkey and Slack to share responses in Slack You can set up automations so survey responses post in Slack. To set up your survey to send Slack messages with your survey responses: Select a survey from Home . From the Connect Apps tab, locate Slack under the Discover tab. Select the quick action, Post to channel . If it's the first time you're posting to a channel, select Connect to link your SurveyMonkey account to Slack. Select Allow to give SurveyMonkey access to your Slack workspace. If it's the first time you're posting to a channel, select Connect to link your SurveyMonkey account to Slack. Select Allow to give SurveyMonkey access to your Slack workspace. Select or search for the Slack Channel you want to post responses to. (Optional) Enter an Optional Message to send along with the response in Slack, to provide context. (Optional) Turn on the toggle to Link to response , if you want to include a link to SurveyMonkey.com within your post. (Optional) Select + next to Include survey data if you want to select to 5 questions to display with your Slack post. Select + Add more data and select a question. Repeat as desired, then select Apply. Select + Add more data and select a question. Repeat as desired, then select Apply. (Optional) To target specific responses, rather than post for all responses, select + Target specific responses . Select Add filter . Select your Criteria questions and answer. Select Add . To add additional filters, select + Add new filter and repeat the last 3 steps. Select Apply . Select Add filter . Select your Criteria questions and answer. Select Add . To add additional filters, select + Add new filter and repeat the last 3 steps. Select Apply . Select Activate . An overview of all Slack quick actions you set up are available in the Manage tab within the Connect apps tab. Select a toggle to disable or enable a quick action. Or, you can select the three dot menu ( …) to Edit action , Manage connection , or Delete an automation. TIP! Feel free to create multiple workflows to deliver to various channels or use filters to customize the information getting sent to Slack. Condition Limitations When you add a filter to a quick action, most questions are available to filter by, except: Date/Time Click map Text Image File upload Text A/B Image A/B Accepting payments via Stripe or PayPal When you add a filter to a quick action, most questions are available to filter by, except: Date/Time Click map Text Image File upload Text A/B Image A/B Accepting payments via Stripe or PayPal Automated Responses in Slack Any new responses matching your Send when filter criteria post to your channels in real time. The message you set up displays and may have a link to view the individual response, which opens a Shared data page in a new tab. Manage Your Slack Connections You can view and manage your connected apps and actions from the Manage tab, under Connect Apps. You can Manage connections to either Reauthenticate , which refreshes your existing connection, or Delete the individual users' installation of the app. In order to fully remove the SurveyMonkey app from your Slack workspace, a Slack Admin is needed. They can Remove app from the app listing's Configuration tab . To manage your Slack quick actions, you can also select the toggle to turn an action on or off, or click the … to Edit action or Delete it permanently. title: SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Sending Reminder Emails
body: SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Sending Reminder Emails Create Fields and Templates in Salesforce Create Mappings Create a Flow for Your Survey Create a Flow for the Reminder Email SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Sending Reminder Emails SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Sending Reminder Emails Create Fields and Templates in Salesforce Create Mappings Create a Flow for Your Survey Create a Flow for the Reminder Email Get the integration ! SurveyMonkey for Salesforce is an Enterprise add-on. Contact Sales or your Customer Success Manager (CSM). Limitation: The integration setup is only available in English. If you use our SurveyMonkey for Salesforce integration , you can send reminder emails from Salesforce to encourage people to take your survey. You can create a custom object and flow to send a reminder email after a certain period of time. This process works if you create your own mappings and use the Weblink Collector . These instructions won’t work if you use the managed package or create a SurveyMonkey Email Collector. To send reminder emails from Salesforce, you need to: Build a custom object in Salesforce with specific fields Create your Salesforce email templates Create object mappings in SurveyMonkey Build 2 flows in Salesforce that work together Create Fields and Templates in Salesforce Set up the following in Salesforce: Create a new custom object in Salesforce, or edit an existing one. Create a Sent Date field on the response object in Salesforce. On your object, create a checkbox field labeled Send Reminder Email . The checkbox field doesn’t need to be visible on the page layout, but the person setting up the Salesforce flow needs access to it. Create two email templates in Salesforce - one to send the survey, and one to send the reminder email. Create Mappings In SurveyMonkey, set up mappings to update an existing record when a response is submitted. Map the Response Created attribute from SurveyMonkey to the Sent Date field you created in Salesforce. At the Deployment Options , create a Weblink Collector. Paste this into your email template in Salesforce. Create a Flow for Your Survey Create a flow to send your survey email when a certain condition is met. This flow should also check the box to send a reminder email. Set the action to update the Send Reminder Email checkbox field. Choose any time length. A typical length is 3-7 days after sending the survey. Create a Flow for the Reminder Email Once you set up your mappings, create a flow that sends your reminder email. Before sending your survey, test all flows to make sure they’re working as expected. Related Articles Company SurveyMonkey About Us Jobs Blog Help SurveyMonkey Help GetFeedback Help Market Research Help SurveyMonkey Audience Help SurveyMonkey Contribute Help Wufoo Help Apply Help Support Site Status Unsubscribe Contact Us Email Opt-In Policies Legal Center Privacy Policy Cookies Notice California Privacy Notice

title: Google Add-Ons
body: Google Add-Ons Google Sheets Add-On Google Forms Add-On Linking and Unlinking Your Accounts Google Add-Ons Google Add-Ons Google Sheets Add-On Google Forms Add-On Linking and Unlinking Your Accounts Limitation: The Google add-on setup is only available in English. We have two Google add-ons available: Use the SurveyMonkey for Google Sheets add-on to import your survey results directly into Google Sheets. Use the SurveyMonkey for Google Forms add-on to import your form into a SurveyMonkey survey. Google Sheets Add-On This add-on is available for SurveyMonkey paid plans . The Google Sheets add-on lets you import your survey responses to a spreadsheet. We’ll update your spreadsheets with new responses until you choose to stop importing. To import your survey results to Google Sheets: Get the free SurveyMonkey for Google Sheets add-on . You can find it in the SurveyMonkey App Directory or the Google Workspace Marketplace. Create a new spreadsheet in your Google account. Click Extensions from the toolbar. Select the SurveyMonkey add-on, then select Open . Select Get Started to log in with your SurveyMonkey details to authorize and open the app. The login page opens in a new browser tab. Once you log in, go back to your spreadsheet. Start Syncing Responses Once you sign in, you can start importing responses from SurveyMonkey. To import responses: Once your survey list pops up, select the survey you want to import results from. Check the boxes for the collectors you want to import results from. A green dot means the collector is open, and a gray dot means it's closed. Click Start importing to import the survey data. We create a new sheet with the same name as the survey you’re importing. We’ll also update your sheet with new responses any time you open the SurveyMonkey add-on. TIP! It’s best to stop importing responses before making changes to your spreadsheet. Spreadsheet Organization The add-on imports all responses from the collectors you selected into a sheet with the exact same name as the survey. The following information will help you get started analyzing the spreadsheet: Row 1 contains the question text from the survey. When a question isn't answered or is skipped by logic, the text "Not Answered" displays in the cell. The Checkbox question type lists each answer choice as it's own column and assigns True if the answer option was selected or False if it wasn’t. Questions with multiple rows, columns, or fields of answer choices span across multiple columns in the spreadsheet with each row, column, or field in its own column. The spreadsheet organizes respondents by row and includes the time the survey was submitted or last modified and the complete answer set for each respondent. For additional respondent metadata you may have included in an Email Invitation Collector, please download an All Responses Data XLS export . Filtering Your Spreadsheet You can create filters in Google Sheets to organize the results, but it's best to wait to edit the spreadsheet until you're done refreshing the results—refreshing may overwrite changes you've made to the sheet. Refreshing Your Data To refresh the available surveys or response counts per collector, click the refresh button at the top of the list to the right of your SurveyMonkey username. To import new responses to the sheet, close and reopen the SurveyMonkey add-on. We’ll update your spreadsheet with new responses. We can only import responses into a sheet (or tab) that has the same name as the survey you’re importing. If the name of the sheet or survey changes, we’ll import responses to a new sheet. Importing Data to a New Sheet You can import the survey data into a new sheet (or tab) within the spreadsheet if you don't want to overwrite any changes you've made. You have two options: Edit the name of the sheet (the tab within the spreadsheet—not the name of the spreadsheet itself), then click Import to the right of the survey title. A new sheet will be created within the spreadsheet. Edit the survey title in SurveyMonkey, then click Import to the right of the survey title. A new sheet will be created with the updated survey title. Stop Importing Responses Stop importing responses to change which collectors you import responses from or make changes to your sheet. To stop importing new responses: From the SurveyMonkey extension, select the survey you want to stop importing responses from. Click Stop importing to the right of the survey title. If you want to keep importing responses later, just select Start importing . If you start importing again, any changes made to the spreadsheet will be lost. To keep any changes you made, rename your tab before you start importing responses again. Limitations Google Sheets allows us to import up to 3,000 responses at a time. To view more responses in a sheet, consider exporting your results to an XLS or CSV file. If your survey has a lot of questions or responses, please refer to Google's spreadsheet size limits . We support the new version of Google Sheets, which has a limit of 2 million cells per spreadsheet. A/B Test responses can’t be imported. Google Forms Add-On This add-on is available for all SurveyMonkey plan types, including the free plan. The Google Forms add-on lets you convert a Google Form to a survey in SurveyMonkey. You can then design and send your survey from SurveyMonkey. To import your Google Form into a survey: Get the free SurveyMonkey for Google Forms add-on . Open your Google Form. Click Add-ons from the toolbar. Open the SurveyMonkey add-on. You'll need to log in with your SurveyMonkey details to authorize and open the app. Once the app window pops up, select the form questions you want to include in your survey. Questions that are greyed out can't be imported. Click Convert to Survey . Log in to SurveyMonkey to finish designing your survey . Linking and Unlinking Your Accounts Your Google account can only be linked with one SurveyMonkey account at a time. To switch the SurveyMonkey account you're using in the add-on: Click Sign Out from the bottom of the SurveyMonkey app window. Click Get Started within that same window. On the authorization page, click Use Another Account and log in. To unlink your accounts entirely: Go to your SurveyMonkey My Account page . In the Linked Accounts section, click Unlink next to the Google Sheets or Google Forms application. Go to your Google My Account page . Find your connected apps and sites and revoke access for SurveyMonkey. title: Tableau Integration
body: Tableau Integration Installing the Tableau Connector Migrating Existing Workbooks to Tableau WDC 3.0 Setting Up an Extract Applying Filters to an Extract Tableau Integration Tableau Integration Installing the Tableau Connector Migrating Existing Workbooks to Tableau WDC 3.0 Setting Up an Extract Applying Filters to an Extract Get the integration! The Tableau integration is available as an Enterprise add-on. The integration setup is only available in English. Contact sales » SurveyMonkey's Tableau integration lets you set up an extract to export survey responses and quiz results to Tableau Desktop using a Web Data Connector . You need Tableau Desktop version 10.1.6 or greater to use this integration. EXISTING INTEGRATION USERS : Tableau is deprecating the existing Tableau WDC 2.0 connector. You'll need to install our Tableau WDC 3.0 connector and change the data source in your existing workbooks . Installing the Tableau Connector To connect your data to Tableau, you'll need to install the WDC 3.0 connector. To install the connector: Open your survey, then go to the Connect Apps section. Search for the Tableau integration, then select Details . Select Install to download the connector (the "taco" file). The file will end with a .taco extension. Place the .taco file in the following directory: Windows - C:\Users\[Windows User]\Documents\My Tableau Repository\Connectors macOS - /Users/[user]/Documents/My Tableau Repository/Connectors Windows - C:\Users\[Windows User]\Documents\My Tableau Repository\Connectors macOS - /Users/[user]/Documents/My Tableau Repository/Connectors Restart Tableau Desktop . Migrating Existing Workbooks to Tableau WDC 3.0 If you're connecting SurveyMonkey to Tableau for the first time, skip this step. If you have workbook that uses the existing Tableau WDC 2.0 connector, you'll need to change your data source to the new Tableau WDC 3.0 connector. If you connected your workbook to SurveyMonkey before September 30, 2025, you're likely using the Tableau WDC 2.0 connector. Learn how to change data sources in Tableau . Setting Up an Extract Launch Tableau Desktop . Under Connect, find the To a Server section, then select SurveyMonkey by SurveyMonkey . You may need to select More under To a Server to find it. Sign in to your SurveyMonkey account and authorize Tableau to extract the data. Find the survey you want to connect, then select Import Survey. Choose the questions and data you want to analyze in Tableau. You can also use Filters to find and select specific data. Select Import to bring your data into Tableau. Applying Filters to an Extract While creating a new extract or reviewing an existing one, you can filter the extract if you want to include only certain kinds of responses. You can filter extracts by collector, status, or metadata. Collector : Choose the collectors you want to include in your extract. Status : Choose the response statuses to include in your extract. Metadata : Enter or define the respondent metadata associated with responses to include in your extract, like responses that took longer than a minute or from a particular IP Address. How you sent your survey (the collector type ) and the collector settings determine the metadata that's recorded with responses . For example, we don't record most fields if you've turned on Anonymous Responses . title: Getting Started with SurveyMonkey for Salesforce
body: Getting Started with SurveyMonkey for Salesforce Before You Start Step 1: SurveyMonkey Setup Step 2: Salesforce Object Setup Step 3: Create Mappings Step 4: Send Your Survey Optional: Salesforce Lightning Flows and Components Ways to Use the Integration Getting Started with SurveyMonkey for Salesforce Getting Started with SurveyMonkey for Salesforce Before You Start Step 1: SurveyMonkey Setup Step 2: Salesforce Object Setup Step 3: Create Mappings Step 4: Send Your Survey Optional: Salesforce Lightning Flows and Components Ways to Use the Integration Get the integration ! SurveyMonkey for Salesforce is an Enterprise add-on. Contact Sales or your Customer Success Manager (CSM). The integration setup is only available in English. With SurveyMonkey for Salesforce, you can build automations to trigger surveys and push data back to Salesforce records for in-context analysis. Create reports, dashboards, and automate flows to take action on feedback. This guide helps you get ready to send survey data to Salesforce. Follow the steps below to get started. Then, read our guide, Using SurveyMonkey for Salesforce , to create your mappings and send your survey. Before You Start Make sure you have the Salesforce and SurveyMonkey permissions you need to set up the integration. All your mappings are saved to the Salesforce account you connect to. You can connect to multiple Salesforce accounts, including your sandbox environment. If possible, use an integration-specific Salesforce account . If the logged-in Salesforce account is deactivated, their mappings will stop working. SurveyMonkey Permissions If your SurveyMonkey plan has Power and Casual seats , you need an Enterprise Power seat to access the integration. Salesforce Permissions In Salesforce, you can use the Salesforce Integration license with the SurveyMonkey integration. However, you'll need to enable certain permissions first. The table below lists the recommended permissions for your Salesforce profile. Step 1: SurveyMonkey Setup There are a few steps to take in SurveyMonkey before you start mapping responses to Salesforce. Build the survey you want to connect to Salesforce. Add questions , apply logic , and customize the design . Learn more about creating your survey . (Optional) Add custom variables to track information about survey takers. You can include a Salesforce merge field to pull in known data from Salesforce. You can also add custom variables later when you create your mappings. (Optional) If you want to send your survey via email invitation, create your email message now. Select "resume later" when you finish creating your email message to save it as a template. Step 2: Salesforce Object Setup If you’re sending data to a standard or custom Salesforce object, make sure to set it up before pushing survey data to Salesforce. This applies to new and existing objects. TIP! You may need help from your Salesforce administrator to set up your object. To set up your object: If necessary, build a custom object to map your surveys to. You don’t need to do this if you’re mapping to an existing object. Add custom fields to hold survey data . If necessary, add custom fields for each piece of information in your survey you want to store in this object. Make sure you can write to these fields – SurveyMonkey can’t push data to read-only fields. Some survey questions can only be mapped to certain field types in Salesforce. Use our field mapping guide to make sure you add the right fields for your survey data. Make sure you can write to these fields – SurveyMonkey can’t push data to read-only fields. Some survey questions can only be mapped to certain field types in Salesforce. Use our field mapping guide to make sure you add the right fields for your survey data. Add lookup fields . Lookup relationships allow you to associate data from this object to another one, such as the Contact object. You’ll need to include the record ID (such as the Contact ID) in your survey responses when you send your survey. Step 3: Connect to Salesforce and Create Mappings Connect your Salesforce account to the integration so you can create your mappings. You can connect multiple accounts, including sandbox environments. This process leverages OAuth 2.0 for a secure integration. To access the integration: In SurveyMonkey, select the Products icon and select Integrations & Plug-ins . Select Salesforce . Select Connect or Connect Sandbox to connect your Salesforce account. If you’ve signed in to Salesforce, we’ll automatically connect to your signed-in account. You can repeat these steps to connect more Salesforce accounts. Go to our SurveyMonkey for Salesforce guide when you're ready to create your mappings. How Mapping Works Mappings send your survey data back to Salesforce. You can map specific responses or metadata to fields on Salesforce objects. You can choose from two mapping types: Managed package : If you don't need customization, you can send all responses to the SurveyMonkey Response object. You'll need to install a small package in Salesforce. This option creates the mapping for you. Learn more about our managed package for Salesforce . Custom object mapping : Build your own mappings to send data to custom or standard Salesforce objects. This requires more effort but lets you control where your survey data is sent in Salesforce. Use our field mapping guide to learn which Salesforce fields you can send survey data to. Learn more about mapping types , or learn how to create mappings . Step 4: Send Your Survey Once you create your mappings, you can send your survey. The Salesforce integration gives you 2 deployment options: A Web link , which you can copy and paste into another email. This option is best if you want to send your survey from an existing email template in Salesforce. You can include custom variables in your web link to gather more data about your respondents. An Email Invitation , which sends from SurveyMonkey. You can personalize your SurveyMonkey email with data from Salesforce. We'll help you create an Outbound Message in Salesforce. Then, you'll need to create a Salesforce flow to send your survey. Learn how to use the Salesforce integration deployment options . Optional: Salesforce Lightning Flows and Components SurveyMonkey offers a few features for customers using Lightning Experience : Lightning flow : Lets Salesforce users take or send in-the-moment surveys directly from Account, Contact, or Lead objects. Salesforce users can take a survey within Salesforce, for example, to provide feedback that a customer gave a rep over the phone. SurveyMonkey Lightning component : Lets Salesforce users send a survey to one or more Contacts off any object. Survey Response Visualization Lightning component : Lets you see the responses from the survey that were completed via the Lightning component or flow. Learn more . Ways to Use the Integration You can chat with your CSM about your specific use case so you can best utilize the integration. Organizations use the SurveyMonkey for Salesforce integration in many different ways, depending on how they use Salesforce. Below are some common use cases. Related Articles Company SurveyMonkey About Us Jobs Blog Help SurveyMonkey Help GetFeedback Help Market Research Help SurveyMonkey Audience Help SurveyMonkey Contribute Help Wufoo Help Apply Help Support Site Status Unsubscribe Contact Us Email Opt-In Policies Legal Center Privacy Policy Cookies Notice California Privacy Notice

title: HootSuite Integration
body: HootSuite Integration Installing the SurveyMonkey App on HootSuite Viewing the Results Summary & Individual Responses on HootSuite Sharing Surveys on Social Media through HootSuite Tips HootSuite Integration HootSuite Integration Installing the SurveyMonkey App on HootSuite Viewing the Results Summary & Individual Responses on HootSuite Sharing Surveys on Social Media through HootSuite Tips We've partnered with HootSuite , the leading social media dashboard to manage and measure your social networks. Now you can send your SurveyMonkey surveys out to multiple social networks, and view your results, all in one place. Need help? Reach out to support@hootsuite.com for assistance. Installing the SurveyMonkey App on HootSuite Log in to HootSuite. Click the puzzle piece App Directory icon in the left toolbar. Search the App Directory for SurveyMonkey . Click the Install App button. A SurveyMonkey tab will appear on your HootSuite dashboard. Under that tab, click Connect with SurveyMonkey . A popup appears asking you to enter your SurveyMonkey login information. Enter your SurveyMonkey username and password. Click Authorize . Viewing the Results Summary & Individual Responses on HootSuite Open the SurveyMonkey tab. Locate the survey whose results you'd like to view. In the Actions column to the right of the survey, click the graph icon . The results window defaults to the Question Summaries tab, where you can view charts representing each question of the survey. (Note: For more dynamic charts, return to the Analyze Results section in SurveyMonkey). Open the SurveyMonkey tab. Locate the survey whose results you'd like to view. In the Actions column to the right of the survey, click the graph icon . Click the Individual Responses tab to view raw data: Start Date & Time, Last Modified Date & Time, Status, Collection Mode, and IP Address. Click the plus sign icon to the left of a response to see that respondent's answers to each survey question. Sharing Surveys on Social Media through HootSuite Open the SurveyMonkey tab. Locate the survey you'd like to send. In the Actions column, click the arrow icon to open the Compose Message Box , which will automatically include the survey link. Compose your message. Select the social network(s) that will post your message. Choose to send the message immediately or schedule its delivery for later. Tips Use the search function in the upper right of the SurveyMonkey tab to quickly find a specific survey. Click the refresh icon in the upper right of the SurveyMonkey tab to pull the most current survey responses. Click a survey title to return to the Analyze Results section in SurveyMonkey. Click a collector name to open the survey. title: Export Responses to a Google Sheet
body: Export Responses to a Google Sheet Exporting Responses to Google Sheets Editing the Google Sheets Quick Action Turning Off the Quick Action Export Responses to a Google Sheet Export Responses to a Google Sheet Exporting Responses to Google Sheets Editing the Google Sheets Quick Action Turning Off the Quick Action With a Connect apps quick action, you can automatically export your new survey results to either a new or existing Google spreadsheet, where responses populate in a new sheet in the spreadsheet. The Google Sheets quick action lets you keep your data synchronized for automatic sharing, analysis, and data visualization. Responses are added to your Google Sheet as they arrive. Existing survey response aren't able to be exported to Google Sheets using this quick action. Exporting Responses to Google Sheets The Google Sheets quick action in Connect apps lets you create a new or existing Google Sheet with your survey responses. To export responses to a new Google Sheet: Go to the Connect apps section. Find Google Sheets. Hover over the down arrow and select Create new sheet or Use existing sheet . Select Connect to sign in to your Google account. Type a new spreadsheet name or Select spreadsheet to use an existing. Manage the conditions for your quick action: Choose the data to include : Select Include survey data to choose the questions, answers, and metadata you want to send to the sheet. If you include open text questions, select I understand to acknowledge that respondent data exported may include personal identifying information. Filter the responses : Select Target specific responses to specify which responses will trigger this quick action. Choose the data to include : Select Include survey data to choose the questions, answers, and metadata you want to send to the sheet. If you include open text questions, select I understand to acknowledge that respondent data exported may include personal identifying information. Filter the responses : Select Target specific responses to specify which responses will trigger this quick action. Select Activate to save and turn on your quick action. Your Google Sheets quick action is turned on by default so you can test it and start collecting responses. You can always turn it off later. Editing the Google Sheets Quick Action You can edit the spreadsheet name, conditions, and filters of your SurveyMonkey quick action, at any time. This is useful if you need to change the criteria for which responses are exported or if you want to update the spreadsheet name. If you change the spreadsheet name within Google Sheets, the SurveyMonkey quick action will stop updating the existing spreadsheet and create a new one. To edit your Google Sheets quick action: Go to the Connect Apps section of your survey. Select Manage . Find your quick action. Select the three dots icon ... Select Edit action . Make any desired changes. Select Save . Turning Off the Quick Action If you want to temporarily stop exporting new responses to your Google Sheet, you can turn off the quick action. This is useful if you want to pause the export but might want to restart it later. To turn off the quick action: Go to the Connect apps section of your survey. Select Manage . Find your quick action, then turn off the toggle. Deleting the Quick Action Deleting a quick action permanently removes it. If you no longer need to export responses using this quick action and don't plan to use it again, you can delete it. Deleted automations can't be recovered. To use this automation again in the future, you'll need to create a new quick action. To delete the quick action: Go to the Connect apps section of your survey. Select Manage . Find your quick action. Select the three dots icon ... Select Delete . At the confirmation message, select Delete again. Related Articles Company SurveyMonkey About Us Jobs Blog Help SurveyMonkey Help GetFeedback Help Market Research Help SurveyMonkey Audience Help SurveyMonkey Contribute Help Wufoo Help Apply Help Support Site Status Unsubscribe Contact Us Email Opt-In Policies Legal Center Privacy Policy Cookies Notice California Privacy Notice

title: Using SurveyMonkey for Salesforce
body: Using SurveyMonkey for Salesforce Before You Start Access the Salesforce Integration Connect Your Survey to the Integration How Mapping Works Create Mappings Deployment Options Troubleshooting Email Invitations Test Your Survey and Mappings Share Mappings with Your Team Copy Mappings to Another Account Common Questions Using SurveyMonkey for Salesforce Using SurveyMonkey for Salesforce Before You Start Access the Salesforce Integration Connect Your Survey to the Integration How Mapping Works Create Mappings Deployment Options Troubleshooting Email Invitations Test Your Survey and Mappings Share Mappings with Your Team Copy Mappings to Another Account Common Questions Salesforce Get the integration ! SurveyMonkey for Salesforce is an Enterprise add-on. Contact Sales or your Customer Success Manager (CSM). Limitation: The integration setup is only available in English. With SurveyMonkey for Salesforce, you can build automations to trigger surveys and push data back to Salesforce records for in-context analysis. Create reports, dashboards, and automate flows to take action on feedback. When you integrate survey data with Salesforce, you can better understand, measure, and react to various customer interactions to improve the overall health of your business relationships. Salesforce blocked the creation of new workflow rules in February 2023. You’ll need to build new automations using Flows or use the Migrate to Flow tool . You can still activate, edit, and deactivate existing process builder and workflow rules. Before You Start Create your survey and set up your Salesforce object before you create your mappings. Learn more in our Getting Started guide . If your SurveyMonkey plan has Power and Casual seats, you need an Enterprise Power seat to access the integration. Learn more about seats and permissions . To avoid permission issues, it’s best to use a Salesforce account with a “system admin” profile. Learn more about recommended Salesforce permissions . Access the Integration All your mappings are saved to the Salesforce account you connect to. If the logged-in Salesforce account is deactivated, their mappings will stop working. Make sure to use an integration Salesforce account if possible. You can connect multiple accounts, including sandbox environments. This process leverages OAuth 2.0 for a secure integration. This process leverages OAuth 2.0 for a secure integration. To access the integration: Sign in to the Salesforce account you want to connect to SurveyMonkey. In SurveyMonkey, select the Products icon and select Apps & Integrations . Select Salesforce . Select Connect or Connect Sandbox to connect your Salesforce account. If you’ve signed in to Salesforce, we’ll automatically connect to your signed-in account. Refreshing Sandbox environments : Your Salesforce connection will break when you refresh your sandbox environment. To keep your mappings, reconnect to your sandbox environment, then copy the mappings from your old connection to the new one. Connect Your Survey to the Integration To connect the survey you want to map to Salesforce: After adding your connection, select your username. On the My Mappings page, select Connect Survey . Select a survey title from the dropdown. You can connect any survey you own or that has been shared with you with full access. Surveys are listed by title, not by nickname. Select Next . How Mapping Works Mappings send your survey data back to Salesforce. You'll create mappings to send specific data, such as a response or survey metadata, to a Salesforce object. You can choose from two mapping types: Managed package : This convenient, out of the box option sets up object mapping for you, so you don’t need to build a custom object or fields in Salesforce to hold your response data. The mapping creates a separate SurveyMonkey Response record for each question answered – so if your survey has 5 questions, it creates 5 SurveyMonkey Response records. Learn more about our managed package . Custom object mapping : If you need more custom mapping, you can choose to map responses to a custom or standard object. You can use three different mapping actions: Create a new record, Update an existing record, or Update or create a record. For each mapping type, you can also select the following options: Sync partial responses to Salesforce : Each time a survey taker clicks Next to move on in the survey, each answered question on that page will sync, rather than syncing upon survey completion Disable active assignment rules on creating or updating Salesforce records : Active assignment rules aren't re-applied when Accounts, Cases, or Leads records are created or updated. Object Mapping Actions The table below describes the mapping actions you can use in your custom Object Mappings. Mapping Types After choosing your mapping action, you can set up your mapping. There are 3 mapping types you can use to map data to Salesforce. Create Mappings Build mappings for your survey. If you create mappings on a shared survey, the owner won’t be able to see your mappings. Create a New Record Create a new standard or custom object record every time someone submits a survey. To create new object records: Connect your survey to the Salesforce integration. Select Add Object Mapping or the Edit icon to review your mapping selections. In the first dropdown, select Create a new . Click Select object to choose the object you want to map your responses to. Select survey content or data to map to Salesforce. Map any survey questions and data to your object in Salesforce. You can select an existing or new Custom Variable to pass known info about a survey taker through your survey (for example, Account ID or Case ID). Certain Salesforce fields can only hold certain data types. Use our field mapping guide to make sure you map to compatible fields in Salesforce. If you see an exclamation mark icon, there may be an error with your mapping. Hover over the icon to review the error. Certain Salesforce fields can only hold certain data types. Use our field mapping guide to make sure you map to compatible fields in Salesforce. If you see an exclamation mark icon, there may be an error with your mapping. Hover over the icon to review the error. (Optional) Add more data to map to Salesforce. You can map any static value back to Salesforce, such as the survey language or locale. This value will be mapped every time someone takes your survey. Select Save Object . (Optional) Once back on the Object Mappings page, select Disable active assignment rules on creating or updating Salesforce records . Select Next . Update Existing Records Update an existing standard or custom object when someone submits a survey. You have two options: Update an existing : Find an existing record to update. If we can’t find an existing record, an error displays in the Audit Log. Update or create : Find an existing record to update. If we can’t find an existing record, we’ll create a new one. To update existing records: Connect your survey to the Salesforce integration. Click Add Object Mapping or the Edit icon to review your mapping selections. In the first dropdown, select whether to Update an existing record or Update or create . (Optional) Check the box to Replace any existing data in record fields . If you choose this option, we'll overwrite any existing values in your Salesforce fields with the survey data you map. Click Select object to choose the object you want to map your responses to. Add a query mapping . Query mappings, like a matching rule in Salesforce, tell SurveyMonkey how to find the record to update. Select the source for your mapping. It’s best to map a * New custom variable to the appropriate record ID in Salesforce. If you can't use a Salesforce record ID, you can use a field from your survey, like an email address, to find the matching record. However, the response will fail to sync if duplicate records are found. Select the Salesforce field you want to place this data in. Select the source for your mapping. It’s best to map a * New custom variable to the appropriate record ID in Salesforce. If you can't use a Salesforce record ID, you can use a field from your survey, like an email address, to find the matching record. However, the response will fail to sync if duplicate records are found. Select the Salesforce field you want to place this data in. Select survey content or data to map to Salesforce. Map any survey questions and data to your object in Salesforce. You can select an existing or new Custom Variable to pass known info about a survey taker through your survey (for example, Account ID or Case ID). Certain Salesforce fields can only hold certain data types. Use our field mapping guide to make sure you map to compatible fields in Salesforce. If you see an exclamation mark icon, there may be an error with your mapping. Hover over the icon to review the error. Certain Salesforce fields can only hold certain data types. Use our field mapping guide to make sure you map to compatible fields in Salesforce. If you see an exclamation mark icon, there may be an error with your mapping. Hover over the icon to review the error. (Optional) Add more data to map to Salesforce. You can map any static value back to Salesforce, such as the survey language or locale. This value will be mapped every time someone takes your survey. Click Save Object . (Optional) Once back on the Object Mappings page, click Disable active assignment rules on creating or updating Salesforce records . Click Next . Map to the SurveyMonkey Response Object Create a new SurveyMonkey Response object every time someone submits a survey. You’ll install our managed package to do this. The managed package makes it easy to send data to Salesforce and build Salesforce reports for survey responses . You can also customize Salesforce page layouts to better review survey data. You’ll download the managed package while in SurveyMonkey. You don’t need to download anything from the Salesforce App Exchange. To map to the SurveyMonkey Response object: Connect your survey to the Salesforce integration. Click Sync all responses to SurveyMonkey’s Response object . The first time you do this, you’re prompted to install the package in your Salesforce instance and provided with an installation link. When installing, we recommend selecting For All Users. (Optional) Click Disable active assignment rules on creating or updating Salesforce records . This only applies if your mapping is updating fields directly on the case object. Mapping the Response Object to Lookup Fields To relate the SurveyMonkey Response records to other records, add an object mapping. You’ll need to map to lookup fields on the SurveyMonkey Response object. Select Add Object Mapping or Edit to review your mapping selections. Click Select an Action , then select Update an Existing . Select Account , Case , Contact , Lead , or Opportunity . To associate your responses to a different object, you can add additional lookup fields to the SurveyMonkey Response object in your Salesforce setup. Add Query Mappings to tell Salesforce how to find the related records. Use a Custom Variable to pass the Record ID from Salesforce. (Optional) Add any survey field mappings to map survey fields to fields on this object. Click Save Object . (Optional) If you want to associate your survey responses to multiple objects, repeat steps 4 – 7. Once back on the Object Mappings page, click Next . Deployment Options Choose how to send your survey. You can use a Web Link pasted into your own email, or use a custom SurveyMonkey Email Invitation. There are 2 options you can use to send your survey. You can’t use a collector owned by someone else. If you want to use an existing collector, make sure to choose one that you created. Web link : Create a web link to send in an email from Salesforce or another provider. Web Links are easy to set up and allow you to use Advanced Logic and Piping to customize your survey questions with Salesforce data. However, you’ll need to build your own email template in Salesforce or your other email provider. Email invitation : Trigger a SurveyMonkey email invitation using a Salesforce flow. We'll help you create an Outbound Message in Salesforce. Then, you'll need to create a Salesforce flow to send your survey. Send a Web Link in an Email If you’re using Piping or Advanced Branching with custom variables, use the Web Link deployment option. A Web Link will let your Salesforce data inform your survey logic or customize your survey questions. To use a web link: Create your mapping . On the Deployment Options screen, select Web link . Then, select an existing collector or create a new one. Choose the object that will trigger your survey. Salesforce can send your survey when changes to an object meet certain criteria (for example, when a Case is closed or a Contact is 90 days old). You’ll use this object later when you create your Salesforce flow. If you're not sending your survey from Salesforce, select None. I'm not using Salesforce Flows to trigger my survey. Select Next . Select the Salesforce objects to map to any custom variables you added. When you send the survey from Salesforce, we’ll pull in data from these fields in your web link. We’ll also sync this data to SurveyMonkey so you can filter responses and pipe data into your survey. (Optional) Select Add data to add more fields to your survey link. Click Select data to choose your Salesforce field. Choose the object with the field you want, then select the field. Then, select Save . Select New custom variable to map the field to SurveyMonkey. Enter a Variable ID (this is visible in the survey URL). Then, enter a Variable label (a name for the variable so you can recognize it later). Then, select Save . Click Select data to choose your Salesforce field. Choose the object with the field you want, then select the field. Then, select Save . Select New custom variable to map the field to SurveyMonkey. Enter a Variable ID (this is visible in the survey URL). Then, enter a Variable label (a name for the variable so you can recognize it later). Then, select Save . When you’re ready, select Generate link . (Optional) If you want to hide custom variables from respondents, toggle on the Encrypt web link option and follow the instructions that appear on the screen. You’ll need to take several steps in Salesforce to set this up. This also protects your link so your customers can’t edit them. Learn more Copy the URL. It includes the custom variables you chose to map to the object. Go to Salesforce to complete the setup. Review the instructions below for help. Complete the Salesforce Setup If you’re sending your survey from Salesforce, create an email template and flow. You may need to contact your Salesforce admin for help. To set up your email in Salesforce: In Salesforce, build your email template and add your web link to the email body. Create an email alert using your email template. Make sure to use the object you chose to trigger your survey when you created your web link. Create a flow that sends your email alert when conditions are met. Make sure to use the object you chose to trigger your survey when you created your web link. Example : You want to trigger a survey when someone closes a case. When you build your flow, choose Case as the object to trigger your survey. Select the Case object for your email alert. In Salesforce, create a flow that sends your email when a Case status changes to Closed . When the email is sent, the custom variables in the survey link will populate with data for the person receiving the email. Send a SurveyMonkey Email Invitation To send an Email Invitation from the SurveyMonkey for Salesforce integration: Create your mapping . On the Deployment Options screen, select Email . Select the object that will trigger your survey. Salesforce can send your survey when changes to an object meet certain criteria (for example, when a Case is closed or a Contact is 90 days old). You’ll use this object later when you create your email message and Salesforce flow. Select Next . Select the field on your object that holds the recipient’s email address. We’ll use this field to send your survey to the right people. For example, on a Case object, you might choose the “Contact Email” field. Build your email: Subject : Enter a subject line for your email. Message format : Use our pre-built Template , or build a custom HTML message. Customize email header : Toggle this setting on to choose a custom background color, select a font, add a logo, and make other visual changes to the email header. Maximum length is 255 characters. Body : Enter the body text for your email message. Insert custom data : Personalize your email message with data from fields on your Salesforce object or your SurveyMonkey contacts. There’s a limit of 6 unique custom data tags, but you can use those tags as many times as you want. However, the Email, FirstName, and LastName fields from your SurveyMonkey contacts don’t count toward your total. Embed first question : Toggle on to put the first survey question directly in the email. Hide SurveyMonkey branding : Remove the SurveyMonkey logo from your email. Subject : Enter a subject line for your email. Message format : Use our pre-built Template , or build a custom HTML message. Customize email header : Toggle this setting on to choose a custom background color, select a font, add a logo, and make other visual changes to the email header. Maximum length is 255 characters. Body : Enter the body text for your email message. Insert custom data : Personalize your email message with data from fields on your Salesforce object or your SurveyMonkey contacts. There’s a limit of 6 unique custom data tags, but you can use those tags as many times as you want. However, the Email, FirstName, and LastName fields from your SurveyMonkey contacts don’t count toward your total. Embed first question : Toggle on to put the first survey question directly in the email. Hide SurveyMonkey branding : Remove the SurveyMonkey logo from your email. Select Preview email to view your message. If you’re happy with your email, select Next . Build your Salesforce outbound message. The outbound message tells SurveyMonkey when to send your email invitation. It includes the Salesforce data we need to send the email and map data back to Salesforce. Select the Salesforce objects to map to any custom variables you added. When you send the survey from Salesforce, we’ll pull in data from these fields in your outbound message. (Optional) Select +More data to add more fields to your outbound message. Click Select data to choose your Salesforce field. Choose the object with the field you want, then select the field. Then, select Save . Select New custom variable to map the field to SurveyMonkey. Enter a Variable ID (this is visible in the survey URL). Then, enter a Variable label (a name for the variable so you can recognize it later). Then, select Save . Select the Salesforce objects to map to any custom variables you added. When you send the survey from Salesforce, we’ll pull in data from these fields in your outbound message. (Optional) Select +More data to add more fields to your outbound message. Click Select data to choose your Salesforce field. Choose the object with the field you want, then select the field. Then, select Save . Select New custom variable to map the field to SurveyMonkey. Enter a Variable ID (this is visible in the survey URL). Then, enter a Variable label (a name for the variable so you can recognize it later). Then, select Save . Click Select data to choose your Salesforce field. Choose the object with the field you want, then select the field. Then, select Save . Select New custom variable to map the field to SurveyMonkey. Enter a Variable ID (this is visible in the survey URL). Then, enter a Variable label (a name for the variable so you can recognize it later). Then, select Save . When you’re done, select Build in Salesforce . We’ll create your outbound message in Salesforce. In Salesforce, create a flow to send your outbound message. Include the object you chose to trigger your survey. For example, if you chose the Case object to trigger your survey, create a flow for the Case object. Save and test your flow. You can immediately check your collector in SurveyMonkey to confirm an email invitation is pending. (Optional) Set up reminder and thank-you emails in your collector options . These can help increase your response rates by reminding respondents to take your survey. Updating Your Email Message To change your email message after your collector has received responses: In SurveyMonkey, go back to the Salesforce integration. Find the mapping for your survey. Select the 3 dots menu, then select Edit . Go to the Deployment Options step. Select Next . Edit your email. Don’t edit or send the email from your survey’s collector options. This can cause your custom data fields and the email automation to fail. Use the Salesforce integration to edit your email. Troubleshooting Email Invitations There are a few common errors with email invitations. Here are a few things to try to fix email invitation issues. Make sure your Salesforce account has permissions to send Outbound Messages. Check your Outbound Message in Salesforce. If you see an error, confirm that your endpoint URL is correct. This should be the link you got in the last distribution step in SurveyMonkey. Make sure the right fields were added to the Outbound Message. Some fields have similar names. Including the wrong field can cause the flow to fail. Test Your Survey and Mappings Take a test version of your survey to make sure your mappings work correctly. You can review mapping errors in the Audit Log. Select Mappings near the top of the page to see a survey's audit logs or errors. You can select the iAudit log icon to view your successful syncs or select the !Error icon to view an error description. Share Mappings with Your Team Shared Mappings give your team visibility into your survey mappings for better collaboration. Share Mappings To let your team access your survey and mappings: From SurveyMonkey, share your mapped survey with your team members. Make sure you give Full Access permissions to the Design Survey section. From the SurveyMonkey for Salesforce integration, go to My Mappings and click the Shared toggle for surveys you want to make available. Don't see the Shared column in My Mappings? Contact your CSM to activate the feature for your team. View Shared Mappings To view the team's shared mappings, hover over the down arrow next to Connected Accounts or My Mappings and select Shared Mappings . Team members can Edit Shared Mappings but can't view the deployment options page. To get the invitation URL, team members can contact the survey owner. Copy Mappings to Another Account If you build mappings in a Sandbox account, you can copy them over to a production account. To copy mappings: If you haven't already, add a connection for your other Salesforce account. On the My Mappings page, check the box for the survey you want to copy. Select Copy to Account . Select the account to copy your mapping to. Select OK . Common Questions How do I tie my responses to a specific record in Salesforce? First, check that you included Custom Variables in your survey mapping —either your survey field mapping or query mapping, depending on your mapping action. If your variables are mapped, the merge fields in your survey URL may need to be updated if your sending platform's {Merge field} differs from Salesforce. For example, Pardot uses different merge fields than Salesforce. Check the {Merge field} in the survey URL and replace it with the correct merge field from your sending platform. If you’re sending an Email Invitation, contact your CSM for assistance. First, check that you included Custom Variables in your survey mapping —either your survey field mapping or query mapping, depending on your mapping action. If your variables are mapped, the merge fields in your survey URL may need to be updated if your sending platform's {Merge field} differs from Salesforce. For example, Pardot uses different merge fields than Salesforce. Check the {Merge field} in the survey URL and replace it with the correct merge field from your sending platform. If you’re sending an Email Invitation, contact your CSM for assistance. Will survey responses collected before I connected the integration populate in Salesforce? No—only responses that you collect after the integration is connected can be mapped to Salesforce. No—only responses that you collect after the integration is connected can be mapped to Salesforce. How do we keep the responses sync active if the user that set up the mappings leaves the company? Don't delete a SurveyMonkey account or a Salesforce connection with an active Salesforce mapping, as this deletes the mappings permanently and survey data won't sync to Salesforce. Instead, if necessary, first reassign the SurveyMonkey account—this maintains all survey and integration data in the account. If the Salesforce connection a mapping is set up under will be deactivated, to avoid data loss, copy the mappings over to a new Salesforce connection/account. To copy mappings over to a new Salesforce account: Add a new Salesforce connection by logging into Salesforce and selecting Add account on the integration page (the Salesforce user you are logged in as will be added). Go to Connected Accounts and select the username of the original Salesforce connection. Select survey mappings and Copy to Account . Select the new Salesforce connection. The survey mappings are copied to the new connection. This doesn't include the sync data for original mapping. You can now safely delete the original Salesforce connection or deactivate the user. Don't delete a SurveyMonkey account or a Salesforce connection with an active Salesforce mapping, as this deletes the mappings permanently and survey data won't sync to Salesforce. Instead, if necessary, first reassign the SurveyMonkey account—this maintains all survey and integration data in the account. If the Salesforce connection a mapping is set up under will be deactivated, to avoid data loss, copy the mappings over to a new Salesforce connection/account. To copy mappings over to a new Salesforce account: Add a new Salesforce connection by logging into Salesforce and selecting Add account on the integration page (the Salesforce user you are logged in as will be added). Go to Connected Accounts and select the username of the original Salesforce connection. Select survey mappings and Copy to Account . Select the new Salesforce connection. The survey mappings are copied to the new connection. This doesn't include the sync data for original mapping. You can now safely delete the original Salesforce connection or deactivate the user. title: Zendesk Integration
body: Zendesk Integration Use the SurveyMonkey App to Send Surveys to a Customer List Sending a Survey and Mapping Responses Adding SurveyMonkey to an Automated Zendesk Email Zendesk Integration Zendesk Integration Use the SurveyMonkey App to Send Surveys to a Customer List Sending a Survey and Mapping Responses Adding SurveyMonkey to an Automated Zendesk Email SurveyMonkey's integration with Zendesk lets you send SurveyMonkey surveys to your Zendesk customers. If you're a Zendesk Administrator, you can also use the integration to save survey data in custom fields on contacts. The SurveyMonkey Zendesk integration allows you to: Select a list of customers from Zendesk to survey based on filters you define Select an existing survey, or a template Send a composed email with a survey link from within Zendesk Install the integration from our App Directory . The integration setup is only available in English. Install the SurveyMonkey App To install the SurveyMonkey app: Log into Zendesk. Click the Admin icon in the navigation bar. Under Apps, click Browse . Find and click the SurveyMonkey app. On the SurveyMonkey app page, click Install app in the upper right corner. On the installation page, click Log in with SurveyMonkey . Follow the on-screen instructions to authenticate the request. Click Install . When the installation is complete, refresh Zendesk to see the SurveyMonkey icon in the left-hand navigation bar. You can limit which agents see this app by clicking Enable role restrictions? and selecting the appropriate role. Sending a Survey and Mapping Responses Only Zendesk Administrators can map survey data to contact fields. Agents do not have access to this feature. Zendesk Agents and Administrators can quickly send surveys to any customer list. To send a survey: Click on the integration in your Zendesk menu, select a list to send your survey to. Select the survey you'd like to send by clicking on it's title in the table and clicking Next at the bottom of the table. If you're an admin, you'll be given the option to sync your survey with your contacts. This step lets you store all or part of the survey response in Zendesk as custom fields for users . Zendesk will store the most recent responses for customers who take your survey more than once. There are two ways you can choose to map: Sync All : Select this option if you'd like to store the entire response on your contacts. This option automatically create custom fields for each question when the first response comes into your survey. Sync Partial : Select this option if you'd like to store on part of your surveys response on your contacts. This option let's you choose individual survey fields and select which custom user fields you'd like to use to store them in. To use partial syncing you'll need to have your custom fields setup before you start the mapping process. Sync All : Select this option if you'd like to store the entire response on your contacts. This option automatically create custom fields for each question when the first response comes into your survey. Sync Partial : Select this option if you'd like to store on part of your surveys response on your contacts. This option let's you choose individual survey fields and select which custom user fields you'd like to use to store them in. To use partial syncing you'll need to have your custom fields setup before you start the mapping process. Click Skip Mapping to skip this step. The preview step shows you a preview of your email invitation. You can click Edit to edit the html of your invitation in SurveyMonkey. If the email looks good to you, click Send Email to send your survey. Adding SurveyMonkey to an Automated Zendesk Email You can use SurveyMonkey and Zendesk together to trigger instant feedback with SurveyMonkey customer satisfaction surveys. Automatically Send a Survey When a Ticket is Solved To send a SurveyMonkey survey to Zendesk customers when their ticket has been marked as Solved: In SurveyMonkey, create a customer satisfaction survey or use one of our pre-written templates. Create a web link collector . This will generate a survey link that you can include in your Zendesk notification email to customers. Log into Zendesk. Open the Admin center . In the left-hand rail, under BUSINESS RULES , click Triggers . Next to "Notify requester of solved request", click edit . Configure the conditions under which you would like the notification to be sent to customers. In the "Perform these actions:" section, you can customize the body of the email that will be sent to customers when the above conditions are met. Paste your SurveyMonkey web link URL into the Email body and customize the message to meet your needs. TIP: Use Zendesk's placeholders to append Custom Variables to the end of your survey link. This will allow you to pass data about the respondent from Zendesk into the contact's SurveyMonkey response. title: SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Mapping Multiple Surveys to a Custom Salesforce Object
body: SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Mapping Multiple Surveys to a Custom Salesforce Object Build Page Layouts Create Record Types Map to a Record Type in SurveyMonkey SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Mapping Multiple Surveys to a Custom Salesforce Object SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Mapping Multiple Surveys to a Custom Salesforce Object Build Page Layouts Create Record Types Map to a Record Type in SurveyMonkey Get the integration ! SurveyMonkey for Salesforce is an Enterprise add-on. Contact Sales or your Customer Success Manager (CSM). Limitation: The integration setup is only available in English. The SurveyMonkey for Salesforce integration allows you to map survey data to fields on Salesforce objects. However, if you map multiple surveys to the same custom object, you may end up with blank fields and missing information. You can adjust your object’s page layout to make sure your data displays correctly. To organize a custom object, you can create Record Types in Salesforce. Record types are like mini page layouts, where certain fields can be hidden from view depending on the chosen layout. For this example, we'll map 3 surveys into the same custom object. These surveys will be called “Customer Service Feedback,” “Trip Feedback,” and “Case Closure.” Build Page Layouts First, you’ll need to create a few page layouts in Salesforce for your custom object. You'll use these page layouts to create record types later. Create the following page layouts: A “primary layout” that includes every field you’ve added. A separate layout for each survey you’re mapping to the object. Each layout should contain only the fields you’re mapping that survey to. In this example, we create 4 page layouts: a primary layout, a Customer Service Feedback layout, a Trip Feedback layout, and a Case Closure layout. Create Record Types After creating your page layouts, create a record type for each page layout. From Setup in Salesforce, go to your object, then select Record Types . Follow this guidance when creating the record types: You’ll need to select an existing record type to create a new one. If you don’t have any, you can use the Master type. Make the record type available for any profile that has access to your survey data. You don’t have to check the Active box yet, but the layouts won’t work until you activate them. On the second page, select the page layout to use for your record type. Repeat the process to create a record type for each page layout you created. Map to a Record Type in SurveyMonkey Finally, map responses from your survey to the appropriate record types in Salesforce. To choose record types in SurveyMonkey: Go to the Salesforce Integration . Connect your account and survey if you haven't already. Create a new mapping . Map all of your responses to the custom object. Under Add more data , map the record type ID to the Record Type ID field as a static value. Select Save object to save your mapping. Repeat for each survey you’re mapping to the custom object. Once you create your mappings, submit a few test survey responses to make sure the responses display correctly in your Record Types.
