title: SurveyMonkey Audience Custom Balancing
body: SurveyMonkey Audience Custom Balancing SurveyMonkey Audience Custom Balancing SurveyMonkey Audience Custom Balancing Custom balancing lets you choose the breakdown of your responses in a SurveyMonkey Audience project. When you're getting responses from our Contribute, Rewards, or Global panel, you can use custom balancing to choose the distribution of completed responses you want from each gender or age group you're targeting. For example, get 80% of your completed responses from female respondents and 20% from male respondents. To use custom balancing: Create a Targeted Audience collector. Under Basic Demographics, click Age or Gender . Choose the Custom option. Any previously selected age or gender criteria is removed so you can use the custom balancing tool. For Gender , use the slider scale to pick the percentage of responses you want from males and females. For Age , click Edit and enter the minimum and maximum age range for each group you're looking to survey. You can target 2–8 different age groups. Next enter the percentage of complete responses you want from each group (the percentages must total 100%). Each age range should be 5 years or more (18–23 works, but 18–21 doesn't), and age groups can't overlap (you can't have both 18-30 and 25-35 as age groups). Click Save once you're done. Take a look at your Project Details on the right side of the page to review your custom balancing selections and the additional cost per response. TIP! Custom balancing restricts the pool of available people to take your survey, so you may have to buy a larger number of completed responses than you need. The exact number is variable and depends on: the number of age group, the size of each age group, the percentage of responses for each age group, and any custom gender balancing. Completed Responses Due to the nature of the system, the variability of response rates, and natural margin of error, we can't guarantee that you'll get the exact number of completed responses that you specified per gender and age. There's a fault tolerance of ±5 responses per gender group and age group. Read more about completed responses . Using Both Age and Gender Balancing You can use both custom age and gender balancing at the same time. When you do that, we combine the percentage of both gender and age balancing to determine the distribution of responses from each gender against each age group. Let's say you're buying 500 completed responses and choose the following custom gender and age balancing settings: Gender : Female 75%, Male 25% Age : 18–29: 30%, When you do that, we combine the percentage of both gender and age balancing to determine the number of completed responses your project will receive: 70% With these custom gender and age balancing options, the system calculates how many responses each gender + age group will get like this: Completed Responses (500) * Female Responses (75%) * 18-29 Age Group (30%) = 113 responses Completed Responses (500) * Female Responses (75%) * 30–39 Age Group (70%) = 263 responses Completed Responses (500) * Male Responses (25%) * 18-29 Age Group (30%) = 38 responses Completed Responses (500) * Male Responses (25%) * 30–39 Age Group (70%) = 88 responses Related Articles Company SurveyMonkey About Us Jobs Blog Help SurveyMonkey Help GetFeedback Help Market Research Help SurveyMonkey Audience Help SurveyMonkey Contribute Help Wufoo Help Apply Help Support Site Status Unsubscribe Contact Us Email Opt-In Policies Legal Center Privacy Policy Cookies Notice California Privacy Notice

title: Using SurveyMonkey for Market Research
body: Using SurveyMonkey for Market Research Getting Started Designing Your Survey Using Market Research Solutions Collecting Responses Analyzing Results Using SurveyMonkey for Market Research Using SurveyMonkey for Market Research Getting Started Designing Your Survey Using Market Research Solutions Collecting Responses Analyzing Results Learn the tips and tricks to conducting market research surveys with SurveyMonkey Audience so you can get the answers you need. Whether you want to keep existing customers or gain new business, you’ll need the right data to back you up. These resources will help you make sure your market research survey is on the right track. Getting Started Get started using SurveyMonkey Audience to do market research. Learn how to do market research Doing market research for the first time? Check out our comprehensive guide on how to do market research . This guide can help you: Get an introduction to market research concepts Learn how to plan your own project Find tips on survey design Learn how to target the right people Understand survey analysis Find out how to act on survey results Once you feel comfortable planning a study, you can start creating your survey . When reviewing data from your Audience survey, contact us before deleting responses. We can replace responses that we confirm are low quality. Doing market research for the first time? Check out our comprehensive guide on how to do market research . This guide can help you: Get an introduction to market research concepts Learn how to plan your own project Find tips on survey design Learn how to target the right people Understand survey analysis Find out how to act on survey results Once you feel comfortable planning a study, you can start creating your survey . When reviewing data from your Audience survey, contact us before deleting responses. We can replace responses that we confirm are low quality. Reach a target audience Learn how to use our SurveyMonkey Audience panel to reach your target audience. How to Reach a Target Audience Buying Responses with SurveyMonkey Audience Learn how to use our SurveyMonkey Audience panel to reach your target audience. How to Reach a Target Audience Buying Responses with SurveyMonkey Audience Manage your SurveyMonkey team (Administrators) Managing market research projects and credits across a team? Use our administrator guides to help you set up your team. Seats, roles and permissions Managing seats Understanding Audience credits Managing market research projects and credits across a team? Use our administrator guides to help you set up your team. Seats, roles and permissions Managing seats Understanding Audience credits (optional) Purchase Audience Credits You can pre-purchase Audience Credits to use for your Audience projects. Credits allow you to pay in advance for Audience responses and our market research solutions . When you check out, you can pay with Credits instead of a credit or debit card. You can pre-purchase Audience Credits to use for your Audience projects. Credits allow you to pay in advance for Audience responses and our market research solutions . When you check out, you can pay with Credits instead of a credit or debit card. Learn how other companies use SurveyMonkey Audience Want examples of how other companies use SurveyMonkey Audience to do market research? Learn how JUST uses SurveyMonkey Audience to get quick, valuable market insights and better understand their target audience. Want examples of how other companies use SurveyMonkey Audience to do market research? Learn how JUST uses SurveyMonkey Audience to get quick, valuable market insights and better understand their target audience. Designing Your Survey There are a few requirements to follow when you send your survey through our Audience panel. You can also use a few tips to make your survey more engaging and increase your response rate. Requirements when using SurveyMonkey Audience When you use our Audience panel, your survey needs to follow certain guidelines. If a survey doesn't meet these requirements, the project may be paused and stop collecting responses. Here are a few requirements: Make sure your survey has less than 80 questions. Make at least one question required. Remove any links that direct people to another website. Delete questions asking people for contact info like email, phone number or address. Review the rest of our SurveyMonkey Audience Design Guidelines while designing your survey. Refunds are not available for surveys that don't follow our design guidelines. Surveys that include Personal Identifiable Information (PII) or have logic loops won't be refunded. When you use our Audience panel, your survey needs to follow certain guidelines. If a survey doesn't meet these requirements, the project may be paused and stop collecting responses. Here are a few requirements: Make sure your survey has less than 80 questions. Make at least one question required. Remove any links that direct people to another website. Delete questions asking people for contact info like email, phone number or address. Review the rest of our SurveyMonkey Audience Design Guidelines while designing your survey. Refunds are not available for surveys that don't follow our design guidelines. Surveys that include Personal Identifiable Information (PII) or have logic loops won't be refunded. Best practices for survey design There are a few things you can do to get a higher response rate: Start general, then get specific . Ask more general questions first, then add more specific questions. Add detailed follow-up questions at the end. Keep your survey short - ideally 30 questions or fewer. People are more likely to complete a shorter survey and often give higher quality responses. Check for bias . Make sure you don't ask any leading questions in your survey. Test your survey . Always take your survey before sending it to others. This helps you make sure there aren't any issues before sending it to your audience. Learn more about creating a great survey . There are a few things you can do to get a higher response rate: Start general, then get specific . Ask more general questions first, then add more specific questions. Add detailed follow-up questions at the end. Keep your survey short - ideally 30 questions or fewer. People are more likely to complete a shorter survey and often give higher quality responses. Check for bias . Make sure you don't ask any leading questions in your survey. Test your survey . Always take your survey before sending it to others. This helps you make sure there aren't any issues before sending it to your audience. Learn more about creating a great survey . How long will it take to get my results? The time it takes to get results will vary based on your survey design. It can take longer to get results if your survey has any of the following: 50+ questions of any type 5+ open-ended questions Dropdown questions Block randomization Niche targeting The time it takes to get results will vary based on your survey design. It can take longer to get results if your survey has any of the following: 50+ questions of any type 5+ open-ended questions Dropdown questions Block randomization Niche targeting Using Market Research Solutions You don't always have to start your survey from scratch. SurveyMonkey offers several purpose-built market research solutions to help you get the insights you need in less time. Each solution includes unique analysis features to help you get the most out of your survey data. Idea Screening Solution ( Try it ) - Test your ideas early with your target audience. Feature Importance (MaxDiff) Solution ( Try it ) - Figure out what products, features, or attributes matter most to your target audience using MaxDiff (maximum difference) methodology. Price Optimization Solution ( Try it ) - Find the ideal price point for your product or service using the Van Westendorp methodology. Creative and Concept Testing Solutions ( Try it ) - Test ads, videos, logos, and more with your target audience. Collecting Responses When you're done designing your survey, you can start collecting responses. SurveyMonkey Audience offers comprehensive targeting options to make sure you can reach your ideal audience. Our panels are representative of a diverse online population that voluntarily joined a program to take surveys. The project cost depends on factors like who you want to survey to and how many responses you need. Use our quote calculator to estimate how much your final project will cost. Setting up a Target Audience collector To buy responses through SurveyMonkey Audience: After you create your survey , go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Choose Buy Responses . Set up targeting options, add screening questions, and set the number of responses you need. Learn more about buying responses with SurveyMonkey Audience . To buy responses through SurveyMonkey Audience: After you create your survey , go to the Collect Responses section of your survey. Choose Buy Responses . Set up targeting options, add screening questions, and set the number of responses you need. Learn more about buying responses with SurveyMonkey Audience . Estimating qualification rate / incidence rate If your survey has a screening question with disqualification logic, you need to select a qualification rate before completing your order. The qualification rate is the estimated percentage of people you expect to qualify for your survey based on your screening questions. Your qualification rate affects the number of people we send your survey to. Learn more It's important to do independent research to estimate your qualification rate. There are a few tips you can use: Check your company's market research data . Many companies already know roughly what to expect. Try asking colleagues if they know who would have access to data like this. Do some quick research online . If you're targeting a well-researched population, there may be industry evidence documented online. Run a small test project . You can get a better idea (within a margin of error of +/- 10%) of the qualification rate by surveying just 100 people. This strategy works best if you plan on buying a larger sample and don't mind spending a smaller amount to get a better idea of what your qualification rate might be. It's better to estimate a lower qualification rate than you expect to improve the chances of getting the number of complete responses you need. We aren't able to offer a refund if you misestimated your qualification rate. The qualification rate is the estimated percentage of people you expect to qualify for your survey based on your screening questions. Your qualification rate affects the number of people we send your survey to. Learn more It's important to do independent research to estimate your qualification rate. There are a few tips you can use: Check your company's market research data . Many companies already know roughly what to expect. Try asking colleagues if they know who would have access to data like this. Do some quick research online . If you're targeting a well-researched population, there may be industry evidence documented online. Run a small test project . You can get a better idea (within a margin of error of +/- 10%) of the qualification rate by surveying just 100 people. This strategy works best if you plan on buying a larger sample and don't mind spending a smaller amount to get a better idea of what your qualification rate might be. It's better to estimate a lower qualification rate than you expect to improve the chances of getting the number of complete responses you need. We aren't able to offer a refund if you misestimated your qualification rate. Need more advanced targeting? If you need more advanced targeting, you can still use SurveyMonkey to design your survey and analyze your responses. Create a web link for your survey, then send it through a third party panel. Your responses will be visible in Analyze . If you need more advanced targeting, you can still use SurveyMonkey to design your survey and analyze your responses. Create a web link for your survey, then send it through a third party panel. Your responses will be visible in Analyze . Analyzing Results Dive into your results to understand how your target audience feels. There are a few steps you should take when analyzing your survey results. Clean your data It's important to remove unhelpful responses before analyzing your results. There are a few things you can do to clean your data: If you're sending your survey through our Audience panel, contact us . We can replace responses that we confirm are low quality. If you're not using our Audience panel, you can hide responses from people who don't meet your target audience or didn't answer thoughtfully. Learn more about cleaning your data . It's important to remove unhelpful responses before analyzing your results. There are a few things you can do to clean your data: If you're sending your survey through our Audience panel, contact us . We can replace responses that we confirm are low quality. If you're not using our Audience panel, you can hide responses from people who don't meet your target audience or didn't answer thoughtfully. Learn more about cleaning your data . Filtering and comparing data Use filter and compare rules to dig deeper into your data. Filter rules allow you to break down your survey results and focus on specific parts of your data. For example, you can filter by question and answer to view respondents who answered a question a certain way. Compare rules let you choose two or more answer options from a single question and view them side-by-side. For example, if you include a question in your survey asking people what age they are, you can create a compare rule to view the survey results for each age range. Learn more about filtering and comparing results in SurveyMonkey. Use filter and compare rules to dig deeper into your data. Compare rules let you choose two or more answer options from a single question and view them side-by-side. For example, if you include a question in your survey asking people what age they are, you can create a compare rule to view the survey results for each age range. title: Idea Screening Solution
body: Idea Screening Solution How to Set up Your Idea Screening Setting Up Your Stimuli Setting Up Your Survey Previewing Your Survey Collecting Responses How to Analyze Your Data Idea Screening Solution Idea Screening Solution How to Set up Your Idea Screening Setting Up Your Stimuli Setting Up Your Survey Previewing Your Survey Collecting Responses How to Analyze Your Data ADD-ON FEATURE : You can use this solution with any SurveyMonkey plan type. Get started now , or explore our market research solutions . This solution is available for US Data Center accounts only. Idea Screening lets you quickly test and rank early stage product, marketing, or brand creative ideas so you know which are best to invest in. Let’s say you're a marketer and you need to present new ad ideas to your team. However, you want to narrow those ideas down from 10 to 3, and your meeting is in 2 hours. With Idea Screening, you can quickly upload your ad ideas, choose your target audience, and get results in a presentation-ready report before your meeting. How to Set up Your Idea Screening With Idea Screening, respondents give feedback on your text, image, or video idea, also called stimuli. You can add 2 to 30 text, image, or video stimuli, and each respondent will see up to 5 stimuli. Measure your idea through attributes like first reaction and purchase intent. Attributes are pre-written, industry standard questions created specifically for idea screening and concept testing. The 5-point Likert scale question, "How likely are you to purchase this product?" and the open-ended question, "What do you like most about this product?" are examples. You can create your own custom attributes and add questions before or after your respondent sees your stimuli. Visit our Market Research Solutions page to create your Idea Screening study. Once created, your study is available from the My S u rveys page in your account. Add-on Purchase: For assistance customizing your Idea Screening study, including adding multiple languages, different question types, or reaching a hard-to-reach audience, we can help! Contact our team Setting Up Your Stimuli Adding an image or video with a text description gives your survey takers the most information about your product, service, or messaging. To add your stimulus content: Visit our Market Research Solutions page to Get Started on an Idea Screening study. Select +Add stimulus content . Create a nickname for your text, image, or video stimuli. The nickname is only visible to you. Use the rich text editor to add your stimuli and descriptor: Text: Use the options such as bold, underline, font size, bullet points, and tables to format your text . Image: Select the Image icon, then choose the General or Upload option to add your image and Save . Video: Select the Media icon, then choose the General or Embed option to add a Vimeo or YouTube video and Save . Text: Use the options such as bold, underline, font size, bullet points, and tables to format your text . Image: Select the Image icon, then choose the General or Upload option to add your image and Save . Video: Select the Media icon, then choose the General or Embed option to add a Vimeo or YouTube video and Save . Select OK . (Optional) Repeat steps 2 - 5 to add more stimuli to test. Choose the number of stimuli for each respondent to see. Choose the number of responses per stimulus. Total number of responses are calculated by: # of total stimuli / (# of stimuli respondents see * # of responses per stimulus) Total number of responses are calculated by: # of total stimuli / (# of stimuli respondents see * # of responses per stimulus) At the bottom of the screen, review the summary and the subtotal. Select Next to set up your Target Audience . Setting Up Your Survey To set up your survey: Toggle the Show instructions option on or off. If on, enter the instructions you want respondents to read before seeing the stimuli. In the Attributes section, drag and drop attributes in the order you like. You can select Add attributes to include other standard or custom attributes, or hover over an attribute to Remove it. Attribute questions display below each stimulus within your survey. You can add up to 15 attributes if you have less than 20 stimuli. If you have more than 20 stimuli, you can add up to 7 attributes. Change the term used in the question via the open-ended box. To view details about the question the respondent will see, select the Expand icon to the right of each question. You can add up to 15 attributes if you have less than 20 stimuli. If you have more than 20 stimuli, you can add up to 7 attributes. Change the term used in the question via the open-ended box. To view details about the question the respondent will see, select the Expand icon to the right of each question. Click Save . At the bottom of the screen, review the screening summary and subtotal. Select Next to preview your survey. Previewing Your Survey To preview your survey: Take the survey in the preview. By default, the preview shows you a subset of stimuli, like respondents see, but if you want to view all stimuli, click the toggle on to View all stimuli in the preview . Click the Device views to see how your survey looks on desktop, tablet, or mobile screens. By default, the preview shows you a subset of stimuli, like respondents see, but if you want to view all stimuli, click the toggle on to View all stimuli in the preview . Click the Device views to see how your survey looks on desktop, tablet, or mobile screens. (Optional) Select Style to change the color theme that respondents see. At the bottom of the screen, review the summary and subtotal. Select Next to check out. TIP! You can use the Back button at the bottom of the screen to change the setup of your Idea Screening study at any time before checkout. Collecting Responses When you’re ready to send your survey, select the Collect icon from the left-side menu. There are two ways to collect responses: Share a survey link : Create a web link to send your survey to your own audience. This feature is only available on certain plans. Target your ideal respondents : Buy responses from certain demographics using the SurveyMonkey Audience panel. This feature is available on all plans. You can create multiple collectors for your study. Share a Survey Link PAID FEATURE: Web Link collector for this solution is available on any paid plan . Free plans can use SurveyMonkey Audience to collect responses. Create a web link that you can send your way. To share a survey link: On the Collect page, select Add new collector , then select Web link collector . Customize your Web link settings. You can: Set a custom survey end page Allow multiple responses Set a cutoff date and time Set response limits Set a custom survey end page Allow multiple responses Set a cutoff date and time Set response limits Copy your web link when you’re ready to send your survey. Target your Ideal Respondents SurveyMonkey Audience panelists have been sorted based on hundreds of targeting options so you can target your respondents based on country, demographics, employment status, hobbies, religion, and more. To choose your target audience: On the Collect page, select Add new collector , then select Buy Responses Select your target audience by choosing Country , Gender , Age , and Income criteria. Select More Targeting Options to browse and choose from hundreds of other targeting options. (Optional) Select whether to add a screening question to narrow down your target audience and disqualify people who aren't the best fit for your survey. If you add a screening question, estimate how many people you expect to qualify for your survey. Add a qualifying question to the beginning of your survey. We recommend either Multiple Choice or Checkboxes. Add skip logic that disqualifies people if they select certain answer choices. Return to the Target audience setup page to estimate your Qualification Rate. Add a qualifying question to the beginning of your survey. We recommend either Multiple Choice or Checkboxes. Add skip logic that disqualifies people if they select certain answer choices. Return to the Target audience setup page to estimate your Qualification Rate. Review your target audience summary and click Checkout . Checkout To checkout your study: Review the details of your order. Under Payment Method , select to pay with Credit or Debit Card , or with My Credits . Enter your Billing Details , review the total, and select Confirm . How to Analyze Your Data Idea Screening provides you with instant insights and automated analysis capabilities. Scorecards show statistical significance and compile results in a single visual. AI-powered insights surface which ideas scored best, or worst with different groups of respondents. Also, presentation-ready PowerPoint exports make sharing your findings easy. Viewing Survey Responses You can view a comparison of your survey results or browse through individual responses. Comparison Viewing Comparison, the default Analyze view, gives you an overview of the Summary Scorecard and each Attribute. Comparison What You See Summary Scorecard A breakdown showing how each of your stimuli scored by attribute. Boxes in blue are rated with the most statistical significance and the letters show which ideas we identify significance over. Use the drop-down menu to change between your top two and bottom two box scores. Attribute Scorecard Displays the top two and bottom two scores associated with each answer choice for each question. Boxes in blue are rated with most confidence. Open-ended responses show as a word cloud. Use the drop-down menu to sort through each stimulus. Select Modify Range to change the total number of words in the cloud. You may notice the number of respondents viewing each stimulus may vary. Idea screening uses block randomization so variation is expected. Statistical Significance Idea screening uses the McNemar's test, which is a method for calculating statistical significance based on respondent's seeing multiple stimuli. A statistically significant difference tells you whether one group's answers are substantially different from another group's answers by using statistical testing. Statistical significance means that the numbers are reliably different, greatly aiding your data analysis. You should consider whether the results are important, as it's up to you to decide how to interpret or take action on your results. Confidence Level The confidence level is the likelihood that your sample audience accurately reflects the attitudes of the group you selected. SurveyMonkey recommends a confidence level of 95%, which is most commonly used. Change the confidence level on the top right of the Analysis page. Comparison and Custom Question Data If you included comparison or custom questions in your survey, your data appears below the Summary Scorecard. Viewing Comparison, the default Analyze view, gives you an overview of the Summary Scorecard and each Attribute. You may notice the number of respondents viewing each stimulus may vary. Idea screening uses block randomization so variation is expected. Statistical Significance Idea screening uses the McNemar's test, which is a method for calculating statistical significance based on respondent's seeing multiple stimuli. A statistically significant difference tells you whether one group's answers are substantially different from another group's answers by using statistical testing. Statistical significance means that the numbers are reliably different, greatly aiding your data analysis. You should consider whether the results are important, as it's up to you to decide how to interpret or take action on your results. Confidence Level The confidence level is the likelihood that your sample audience accurately reflects the attitudes of the group you selected. SurveyMonkey recommends a confidence level of 95%, which is most commonly used. Change the confidence level on the top right of the Analysis page. Comparison and Custom Question Data If you included comparison or custom questions in your survey, your data appears below the Summary Scorecard. Individual Responses Viewing Individual Responses shows each respondent's complete set of answers to your survey. Each individual response includes respondent metadata and demographics, and survey-taking metrics. To browse, select the Individual Responses tab. Use the menu at the top left to sort by stimuli. Viewing Individual Responses shows each respondent's complete set of answers to your survey. Each individual response includes respondent metadata and demographics, and survey-taking metrics. To browse, select the Individual Responses tab. Use the menu at the top left to sort by stimuli. Filtering Your Results Filtering allows you to show responses that match your filter criteria and hide the rest. Recommended filters through AI-powered Insights focus on segments of your data where we think you'll find interesting information. You can only apply 1 filter at a time. Create Your Own Filters To create your own filters: Select +Create Filter in the Filters section. Choose the Basic demographics you want to filter. Select the Advanced tab to filter by specific criteria and logic. Use the +And or +Or buttons to add more criteria and logic to the filter. Add a name for your filter and select Apply . To create your own filters: Select +Create Filter in the Filters section. Choose the Basic demographics you want to filter. Select the Advanced tab to filter by specific criteria and logic. Use the +And or +Or buttons to add more criteria and logic to the filter. Add a name for your filter and select Apply . Create Filters with AI-powered Insights To apply recommended filters: Select Explore all insights from the Filters section. In the Stimuli section, choose the stimuli to filter by. From the Score menu, choose to display all results, results that scored well, or results that didn't score well. Select Apply filter on a recommended insight. You can edit, delete, and toggle the filter on and off in the Filters section, or select the X next to the applied filter to remove it. To apply recommended filters: Select Explore all insights from the Filters section. In the Stimuli section, choose the stimuli to filter by. From the Score menu, choose to display all results, results that scored well, or results that didn't score well. Select Apply filter on a recommended insight. You can edit, delete, and toggle the filter on and off in the Filters section, or select the X next to the applied filter to remove it. Exporting Your Data You can export raw data in Excel or SPSS to analyze offline, or use presentation-ready, customizable PowerPoint exports to share with your stakeholders. To export your data: Select Export . Choose PPT , XLSX , SPSS , or CSV format. Select Current View if filter rules are applied or Original View if no rules are applied. Name your file and select Export . TIP! Once you've refined your product ideas, check out our other Market Research Solutions for further insights. title: Response Rate
body: Response Rate Response Rate Response Rate Your response rate is the percentage of people who respond to your survey. To calculate the response rate percentage for your survey, use the following equation: You can find the total number of responses in the Analyze Results section of your survey. To calculate your response rate based on the number of complete responses to your survey, filter by completeness and select Complete responses . The number of complete responses appears at the top of the page when the filter is applied. TIP! Learn how to calculate the number of respondents you need or use our sample size calculator . Improving Your Response Rate If a large number of respondents don't respond to your survey, or they exit or abandon your survey before completing it, you'll have a low response rate. In general, you can expect a low response rate if your survey is long, your survey language is complicated, or you send your survey to the wrong audience. Read our tips to ensure you're doing all you can to get the best response rate possible. Clean Up Your Survey Design The length and tone of your survey dramatically impact your response rate. If survey is long and your questions are text heavy, respondents can feel overwhelmed and exit your survey. Keep these tips in mind when designing your survey: Keep your survey short—include only the essential questions and answer options. Attention and motivation tend to drop as a survey goes on. Use the fewest, shortest words possible to say what you mean. The less respondents have to read, the better. Keep your language simple. Aim for a vocabulary you think a young adult would understand and don't use jargon. Let respondents skip open-ended questions—don't require open-ended questions. Respondents who don't want to take the time to write a response might exit the survey instead of writing a response. The length and tone of your survey dramatically impact your response rate. If survey is long and your questions are text heavy, respondents can feel overwhelmed and exit your survey. Keep these tips in mind when designing your survey: Keep your survey short—include only the essential questions and answer options. Attention and motivation tend to drop as a survey goes on. Use the fewest, shortest words possible to say what you mean. The less respondents have to read, the better. Keep your language simple. Aim for a vocabulary you think a young adult would understand and don't use jargon. Let respondents skip open-ended questions—don't require open-ended questions. Respondents who don't want to take the time to write a response might exit the survey instead of writing a response. Target Your Audience Survey topics may not engage or interest all survey-takers. If someone is uninterested, they may exit your survey and lower your response rate. You can add a qualifying question to your survey to ensure you're surveying the right people. Add Skip Logic to your survey to skip people past questions or pages that may not apply to them. If you're using SurveyMonkey Audience to buy survey responses, read our targeting tips . Survey topics may not engage or interest all survey-takers. If someone is uninterested, they may exit your survey and lower your response rate. You can add a qualifying question to your survey to ensure you're surveying the right people. Add Skip Logic to your survey to skip people past questions or pages that may not apply to them. If you're using SurveyMonkey Audience to buy survey responses, read our targeting tips . Keep Contacts Up to Date If you know your survey audience personally, let people know that you're planning to conduct a survey, what it's about, and when to expect it. If you're sending your survey to a list of contacts, either by Email Invitation or through another messaging platform, make sure your contact list is up to date. If your contact list is out of date, you may be missing important contacts whose email addresses have changed, and your messages could bounce. If you know your survey audience personally, let people know that you're planning to conduct a survey, what it's about, and when to expect it. If you're sending your survey to a list of contacts, either by Email Invitation or through another messaging platform, make sure your contact list is up to date. If your contact list is out of date, you may be missing important contacts whose email addresses have changed, and your messages could bounce. Send Your Survey Multiple Ways If you use more than one collector to distribute your survey, you'll increase your chances of getting responses. In addition to emailing a list of contacts, consider posting a link to your survey in a Listserv, Facebook, LinkedIn, or other web communities. If you use more than one collector to distribute your survey, you'll increase your chances of getting responses. In addition to emailing a list of contacts, consider posting a link to your survey in a Listserv, Facebook, LinkedIn, or other web communities. Test Your Survey Test your survey with a smaller group of people before sending it out to your entire contact list. This will help you identify any issues in your survey language or design and give you a general idea of what you can expect to see as an overall response rate from a larger group. Test your survey with a smaller group of people before sending it out to your entire contact list. This will help you identify any issues in your survey language or design and give you a general idea of what you can expect to see as an overall response rate from a larger group. Personalize Email Invitations and Send Reminders Make sure your survey invitations are inviting—keep them short, simple, and approachable. Provide a brief introduction about what your survey is about, and how long it will take. If you need to include detailed information, like a privacy notice, consent statement , or survey instructions, include it in a survey introduction instead of your invitation. If you're sending your survey via Email Invitation , personalize invitations and reminders by including the name of your respondents using custom data tags in your message. title: Feature Importance (MaxDiff)
body: Feature Importance (MaxDiff) How MaxDiff Works (Experimental Design) Setting Up Your Survey Collecting Responses Analyzing Results Exporting Data Feature Importance (MaxDiff) Feature Importance (MaxDiff) How MaxDiff Works (Experimental Design) Setting Up Your Survey Collecting Responses Analyzing Results Exporting Data ADD-ON FEATURE : You can use this solution with our Audience collector on any SurveyMonkey plan type. Get started now , or explore our other market research solutions . This solution is available for US Data Center accounts only. The Web Link collector is available on Advantage, Premier, and Enterprise plans . The MaxDiff solution helps you understand what items or features matter most to your audience. This is helpful when you’re prioritizing new products or features and want to know what your customers care about most. The solution is based on MaxDiff methodology. We create your survey questions using the items you enter. You don’t have to create each MaxDiff question yourself – you enter the items you want to include in your survey, and we create the questions. How MaxDiff Works (Experimental Design) The MaxDiff solution builds your survey questions using the items you enter. You don’t have to create each MaxDiff question yourself – you enter the items you want to include in your survey, and we create the questions. MaxDiff is not a predictive model. It uses algorithmic predictions to estimate outcomes based on multiple-choice scenarios. We recommend that you provide your own notices about these tools to your respondents. Expand the dropdown to learn more about the experimental design. MaxDiff experimental design In a MaxDiff study, respondents should see each item about the same number of times as the other items. SurveyMonkey’s MaxDiff solution creates 30 versions of the survey and distributes them randomly to survey takers to achieve the most bias-free results. However, you can choose how many items are included in each set and how many questions each respondent sees. We consider the following metrics when creating the different versions of your survey. These metrics ensure that your items are represented fairly to reduce bias in your results. One-way Frequencies : Each item should ideally appear an equal number of times to the respondent as they take the survey. Two-way Frequencies : Each item should ideally appear in the same set with each other item an equal number of times. Connectivity : Each item should directly or indirectly be shown with every other item across the 30 versions of the survey. Within-set positional balancing : Each item should ideally appear an equal number of times in the top, middle, and bottom of the question when shown to respondents. Across-set positional balancing : The same item shouldn’t be shown in successive or nearby questions. In a MaxDiff study, respondents should see each item about the same number of times as the other items. SurveyMonkey’s MaxDiff solution creates 30 versions of the survey and distributes them randomly to survey takers to achieve the most bias-free results. However, you can choose how many items are included in each set and how many questions each respondent sees. We consider the following metrics when creating the different versions of your survey. These metrics ensure that your items are represented fairly to reduce bias in your results. Two-way Frequencies : Each item should ideally appear in the same set with each other item an equal number of times. Connectivity : Each item should directly or indirectly be shown with every other item across the 30 versions of the survey. Within-set positional balancing : Each item should ideally appear an equal number of times in the top, middle, and bottom of the question when shown to respondents. Across-set positional balancing : The same item shouldn’t be shown in successive or nearby questions. Data Retention Results from your study are retained for 3 years. After 3 years, the results are deleted. Setting Up Your Survey Learn how to build your MaxDiff study. Get Started To set up your study: Create a new MaxDiff study . Replace Untitled study with a study title on the Get Started page. Review what to expect in setup and after launching your study. Select Next: Set up MaxDiff . Set Up MaxDiff To add survey components: Add an introduction to let survey takers know exactly what you want them to do while completing your survey. Add MaxDiff question text to tell survey takers how to respond to your MaxDiff question. This text goes above your MaxDiff question. Make sure people know to choose one best and one worst from each set of items. Choose the label to use for the “Best” and “Worst” options in your MaxDiff questions. “Best” and “Worst” are selected by default. You can also create your own labels. Choose the label to use for the “Best” and “Worst” options in your MaxDiff questions. “Best” and “Worst” are selected by default. You can also create your own labels. Add items to MaxDiff to use in your questions. You can add items one at a time or import items in bulk. Select Add an item to enter a new item. Add a label and image if you want. The Item description is what survey takers will see. Select Import items to use a list of items. Preview the items on the right. When you’re done, select Import . Select Add an item to enter a new item. Add a label and image if you want. The Item description is what survey takers will see. Select Import items to use a list of items. Preview the items on the right. When you’re done, select Import . Edit items per set, totals sets . This option determines how many items to include in each question and how many question sets you want survey takers to see. When you’re done, you can Preview MaxDiff Question below. Items per set : The number of items shown in each MaxDiff question set. Add at least 5 items. Sets per respondent : The number of MaxDiff question sets each survey taker will see. Read the help text above the Sets per respondent field; it changes based on the number of items you add. Image scale : The size of the image you’ve added to your items. The scale applies to all images. View the image in the Preview MaxDiff Question section. Preview MaxDiff Question : See what your questions will look like in the survey. Select Single set to see what a single question will look like. Select All items to preview all items together in one set. Select View report to see the experimental design report. This report tells you how we balance your study to avoid biased results. To save a copy of this report, select Download report (.csv) . The scale applies to all images. View the image in the Preview MaxDiff Question section. Preview MaxDiff Question : See what your questions will look like in the survey. This report tells you how we balance your study to avoid biased results. To save a copy of this report, select Download report (.csv) . Select Next: Add custom questions . Add Custom Questions You can add additional custom questions to your survey to gather other important information from your target audience. You can: Use the Question Bank to add pre-written questions, if you want. Implement logic for the questions you add so only some people see certain questions. Brand your survey so the survey includes your brand colors and logo. Add custom variables to track data about your respondents. You can use custom variables as a filter when you analyze results. Add translations to your survey so people can take it in another language. Learn more about setting up survey translations . MaxDiff questions are locked to protect our proven methodology and can’t be edited. You can preview them but can’t change them. Under Payment Method , select to pay with Credit or Debit Card , or with My Credits . Enter your Billing Details , review the total, and select Confirm . Once you submit payment, we'll start gathering responses for your survey right away. Analyzing Results Select the chart icon on the left side of the screen to start analyzing your results. In the Analyze section, there’s an Overview, Counts, Empirical Bayes, Survey results, and Individual Responses. Overview : Track your Audience project's status, view how many responses are collected, and see a summary of your targeting criteria. Counts : Get a simple view of how often items were chosen as Best or Worst. Empirical Bayes : Learn how each item performed compared to others. TURF : Review item combinations that are likely to appeal to your target audience. Survey results : View charts and data for your custom questions. Individual responses : View each survey taker’s response. Counts Analysis Counts analysis shows you how often items were chosen as Best or Worst. This data helps you quickly understand how survey takers rated each item. You can view a few different data sets in the chart: Simple counts, Best counts, Worst counts, or Best and Worst counts. Simple counts : Total Best ratings for an item minus Worst ratings. Best counts : How many times an item was chosen as Best. Worst counts : How many times an item was chosen as Worst. Best and Worst counts : Compare how many times an item was chosen as Best and Worst. View all data for each item in the table below your chart. The table also includes Count proportion , which is the quantity of Best or Worst counts divided by the number of times people saw the item. Empirical Bayes Analysis Empirical Bayes shows how survey takers feel about each item. It estimates each item's likelihood of being chosen as Best, relative to other items. Empirical Bayes calculates a utility score for each item, which is a measure of how well an item performed. We calculate this score across all sets and survey takers. We use the following data to calculate utility score for each item: Number of times chosen as Best Number of times chosen as Worst Number of times shown ​​First, we combine all responses to find the utility score for each item. Then, we calculate an item's utility value for each respondent. If someone didn't see all items, we use Bayesian Pooling (or "Shrinkage") to estimate how someone would have responded to the item. We assume that they would answer similarly to the aggregate score, since it combines all responses. We "shrink" the survey taker's utility value toward the aggregate score for the item they didn't see. These scores help us estimate how likely it is that an item will be chosen as Best. The chart shows the utility score for each item. A higher score means that an item is more likely to be chosen as Best and may be more important to your target audience. Using Empirical Bayes Select a scale in the top right corner to change how you view the data: Probability-scaled : Shows the likelihood that people will choose an item as Best. We show each utility score as a percentage. The highest scoring item is most likely to be chosen as best. The scores add up to 100. Zero-centered : Adjusts the scale to use 0 as the average score. A positive score means the item performed better than average. A negative score means the item performed worse than average. Raw scores : View the raw utility scores for each item. Raw scores reflect the actual choices people made during the survey. Raw scores are not probabilities. The table below the chart shows each item’s score and the 95% confidence interval. The confidence interval is a range of scores that contains the score we'd see a certain percentage of times if we did the survey over and over. For example, an item has a 95% confidence interval of [13–14]. In other words, the item would score between 13 and 14 in 95 out of 100 repetitions of the survey. TURF Analysis TURF stands for Total Unduplicated Reach and Frequency. It's a technique that can help you understand how different groups of products or features appeal to audiences. Our MaxDiff TURF analysis tool simulates item combinations that are likely to appeal to your target audience. Use this data to prioritize products or features that will reach the most people. Our TURF analysis tool ranks combinations based on two key metrics: reach and frequency . Reach : the percentage of respondents with at least 1 appealing item in the combination. A “reached” respondent has an appealing item in the combination. A combination with high reach has a mix of items that appeal to the most people. Frequency : the average number of items in the combination that respondents found appealing. Frequency will always be a number between 1 and 2. Higher frequency means that a combination’s items were more popular. Using TURF Analysis Use the Items and Items per combination dropdowns to simulate different combinations. Consider simulating multiple combination sizes to learn how different items impact reach and frequency. Filtering Results On any page, select the Filters button above the chart to filter your data. Any filters you apply to one chart will also apply to others. For example, if you add an Age filter to your Counts analysis, we’ll also apply it to your Empirical Bayes analysis. Exporting Data You can export Counts data, aggregated Empirical Bayes data, full response data, or individual responses. Counts or Empirical Bayes data To export your Counts or Empirical Bayes data: Select Export . Choose the data type you want to export: either Counts or Empirical Bayes Aggregate . Name your file. Select Export . The export appears at the bottom of your browser window or is available from your computer's Downloads folder. To export your Counts or Empirical Bayes data: Select Export . Choose the data type you want to export: either Counts or Empirical Bayes Aggregate . Name your file. Select Export . The export appears at the bottom of your browser window or is available from your computer's Downloads folder. Full response data To export full response data: Select Export . Choose Full Response Data . Choose your file format: XLSX , CSV , or SPSS . Choose to export either the Current view or the Original view (with no filters applied). If you're exporting an XLSX or CSV file, choose the format for your columns, then choose the data to show in each cell. Name your file. Select Export . The export appears at the bottom of your browser window or is available from your computer's Downloads folder. To export full response data: Select Export . Choose Full Response Data . Choose your file format: XLSX , CSV , or SPSS . Choose to export either the Current view or the Original view (with no filters applied). If you're exporting an XLSX or CSV file, choose the format for your columns, then choose the data to show in each cell. Name your file. Select Export . The export appears at the bottom of your browser window or is available from your computer's Downloads folder. Individual responses To export individual responses: Select Export . Choose Individual Respondent Responses . Name your file. Select Export . The export appears at the bottom of your browser window or is available from your computer's Downloads folder. To export individual responses: Select Export . Choose Individual Respondent Responses . Name your file. Select Export . The export appears at the bottom of your browser window or is available from your computer's Downloads folder.
