title: Get Quick Insights with Analyze with AI
body: Get Quick Insights with Analyze with AI Survey Requirements Feature Availability and Settings Using Analyze with AI Asking Useful Questions Get Quick Insights with Analyze with AI Get Quick Insights with Analyze with AI Survey Requirements Feature Availability and Settings Using Analyze with AI Asking Useful Questions Analyze with AI helps you find key insights and trends in your survey data by responding to your questions with charts and insight summaries. With Analyze with AI, you can: Uncover insights based on responses, timeframes, and more in seconds Ask for comparisons, or information about specific segments Visualize data points based on your results Export and share any charts that Analyze with AI creates for you How it works: Analyze with AI helps you segment, summarize, and visualize your survey responses to quickly gather insights. It doesn’t modify anything in your survey, such as applying filters to responses on the page, editing charts, or building dashboards. It draws insights from all of your results, regardless of any filters you’ve applied. What it can analyze: Analyze with AI can analyze these question types and data: Multiple Choice Checkbox Dropdown NPS Star Rating Matrix/Rating Scale Ranking Matrix of Dropdown Menus Comment Box (if responses are tagged) Single Text Box (if responses are tagged) Basic demographic information (for surveys sent via SurveyMonkey Audience ) How to analyze Comment Box and Single Text Box: Analyze with AI can only analyze open-ended text responses if they’re tagged. If you have access to Sentiment Analysis or Thematic Analysis , Analyze with AI can generate sentiments and themes for deeper insights into open-ended responses. You’ll also see any tags or themes that Analyze with AI created on the Question Summaries page. Analyze with AI also supports existing tags that you’ve created via Sentiment Analysis, Thematic Analysis, rule-based tagging , or manual tagging . Survey Requirements Analyze with AI is available for surveys that meet these requirements: The survey language is in English Your survey has between 1 and 10,000 responses Limitations Analyze with AI can’t answer questions about your account or offer product support. Analyze with AI can’t answer questions about logic, advanced branching, or piping that have been applied to your survey. The feature may not be able to answer questions about complex custom variables or custom data added to your collectors. Analyze with AI can’t answer questions about “Other” textbox responses from Multiple Choice, Checkboxes, and Star Rating Scale question types. Certain survey use cases are not permitted—for details, please see SurveyMonkey's Acceptable Uses Policy , as well as additional third party provider usage policies , and acceptable use and conduct policies Feature Availability and Settings Analyze with AI is only available to some customers in supported regions. The way you access this feature depends on your plan: Individual plans : If Analyze with AI is available for your plan, you can access it at any time. Teams and Enterprise plans : Your Primary Admin determines whether your team can access Analyze with AI . For details on the terms that apply to the use of this feature, please see our Self-Serve AI Service-Specific Terms and SurveyMonkey Enterprise Service-Specific Terms . HIPAA and Enhanced Sensitive Data Protection : Analyze with AI isn’t available to HIPAA-enabled accounts, or those with the Enhanced Sensitive Data Protection feature enabled. Additionally, based on your plan type, Analyze with AI may set limitations on the number of questions available per survey. Analyze with AI is also subject to fair use of the feature, so your account may be temporarily disabled if we notice abnormal activity. How Your Data is Processed Analyze with AI uses Azure Open AI service or Open AI to generate insights about your survey. Your content isn’t used to train these third party providers’ models. Learn more about how this feature processes your data . Don’t include sensitive or personal information in your questions – you are responsible for the information you enter in Analyze with AI. Analyze with AI’s answers may have limitations based on the survey data or how you phrased your questions. Review the results carefully. Use of this feature is subject to additional terms, as described in our Service-Specific Terms . Using Analyze with AI To use Analyze with AI: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. To include open-text questions in your analysis, make sure to tag text responses. If you have access to Sentiment Analysis or Thematic Analysis , Analyze with AI can tag your responses for you. You can also use rule-based tagging or manual tagging . Select Analyze with AI in the top right corner of the Question Summaries page. If you don’t see the Analyze with AI option, the feature isn’t available for your survey or account. Accept the terms and conditions. Type your question, or select View suggestions and select a suggested question. Select Send to ask your question. Understanding and Rating Answers Analyze with AI provides a text explanation in each answer. Some answers include a chart or table. Hover over the info icon below the chart to learn how Analyze with AI got this result. You can also see the survey questions that Analyze with AI used for its answer. You can rate the answer to let us know if it was helpful or accurate. Select the thumbs up or thumbs down button to rate the answer. You can also leave a comment about your negative rating or submit your feedback via the feedback form. Your ratings help us improve Analyze with AI and provide more relevant answers in the future. Asking Useful Questions Here are a few tips to improve the answers you get from Analyze with AI. Use the terms “responses” and “respondents” carefully. Use respondents to ask about the total number of individuals. Use responses If you want the number of votes or choices. Use respondents to ask about the total number of individuals. Use responses If you want the number of votes or choices. Use terms and concepts from your survey. This helps Analyze with AI understand what data to find and analyze for you. For example, if your survey is about a specific product or industry, ask questions that include the product or industry in your survey. This helps Analyze with AI understand what data to find and analyze for you. For example, if your survey is about a specific product or industry, ask questions that include the product or industry in your survey. Be specific. Clearly define what specific aspect of the data you are inquiring about. Example : Don’t ask what the “best product” is. Instead, you can ask, “Which product has the highest satisfaction level?" Clearly define what specific aspect of the data you are inquiring about. Example : Don’t ask what the “best product” is. Instead, you can ask, “Which product has the highest satisfaction level?" Avoid general questions. Instead, target specific questions, metrics, or trends. Example : If you’re asking about NPS scores, don’t ask, “How much positive feedback did we get?” Instead, ask about the percentage of promoters. Instead, target specific questions, metrics, or trends. Example : If you’re asking about NPS scores, don’t ask, “How much positive feedback did we get?” Instead, ask about the percentage of promoters. Use clear and direct language. Avoid jargon or overly complex terms unless they are directly relevant to your survey. Avoid jargon or overly complex terms unless they are directly relevant to your survey. Quantify when possible. Ask for numbers or percentages to get more specific results. Example : "What percentage of respondents were very satisfied with the product quality?" Ask for numbers or percentages to get more specific results. Example : "What percentage of respondents were very satisfied with the product quality?" Ask for comparative analysis If you’re interested in trends, comparisons, or changes, specify the exact parameters you want compared. Example: "Compare the satisfaction levels between different age groups." If you’re interested in trends, comparisons, or changes, specify the exact parameters you want compared. Example: "Compare the satisfaction levels between different age groups." Focus on actionable insights. Ask for actionable insights or recommendations. Example: "Based on the survey responses, what areas should we focus on to improve customer satisfaction?" Ask for actionable insights or recommendations. Example: "Based on the survey responses, what areas should we focus on to improve customer satisfaction?" Consider data breakdown Specify if you need a breakdown of responses by certain demographics or categories. Example: "What are the satisfaction levels by geographic region?" Specify if you need a breakdown of responses by certain demographics or categories. Example: "What are the satisfaction levels by geographic region?" Seek clarifications on anomalies If you notice any unusual patterns or outliers in your data, ask for clarifications or deeper analysis. Example: "Why might there be a higher dissatisfaction rate among customers aged 18-24?" If you notice any unusual patterns or outliers in your data, ask for clarifications or deeper analysis. Example: "Why might there be a higher dissatisfaction rate among customers aged 18-24?" Ask a different question when you get the wrong result. If Analyze with AI doesn’t answer your question with the right information, ask again in a different way. Use the thumbs up and thumbs down to rate the responses so we can improve Analyze with AI. If Analyze with AI doesn’t answer your question with the right information, ask again in a different way. Use the thumbs up and thumbs down to rate the responses so we can improve Analyze with AI. title: Workgroups
body: Workgroups Create a Workgroup Workgroup Surveys & Roles Manage Workgroups Find a Workgroup Workgroups Workgroups Create a Workgroup Workgroup Surveys & Roles Manage Workgroups Find a Workgroup ENTERPRISE FEATURE: If you're interested, contact sales . If you already have an Enterprise account, contact your Customer Success Manager. Workgroups help organize team members with a shared purpose to work together on survey projects. Primary Admins and Admins can create workgroups to quickly and easily share surveys with a group of people on your team. Plus, you can manage members, assign roles, and change owner status so each team member has the right level of access to surveys. You can contact your CSM to let Power Users create, own, and manage workgroups, too. What's the difference between Workgroups and Divisions? Workgroups help organize team members collaborating on survey projects while Divisions help with administrative management of large teams. Create a Workgroup To create a new workgroup: Select My Team from the main navigation. Select Workgroups . Click New Workgroup . Type the Workgroup name and Purpose. Click Create Workgroup . From the Members tab, search or click to add members to the workgroup. You can search for members of your team by name, email, or role. From the Surveys tab, add the surveys you want to share with all members of the workgroup. From the Settings tab, select whether the workgroup is Public or Private . Public workgroups are visible to your entire team, while private workgroups are only visible to its members. When a team member is added to a workgroup, they're assigned the default role. Manage Members to update the default role and individual member roles. Workgroup Surveys and Roles Surveys Add surveys to a workgroup to share it with all team members. You can add surveys when creating a workgroup or share surveys directly from Home . Workgroup Roles A user’s role in a workgroup determines if they can view, access, and edit the workgroup's shared surveys. These roles only apply within the workgroup and a user’s Enterprise seat determines what role they can have. Full permissions to the Analyze section. Limited permissions to view the survey design and collector list. People you're working with will see any rules, custom charts, shared data pages, exports, or text analysis features created by the survey owner or any others with Full Access or Analyzer permissions. You need to refresh the Analyze Results page to see others' changes. Manage Workgroups Managing Members The Members tab displays every workgroup member's name, email, and role. This is also where you can add members to a workgroup, re-assign roles, remove members, or review team requests to join a public workgroup. TIP! Check out the Notification Center to see Workgroup messages from the last 30 days. Re-assign a member's role To re-assign an individual member's role: Select My Team from the top navigation. Select Workgroups . From the Members tab, click on . to the right of the member's name you want to re-assign. Click Assign Role . Select the role from the dropdown. Click Assign . To re-assign an individual member's role: Select My Team from the top navigation. Select Workgroups . From the Members tab, click on . to the right of the member's name you want to re-assign. Click Assign Role . Select the role from the dropdown. Click Assign . Remove a member To remove a member from a workgroup: Select My Team from the top navigation. Select Workgroups . From the Members tab, click on . to the right of the member's name you want to remove. Click Remove member . Click Remove . The removed member loses access to the workgroup's shared surveys unless they are the survey owner or the survey is shared with them independently of the workgroup. To remove a member from a workgroup: Select My Team from the top navigation. Select Workgroups . From the Members tab, click on . to the right of the member's name you want to remove. Click Remove member . Click Remove . The removed member loses access to the workgroup's shared surveys unless they are the survey owner or the survey is shared with them independently of the workgroup. Re-assign the default role To re-assign the default role for a workgroup: Select My Team from the top navigation. Select Workgroups . From the Settings tab, click the Default Role dropdown and select the new default role. Click Save Changes . To re-assign the default role for a workgroup: Select My Team from the top navigation. Select Workgroups . From the Settings tab, click the Default Role dropdown and select the new default role. Click Save Changes . Review a request to join a workgroup To review a member request to join a workgroup: Select My Team from the top navigation. Select Workgroups . From the Members tab, Accept or Deny a member request to join the workgroup. To review a member request to join a workgroup: Select My Team from the top navigation. Select Workgroups . From the Members tab, Accept or Deny a member request to join the workgroup. Update Owner A workgroup owner, Primary Admin, or Admin can make any member an owner of the workgroup or remove owner status from an existing owner. Owners can’t remove their own owner status. To update owner status: Select My Team from the top navigation. Select Workgroups . From the Members tab, click on the three dots ( ... ) to the right of the member you want to update. Select Make this person an owner or Remove owner status . Delete a Workgroup If a workgroup is no longer needed, delete the workgroup. When a workgroup is deleted, the shared surveys will no longer be available to members, unless they are owned by the member or the survey is shared independently of the workgroup. To delete a workgroup: Select My Team from the top navigation. Select Workgroups . Find the workgroup you want to delete and click the three dots ( ... ) to the right of that workgroup. Select Delete . Find a Workgroup Anyone on the team can see the workgroups they're a part of in the My Workgroups tab or view the entire team's public workgroups in the All Workgroups tab—just click My Team on the main navigation and select Workgroups . If you'd like to join a public workgroup, you can Ask to join . This sends an email notification to the workgroup owner to review. Related Articles Company SurveyMonkey About Us Jobs Blog Help SurveyMonkey Help GetFeedback Help Market Research Help SurveyMonkey Audience Help SurveyMonkey Contribute Help Wufoo Help Apply Help Support Site Status Unsubscribe Contact Us Email Opt-In Policies Legal Center Privacy Policy Cookies Notice California Privacy Notice

title: Formatting Text
body: Formatting Text Themes vs. Rich Text Editor Bold Specific Words in Question Text Supported HTML Formatting Text Formatting Text Themes vs. Rich Text Editor Bold Specific Words in Question Text Supported HTML When designing a survey, you can use the rich text editor to bold, underline, or italicize text and add images , videos , or links . Some fields have an advanced editor for more formatting options. The available options in the rich text editor vary by question type and field. To see the options available for a particular field, click directly into the field. To format text: Go to the Design Survey section. Click or highlight text in any field. Use the formatting toolbar. In some fields, you can click … to open the advanced editor. Themes vs. Rich Text Editor Themes and CSS themes ( Enterprise only ) let you apply text formatting across your entire survey. The rich text editor lets you edit text in individual fields, one place at a time. You can change the font size and style in your theme settings to control survey-wide text formatting. You can use the rich text editor to add additional formatting or to override the theme font settings for an individual text field. Save your changes to see the formatting applied by theme and the rich text editor in the survey. Formatting text using themes or the rich text editor adds HTML tags that count toward character limits . Bold Specific Words in Question Text Some standard themes have bold question text by default. In this case, you need to change the font settings of your theme and uncheck Bold under Question Text so you can go back and bold specific words in your question. Supported HTML For some parts of your survey, like the Custom Thank You , Survey Closed Message , or Email Invitations , you can use HTML to format text . title: Teams & Enterprise
body: Teams & Enterprise Help Topics Teams & Enterprise Teams & Enterprise Managing Teams Teams If you need more than one SurveyMonkey account for your organization, sign up for a team. Team plans offer consolidated billing, seat management, a Library with shared images and templates, and collaboration features that help your team work together to create, send, and analyze surveys. Team Seats, Roles, and Permissions Your seat type and role on a team controls what permissions you have within your account and how you can work together with your team. Managing Seats on Your Team The Primary Admin or Admin of a team can add seats, invite people to join your team, and manage existing seats on your team from the My Team section of your account. Team Billing Learn all about how billing works for teams. The Primary Admin of a team is in charge of the consolidated billing for all accounts on the team. Manage Accounts with SCIM Use SCIM to keep SurveyMonkey accounts up to date with information stored in an identity provider (IdP). Manage Your Team’s Surveys If you are a Primary Admin, Admin or Division Admin, you can see the surveys created by people on your team and help manage those surveys. Managing Seats on Your Enterprise Team The Primary Admin or Admin of an Enterprise team can add seats, invite people to join your team, and manage existing seats on your team from the My Team section of your account. Consolidating Accounts for Enterprise The consolidation of individual and team accounts into one Enterprise account. Teams If you need more than one SurveyMonkey account for your organization, sign up for a team. Team plans offer consolidated billing, seat management, a Library with shared images and templates, and collaboration features that help your team work together to create, send, and analyze surveys. Team Seats, Roles, and Permissions Your seat type and role on a team controls what permissions you have within your account and how you can work together with your team. Managing Seats on Your Team The Primary Admin or Admin of a team can add seats, invite people to join your team, and manage existing seats on your team from the My Team section of your account. Team Billing Learn all about how billing works for teams. The Primary Admin of a team is in charge of the consolidated billing for all accounts on the team. Manage Accounts with SCIM Use SCIM to keep SurveyMonkey accounts up to date with information stored in an identity provider (IdP). Manage Your Team’s Surveys If you are a Primary Admin, Admin or Division Admin, you can see the surveys created by people on your team and help manage those surveys. Managing Seats on Your Enterprise Team The Primary Admin or Admin of an Enterprise team can add seats, invite people to join your team, and manage existing seats on your team from the My Team section of your account. Consolidating Accounts for Enterprise The consolidation of individual and team accounts into one Enterprise account. Collaborating With Your Team Sharing Surveys with Others You can share surveys with people on or outside your team if you have an Enterprise account or a Full Access seat on a team. Your plan type determines the ways you can share surveys, if people can reshare your surveys, and if you have the option to automatically share surveys with your entire team or workgroup. Working with Others on Surveys We have some great collaboration features to help you work with other people on surveys, no matter what kind of SurveyMonkey account you have. Managing Brand Assets in the Library The library is where Full Access seat team members can find and use shared assets to create surveys. These shared assets include images, documents, templates, themes, and questions. Primary Admins and Admins can also add or manage library items. Divisions A Division is a sub-group within your Enterprise team, with its own admins, users, and division library. Primary Admins and Admins can add divisions for different departments, offices, clients, or any other groups you want to manage separately or give unique branding assets. Workgroups Enterprise Workgroups help organize team members with a shared purpose to work together on projects. Survey Permissions to Shared Surveys When a survey is shared, people are given a level of access to each section of the survey. A team member's default access level is determined by their role, but it may be possible to edit the level of permissions some one has. The highest level of access available to people outside of your team is View Only. Getting Feedback on Surveys and Results You can invite others to give feedback on your survey design by sharing your survey preview link or sending an invite to comment. Once you collect survey responses, you can use a Shared Data Page to invite others to give feedback on your survey results. Discover Teams at Your Company Team Discovery helps people find existing SurveyMonkey teams from their company and makes it easier for Primary Admins to invite people to join their team. Sharing Surveys with Others You can share surveys with people on or outside your team if you have an Enterprise account or a Full Access seat on a team. Your plan type determines the ways you can share surveys, if people can reshare your surveys, and if you have the option to automatically share surveys with your entire team or workgroup. Working with Others on Surveys We have some great collaboration features to help you work with other people on surveys, no matter what kind of SurveyMonkey account you have. Managing Brand Assets in the Library The library is where Full Access seat team members can find and use shared assets to create surveys. These shared assets include images, documents, templates, themes, and questions. Primary Admins and Admins can also add or manage library items. Divisions A Division is a sub-group within your Enterprise team, with its own admins, users, and division library. Primary Admins and Admins can add divisions for different departments, offices, clients, or any other groups you want to manage separately or give unique branding assets. Workgroups Enterprise Workgroups help organize team members with a shared purpose to work together on projects. Survey Permissions to Shared Surveys When a survey is shared, people are given a level of access to each section of the survey. A team member's default access level is determined by their role, but it may be possible to edit the level of permissions some one has. The highest level of access available to people outside of your team is View Only. Getting Feedback on Surveys and Results You can invite others to give feedback on your survey design by sharing your survey preview link or sending an invite to comment. Once you collect survey responses, you can use a Shared Data Page to invite others to give feedback on your survey results. Discover Teams at Your Company Team Discovery helps people find existing SurveyMonkey teams from their company and makes it easier for Primary Admins to invite people to join their team. Enterprise Features Enterprise Team Seats, Roles and Permissions Learn how your seat and role on an Enterprise team controls what account permissions you have and how you can work together. Enterprise Settings Settings let Primary Admins set default options and permissions for their entire Enterprise team. Single Sign-On (SSO) Single Sign-On (SSO) enables people on your team to use their corporate login credentials to log in to SurveyMonkey. Your organization can control who can access your SurveyMonkey team and create authentication policies for increased security. Custom Question Bank Custom Question Bank lets Primary Admins and Admins add custom questions to their team’s Library. Full Access seats on the team can add the questions to their survey from the Question Bank. HIPAA Compliance and SurveyMonkey HIPAA is a United States law that regulates the collection and handling of “protected health information” (PHI). Certain organizations called “covered entities” and their business associates are required to comply with HIPAA. You can collect PHI in surveys if you enable HIPAA features on your team. Our features help you to be compliant. Avoiding Scams We’ve become aware of scams such as job offers, fake coupons, or checks that say they’re sponsored by SurveyMonkey. These are not from us—they’re sent by scammers. Learn how to identify fakes and report scams like this so you and others can stay safer online. title: SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Measuring Net Promoter® Score
body: SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Measuring Net Promoter® Score Creating a Survey Object in Salesforce Grouping NPS Responses Totaling NPS Scores Creating a Custom Report Type for NPS Scores Calculating NPS Scores Mapping NPS Scores from SurveyMonkey to Salesforce SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Measuring Net Promoter® Score SurveyMonkey for Salesforce: Measuring Net Promoter® Score Creating a Survey Object in Salesforce Grouping NPS Responses Totaling NPS Scores Creating a Custom Report Type for NPS Scores Calculating NPS Scores Mapping NPS Scores from SurveyMonkey to Salesforce Get the integration ! SurveyMonkey for Salesforce is an Enterprise add-on. Contact Sales or your Customer Success Manager (CSM). Limitation: The integration setup is only available in English. If you use our Salesforce integration, you can create Net Promoter® Score (NPS) surveys and map the survey responses directly into Salesforce. You can use Salesforce reporting to calculate NPS and create dashboards to display key customer feedback. Learn more about the SurveyMonkey for Salesforce integration . This article walks you through the following steps to set up NPS reporting in Salesforce: Create a custom Salesforce object, or add fields to your existing one Add a formula to group NPS responses Total the NPS scores Create a custom NPS report type Calculate NPS scores using your report and a summary formula This is just one way to set up NPS tracking in Salesforce – your NPS program should be customized to fit your organization’s needs. SurveyMonkey can’t consult on coding issues in your Salesforce environment. Reach out to your Salesforce administrator for help implementing these features. These examples help you get started with our Salesforce integration, and you may need to make changes for your organization. Creating a Survey Object in Salesforce If you don’t already have a custom response object, create a new custom object in Salesforce. In this case, we've named our object NPS Responses. Or, you can use the same object you already use for survey responses. Your custom response object should contain the following fields: Survey Name (Text) Contact (Lookup relationship – Contact) Email (Email) Net Promoter Score (Number) Comments (Long Text) NPS Response URL (Text, URL) NPS Grouping (Formula, result: Text) Promoter (Formula, result: Number) Passive (Formula, result: Number) Detractor (Formula, result: Number) Grouping NPS Responses On your custom object, add a formula field for NPS Grouping. NPS Grouping is a formula that categorizes survey takers as Promoters (9 & 10), Passives (7 & 8), or Detractors (6 & below) based on their Net Promoter Score. You can decide to display images or text in this field. For example, you can use stars, hearts, or other icons to help people quickly identify scores. Use one of the formulas below to use NPS Grouping on your object. NPS Grouping with Images Use this formula in your field to add images to each NPS grouping. You can replace the file path (for example, "/servlet/servlet.FileDownload?file=015o0000001blTH") with a different image. NPS Grouping without Images Use this formula to group NPS scores without using images. Totaling NPS Scores Add the Promoter, Passive, and Detractor fields to total the number of responses you’ve received for each NPS grouping. You need these grouping totals to calculate NPS in Salesforce. These fields don’t need to be visible on the page layout to add their totals together. Use these formulas to total the number of responses for each group: Promoter : IF(Net_Promoter_Score__c > 8, 1, 0) Passive : IF(AND(Net_Promoter_Score__c > 6, Net_Promoter_Score__c < 9), 1, 0) Detractor : IF(Net_Promoter_Score__c < 7, 1, 0) Creating a Custom Report Type for NPS Scores Create a custom report type in Salesforce for your NPS object. You’ll use this report to calculate your NPS score. Calculating NPS Scores To calculate NPS scores in Salesforce: Create a new Salesforce summary report using your NPS report type. You can choose to summarize NPS by Survey Name, or filter the report to only show specific Surveys. Write a summary formula in your report to calculate your score. The formula below is an example of an NPS calculation formula. Make sure to update the formula with the correct object name and field names based on how it’s been set up in your environment. We recommend selecting Grand Total Only when applying the formula. NPS Calculation Formula Mapping NPS Scores from SurveyMonkey to Salesforce Now that your Salesforce environment is ready, you can map your NPS survey into Salesforce. In SurveyMonkey, open the Salesforce integration , then map your response data to the corresponding Salesforce fields. For example, you can map the survey name, NPS score, and any comments to your custom Salesforce fields. When you've finished setting up mappings, you can start collecting responses. title: Question Bank
body: Question Bank Browsing Questions Adding Questions Editing Questions Restrictions Question Bank Question Bank Browsing Questions Adding Questions Editing Questions Restrictions Question Bank is a library containing hundreds of questions you can add to your survey in seconds. These questions are written and certified by our very own survey methodologists. It's available to all SurveyMonkey customers—all you need to get started is a SurveyMonkey account and a survey to play around with. Tip! Consider creating a Custom Question Bank for your team. Browsing Questions To browse Question Bank: Go to the Design Survey section of your survey. Click Question bank . Click a category to open the Question Bank browser. Search for questions by keyword or click Filters to refine the results by tags. TIP! We also have pre-written survey templates you can use to create a survey. When browsing Question Bank, you'll see survey templates that use the types of questions you're browsing. Adding Questions To add a question: Open the Question Bank browser. Drag and drop or just click a question to add it to the preview. In the preview, drag and drop questions in the order you'd like them. Click + Add Questions . Why can't I re-order or delete questions? If your questions are in a grey box in the Question Bank preview, it means you've already added them to your survey. Close the Question Bank browser to move them or delete them. If your questions are in a grey box in the Question Bank preview, it means you've already added them to your survey. Close the Question Bank browser to move them or delete them. How do I put questions on different pages of the survey? Once you close the Question Bank browser, you can add pages to your survey design and move questions wherever you'd like. Once you close the Question Bank browser, you can add pages to your survey design and move questions wherever you'd like. Editing Questions Question Bank questions are written and certified by survey methodologists. Certain questions can be customized without the loss of certification—if you see drop-down menus in the question text, click to see options that may better fit the context of your survey. However, if you make additional edits to the wording of the question, it'll lose its certification and associated badge. Badges After you add a Question Bank question to your survey, you'll see it has a little badge when you hover over the question in your survey design. The badge is just for your reference—it means your question is certified and in some cases who we partnered with to write it—and it doesn't show to respondents. Benchmarks The benchmarks badge indicates whether a question is benchmarkable. Look for it when adding questions from Question Bank and turn on free Global Benchmarks or purchase Industry Benchmarks and view them in your survey results. Your response data from any eligible Question Bank questions will be contributed to benchmarks on an de-identified and aggregated basis. You can opt out of benchmarks at any time by changing your privacy settings. title: Custom Variables
body: Custom Variables Video Overview Setting Up Custom Variables Example Limitations Custom Variables Custom Variables Video Overview Setting Up Custom Variables Example Limitations Custom Variables Custom Variables is a logic feature you can use with a Web Link collector to track data about people who take your survey. It passes data you put in your survey link into your survey results. Video Overview Setting Up Custom Variables Create custom variables when designing your survey, then add them to your Web Link collector before you send it out. Once you have responses, you can see your custom variables when you export. 1. Creating them in your survey design To add custom variables: Click the Design Survey tab. In the left sidebar, click the Logic icon. Click Custom Variables . Click + New custom variable . Set up the first variable: Variable Name (required) - This goes in the Web Link. Label (optional) - This shows in your survey results, to help you track what each variable is for. Variable Name (required) - This goes in the Web Link. Label (optional) - This shows in your survey results, to help you track what each variable is for. Click Save . 2. Adding them to your Web Link Now that you have custom variables in your survey, it’s time to create your survey link and add custom values to each variable. To create your Web Link and add values: Click the Collect Responses tab. Create a Web Link collector . Copy the survey link. The template for adding your custom values will already be added to the end of the link and will follow this format: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/your_survey?var1=[var1_value]&var2=[var2_value]&var3=[var3_value] Outside of SurveyMonkey (in Excel, Google Sheets, Numbers, etc.), replace the bracketed values with the values you want to pass through the URL. Custom variables are case sensitive, so make sure they match what you entered in the Design Survey section. Send each link to the people you want to take the survey. TIP! If you set the Survey End Page to redirect respondents to the website of your choice, custom variables will also pass through to the redirect URL. 3. Viewing them in your results In the Analyze Results tab, you can filter by custom variables . You can see custom variables at the end of each row in All Responses Data XLS or SPSS export types . Example Let's say you want to send out a short employee survey to three members of your Research department. Instead of asking each respondent to fill out their name, department, and title in the survey itself, you want to track this information about them through the survey link using Custom Variables. Here's how you would do this, from beginning to end: Design Survey Create 3 variables based on the respondent information you want to pass through the survey link. Variable Name: n Label: Name Variable Name: dept Label: Department Variable Name: t Label: Title Collect Responses Create a Web Link Collector. When you view the link, the template for adding your custom values will already be appended to the end of it: Outside of SurveyMonkey, create a unique link for each respondent by replacing the bracketed values with each person's Name, Department, and Title. Send each unique link to each respective respondent. https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/your_survey? n = Lizzie & dept = Research & t = Intern https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/your_survey? n = Jenna & dept = Research & t = Analyst https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/your_survey? n = Hailee & dept = Research & t = SurveyDesigner Analyze Results Download an All Responses Data XLS, or SPSS export to see the custom variables paired with each response. In the spreadsheet, the results for this one-question survey will look like this: Limitations URL Length Web Link collectors can attach up to 100 custom variables to the URL. So you don't exceed universal URL length limitations, we suggest URLs remain under 2,000 characters to maintain functionality with popular web browsers. Web Link collectors can attach up to 100 custom variables to the URL. So you don't exceed universal URL length limitations, we suggest URLs remain under 2,000 characters to maintain functionality with popular web browsers. Forbidden Characters and Variable Names You can't use the following in Variable Names, Variable Labels, or as values inserted into the survey link template: Letters with accents (for example, À, É, ï, ó, Û, ñ, or ÿ) Special characters like: - – — # ? & ; You can't use the following in Variable Names: sm mode c cid rid r s sv pID s_mod PREVIEW_MODE Fmt prizeshown Token Disqualify overquota lang javascript You can't use the following in Variable Names, Variable Labels, or as values inserted into the survey link template: Letters with accents (for example, À, É, ï, ó, Û, ñ, or ÿ) Special characters like: - – — # ? & ; You can't use the following in Variable Names: sm mode c cid rid r s sv pID s_mod PREVIEW_MODE Fmt prizeshown Token Disqualify overquota lang javascript No Way to Automatically Insert Values There is no way to automatically insert values into the survey link template within SurveyMonkey. You will need to do this manually, or run your own script to insert the values into the survey link template, outside of SurveyMonkey. If you are uncomfortable with this approach, consider using the Email Invitation Collector to track custom data about respondents. There is no way to automatically insert values into the survey link template within SurveyMonkey. You will need to do this manually, or run your own script to insert the values into the survey link template, outside of SurveyMonkey. If you are uncomfortable with this approach, consider using the Email Invitation Collector to track custom data about respondents. Collector Options Custom variables don't work with Recurrences . Turn off the Recurrence collector option to make sure your custom variables work properly. Custom variables don't work with Recurrences . Turn off the Recurrence collector option to make sure your custom variables work properly. Deletion Custom variables cannot be deleted once responses have been collected. Custom variables cannot be deleted once responses have been collected. title: Clearing or Deleting Responses
body: Clearing or Deleting Responses Clearing or Deleting Responses Clearing or Deleting Responses Deleting responses is permanent. Once you delete them, they can't be restored. You can delete individual responses, all the responses from a collector, or all the responses for an entire survey. If you delete responses from a shared survey , they're also deleted from any accounts with shared access. If you have a Basic (free) plan, the number of responses your account can have and delete depends on when your account was created and your billing location. For example, you may be able to delete 40 or 50 responses total from your account. TIP! If you're on a free (Basic) plan, you can immediately delete all responses over your account limit . Deleting Individual Responses TIP! Create a filter to hide incomplete responses instead of deleting them. When the response status is Incomplete, the survey may be in progress. To permanently delete responses in Table view: Go to the Analyze Results section. Select the Individual Responses tab toward the top of the page. In Table view, find the response you want to delete. Select the Delete button on the right side of the table. At the confirmation message, select Delete Response . To permanently delete responses in Single view: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Select the Individual Responses tab toward the top of the page. In the top right corner, change the view from Table to Single . Use the left and right arrows to locate the response you want to delete. Select the Delete button in the upper-right corner of the response. Select Delete response . If you sent your survey via Email Invitation, the contact won't be deleted from the collector and their response status in the collector will not change. TIP! Create a filter to hide incomplete responses instead of deleting them. When the response status is Incomplete, the survey may be in progress. To permanently delete responses in Table view: Go to the Analyze Results section. Select the Individual Responses tab toward the top of the page. In Table view, find the response you want to delete. Select the Delete button on the right side of the table. At the confirmation message, select Delete Response . To permanently delete responses in Single view: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Select the Individual Responses tab toward the top of the page. In the top right corner, change the view from Table to Single . Use the left and right arrows to locate the response you want to delete. Select the Delete button in the upper-right corner of the response. Select Delete response . If you sent your survey via Email Invitation, the contact won't be deleted from the collector and their response status in the collector will not change. Deleting All Responses from a Collector To permanently delete all responses from a collector: Go to the Collect Responses tab of your survey. Select ... to the right of the collector. Select Clear responses . To permanently delete all responses from a collector: Go to the Collect Responses tab of your survey. Select ... to the right of the collector. Select Clear responses . Deleting All Responses for a Survey To delete all responses for a survey: From Home , select ... to the right of the survey. Select Delete . Select Delete . To clear all responses from a survey shared with you , you need to clear each collector on the survey, one at a time, under the Collect Responses tab. To delete all responses for a survey: From Home , select ... to the right of the survey. Select Delete . Select Delete . To clear all responses from a survey shared with you , you need to clear each collector on the survey, one at a time, under the Collect Responses tab. title: Can I merge surveys or survey results?
body: Can I merge surveys or survey results? Can I merge surveys or survey results? Can I merge surveys or survey results? It's not possible to merge two survey designs or the results of two separate surveys. However, you can compare results from multiple surveys in a multi-survey analysis dashboard . You can add charts from 2 or more surveys to compare results over time and across segments. You can also create multiple collectors for one survey. The results for each collector are merged in the Analyze Results section of the survey so you can easily view and export all survey results. Filter by Collector to export the results separately. Use Data Trends to track your survey results over time with multiple collectors. Combine or hide answer choices in your survey results by creating a custom chart. It's not possible to merge the results of two separate surveys, even if they are identical in design or copies of one another. If you need to merge the data of two separate surveys, export the data for each survey and try combining the files in Excel. title: Comparing Survey Results
body: Comparing Survey Results Creating Compare Rules Types of Compare Rules Managing Compare Rules Exporting & Sharing Rules Comparing Survey Results Comparing Survey Results Creating Compare Rules Types of Compare Rules Managing Compare Rules Exporting & Sharing Rules Compare rules let you choose two or more answer options from a single question and view them side-by-side. For example, if you include a question in your survey asking people what age they are, you can create a compare rule to view the survey results for each age range. This can help you understand how different age groups responded to questions in your survey. TIP! To compare results from multiple surveys, create a multi-survey analysis dashboard . To do more complex comparisons using answer choices from multiple questions, create a Crosstab report . Creating Compare Rules You can create a compare rule using the following closed-ended question types : Multiple Choice, Checkboxes, Star Rating, Dropdown, Matrix/Rating Scale, Image Choice, or Ranking. If you create a compare rule using a Matrix/Rating Scale question, you won't be able to combine or hide its answer choices . To create a compare rule: Go to the Analyze Results section of your survey. Select Rules from the toolbar, then click + Compare . Select a compare rule type. Choose the criteria you want to focus on. Click Apply . You'll see any active rules at the top of the page. We'll also show the number of responses included in your rule, compared to the number of responses in your survey. You can turn on statistical significance to automatically calculate when your results show differences that are statistically unlikely to be due to random chance. When you use a Slider question in your survey and a compare rule is applied, the Slider charts won’t display in your results. Types of Compare Rules Managing Compare Rules To manage your compare rules: Select Rules from the toolbar. Click the three dots menu next to a rule to unapply, edit, rename, copy, or delete it. Click the name of the rule to turn it on or off. A green check mark ✅ next to a rule means that the rule is active. You'll also see any active rules at the top of the page. Exporting & Sharing Rules You can export your results with a rule applied or share your survey results with other people. Save multiple rules together as a view to easily access different sections of your data. Exporting to XLS : When you use a compare rule on a Checkboxes question, the XLS file will show the number of people who submitted your survey, not the number of responses.
